{"uri": "8185593008", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "15:47:14", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T15:47:14Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T15:45:55Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8156862854957581, "url": "https://www.tbsnews.net/sports/albania-dent-croatias-euro-2024-hopes-dramatic-draw-879981", "title": "Albania dent Croatia's Euro 2024 hopes with dramatic draw", "body": "After a disappointing 3-0 loss to Spain in their opener, Croatia were behind again when Qazim Laci gave Albania an early lead in Hamburg.\n\nAlbania left Croatia in danger of a group-stage exit from Euro 2024 after a thrilling 2-2 draw on Wednesday as Albania's Klaus Gjasula scored at both ends, including a dramatic injury-time equaliser.\n\nAfter a disappointing 3-0 loss to Spain in their opener, Croatia were behind again when Qazim Laci gave Albania an early lead in Hamburg.\n\nBut Croatia improved after making two half-time substitutions and Andrej Kramaric levelled with 16 minutes remaining, before Gjasula put through his own net.\n\nThe Albania midfielder became the last-gasp hero, though, slotting into the bottom corner in the fifth minute of injury time to snatch his team a point.\n\nCroatia, World Cup semi-finalists in 2022, will now likely need to win their final Group B match against holders Italy on June 24 to reach the knockout phase for a fifth straight major tournament.\n\nAlbania have won plenty of plaudits with their performances against both Italy, in a 2-1 defeat, and Croatia, but could not hold a lead in either game and will probably have to beat Spain to keep their last-16 hopes alive.\n\nCroatia's 'golden generation' were ultimately made to pay for a poor first-half display and are in danger of bowing out from major tournament football in limp fashion.\n\nCroatia coach Zlatko Dalic opted against a change in formation from the Spain defeat, sticking with his midfield trio of Luka Modric, Mateo Kovacic and Marcelo Brozovic.\n\nBut he brought in Ivan Perisic at left-back, moving Manchester City's Josko Gvardiol into central defence.\n\nAlbania start fast again\n\nThe smell of smoke from flares filled the air outside the stadium as the supporters of both teams created one of the best atmospheres of the tournament so far.\n\nAlbania scored the fastest goal in European Championship history after just 23 seconds against Italy and they made another quick start.\n\nIt took until only the 11th minute for Sylvinho's men to break the deadlock this time, as Sparta Prague midfielder Laci ghosted into the area unmarked to nod home an inch-perfect, inswinging cross from Jasir Asani.\n\nCroatia tried to impose their passing game, but Albania were constantly in their faces and continued to look the more dangerous side, with right-back Elseid Hysaj firing off target.\n\nThe underdogs could have doubled their advantage just after the half-hour mark, but Kristjan Asllani was denied by Dominik Livakovic when face-to-face with the Croatia goalkeeper.\n\nAlbania striker Rey Manaj passed up another excellent opportunity, failing to get enough purchase on his free header in first-half added time to seriously trouble Livakovic.\n\nDalic responded by making two changes at the interval, bringing on 21-year-old Luka Sucic and Mario Pasalic for the ineffective Lovro Majer and Brozovic.\n\nThose substitutions brought about a quick improvement from Croatia, as Albania goalkeeper Thomas Strakosha made a good save to keep out Sucic's left-footed shot, before Pasalic headed over seconds later.\n\nAlbania continued to threaten on the counter-attack, though, with Nedim Bajrami drilling wide of the near post in the 67th minute.\n\nBut Croatia finally found a way through in the 74th minute as substitute Ante Budimir picked out Kramaric inside the box and the forward cut inside before sending a composed finish inside Strakosha's near post.\n\nThe turnaround appeared to be complete two minutes later as Sucic's close-range effort was blocked, but only against the unfortunate Gjasula and into an empty net.\n\nAlbania did not give up, missing a series of chances as it appeared Croatia would cling on.\n\nGjasula had other ideas though, sweeping a loose ball home before a chaotic denouement that saw both sides throw bodies forward in search of a winner, to no avail.", "source": {"uri": {"uri": "2024-06-395057123", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "18:31:11", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T18:31:11Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T15:21:03Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8078431487083435, "url": "https://supersport.com/football/uefa-euro/news/3d50dc01-d2fc-49b9-8832-c3c040c5afb4/albania-dent-croatia-s-euro-2024-hopes-with-dramatic-draw", "title": "Albania dent Croatia's Euro 2024 hopes with dramatic draw", "body": "Albania left Croatia in danger of a group-stage exit from Euro 2024 after a thrilling 2-2 draw on Wednesday as Albania's Klaus Gjasula scored at both ends, including a dramatic injury-time equaliser.\n\nAfter a disappointing 3-0 loss to Spain in their opener, Croatia were behind again when Qazim Laci gave Albania an early lead in Hamburg.\n\nBut Croatia improved after making two halftime substitutions and Andrej Kramaric levelled with 16 minutes remaining, before Gjasula put through his own net.\n\nThe Albania midfielder became the last-gasp hero, though, slotting into the bottom corner in the fifth minute of injury time to snatch his team a point.\n\nCroatia, World Cup semifinalists in 2022, will now likely need to win their final Group B match against holders Italy on June 24 to reach the knockout phase for a fifth straight major tournament.\n\n\"We will believe until the very end, to give our best as we did in this match,\" said forward Kramaric.\n\n\"Unfortunately we didn't win but we hope to be a bit luckier against Italy.\"\n\nAlbania have won plenty of plaudits with their performances against both Italy, in a 2-1 defeat, and Croatia, but could not hold a lead in either game and will probably have to beat Spain to keep their last-16 hopes alive.\n\n\"We have to go forward but we have to fight for every single point,\" said Albania coach Sylvinho.\n\n\"It's important for our lives, the life of the country, the federation. I'm proud of the players so we have to enjoy the moment.\"\n\nCroatia's 'golden generation' were ultimately made to pay for a poor first-half display and are in danger of bowing out from major tournament football in limp fashion.\n\nCroatia coach Zlatko Dalic opted against a change in formation from the Spain defeat, sticking with his midfield trio of Luka Modric, Mateo Kovacic and Marcelo Brozovic.\n\nBut he brought in Ivan Perisic at left-back, moving Manchester City's Josko Gvardiol into central defence.\n\nALBANIA START FAST AGAIN\n\nThe smell of smoke from flares filled the air outside the stadium as the supporters of both teams created one of the best atmospheres of the tournament so far.\n\nAlbania scored the fastest goal in European Championship history after just 23 seconds against Italy and they made another quick start.\n\nIt took until only the 11th minute for Sylvinho's men to break the deadlock this time, as Sparta Prague midfielder Laci ghosted into the area unmarked to nod home an inch-perfect, inswinging cross from Jasir Asani.\n\nCroatia tried to impose their passing game, but Albania were constantly in their faces and continued to look the more dangerous side, with right-back Elseid Hysaj firing off target.\n\nThe underdogs could have doubled their advantage just after the half-hour mark, but Kristjan Asllani was denied by Dominik Livakovic when face-to-face with the Croatia goalkeeper.\n\nAlbania striker Rey Manaj passed up another excellent opportunity, failing to get enough purchase on his free header in first-half added time to seriously trouble Livakovic.\n\nDalic responded by making two changes at the interval, bringing on 21-year-old Luka Sucic and Mario Pasalic for the ineffective Lovro Majer and Brozovic.\n\nThose substitutions brought about a quick improvement from Croatia, as Albania goalkeeper Thomas Strakosha made a good save to keep out Sucic's left-footed shot, before Pasalic headed over seconds later.\n\nAlbania continued to threaten on the counter-attack, though, with Nedim Bajrami drilling wide of the near post in the 67th minute.\n\nBut Croatia finally found a way through in the 74th minute as substitute Ante Budimir picked out Kramaric inside the box and the forward cut inside before sending a composed finish inside Strakosha's near post.\n\nThe turnaround appeared to be complete two minutes later as Sucic's close-range effort was blocked, but only against the unfortunate Gjasula and into an empty net.\n\nAlbania did not give up, missing a series of chances as it appeared Croatia would cling on.\n\nGjasula had other ideas though, sweeping a loose ball home before a chaotic denouement that saw both sides throw bodies forward in search of a winner, to no avail.", {"uri": "2024-06-395080043", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "19:02:06", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T19:02:06Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T15:04:45Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.800000011920929, "url": "https://tribtown.com/2024/06/19/gjasula-scores-own-goal-then-last-gasp-equalizer-for-albania-in-2-2-draw-with-croatia-at-euro-2024/", "title": "Gjasula scores own goal then last-gasp equalizer for Albania in 2-2 draw with Croatia at Euro 2024", "body": "HAMBURG, Germany (AP) -- Albania substitute Klaus Gjasula had the rare experience of scoring for both teams Wednesday in an intense 2-2 draw with Croatia that could make it difficult for each to survive the group stage at Euro 2024.\n\nThe Croatian players were particularly disappointed with the result in Hamburg after Gjasula's stoppage-time goal denied them a much-needed win after they lost 3-0 to Spain in their opening Group B match.\n\n\"My first minutes on the pitch were very, very difficult for me not only for the own goal but also other situations,\" Gjasula said. \"Then God wanted and gave me the opportunity to score. A very beautiful, historic day for me.\"\n\nIn the first-ever competitive match between the two Balkan teams, Croatia tried to set the pace from the start, but it was Albania's Qazim Laci who scored first, heading in a cross from the right flank in the 11th minute.\n\nAndrej Kramaric equalized in the 74th minute before Gjasula's own goal made it 2-1 for Croatia just two minutes later.\n\nAt that point, Croatia looked in control but a late surge by Albania changed everything once again as Gjasula redeemed himself by scoring with a low shot in the 95th minute.\n\nIt was a thrilling end-to-match that leaves both Croatia and Albania in a precarious situation in the group. Albania lost to defending champion Italy 2-1 in its first match.\n\nThe third-place Albanians, who are ahead of Croatia on goal difference, celebrated the most after the match, while Luka Modric and his teammates -- semifinalists at the 2022 World Cup -- looked disappointed as they applauded the Croatian fans.\n\n\"We would have been a lot happier if we hadn't conceded the last goal. The situation would have been totally different,\" Kramaric said. \"We turned the match, and we should have won. But that's football.\"\n\nThe Volksparkstadion in Hamburg was split evenly between red-clad Albania fans and spectators in Croatia's checkered shirt providing a loud and energetic atmosphere.\n\nFans in Croatia's section set off flares repeatedly, despite warnings over the loudspeakers that it would result in disciplinary action.\n\nCroatia struggled to create chances in the first half and could have faced a greater deficit but goalkeeper Dominik Livakovic blocked a shot from Kristjan Asllani and a header from Rey Manaj to keep it 1-0 at halftime.\n\nThe Croatians came out with more energy after the break and turned the match around in two minutes. Kramaric equalized with a shot just inside the post. And just moments later Gjasula was unlucky when Albania tried to clear the ball from the penalty area but it bounced off him and into the net for the fourth own goal of the tournament.\n\nAlbania coach Sylvinho said he was proud of his team's performance. Albania is playing only its second European Championship and was considered unlikely to advance out of the group.\n\n\"It was amazing. I will remember this game all my life,\" he said.\n\n___\n\nAssociated Press writer Llazar Semini in Tirana, Albania, contributed to this report.", "source": {"uri": "tribtown.com", "dataType": {"uri": "8185554299", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "15:20:40", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T15:20:40Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T15:18:02Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7960784435272217, "url": "https://sports.yahoo.com/albania-dent-croatias-euro-2024-151042000.html", "title": "Albania dent Croatia's Euro 2024 hopes with dramatic draw", "body": "Albania left Croatia in danger of a group-stage exit from Euro 2024 after a thrilling 2-2 draw on Wednesday as Albania's Klaus Gjasula scored at both ends, including a dramatic injury-time equaliser.\n\nAfter a disappointing 3-0 loss to Spain in their opener, Croatia were behind again when Qazim Laci gave Albania an early lead in Hamburg.\n\nBut Croatia improved after making two half-time substitutions and Andrej Kramaric levelled with 16 minutes remaining, before Gjasula put through his own net.\n\nThe Albania midfielder became the last-gasp hero, though, slotting into the bottom corner in the fifth minute of injury time to snatch his team a point.\n\nCroatia, World Cup semi-finalists in 2022, will now likely need to win their final Group B match against holders Italy on June 24 to reach the knockout phase for a fifth straight major tournament.\n\nAlbania have won plenty of plaudits with their performances against both Italy, in a 2-1 defeat, and Croatia, but could not hold a lead in either game and will probably have to beat Spain to keep their last-16 hopes alive.\n\nCroatia's 'golden generation' were ultimately made to pay for a poor first-half display and are in danger of bowing out from major tournament football in limp fashion.\n\nCroatia coach Zlatko Dalic opted against a change in formation from the Spain defeat, sticking with his midfield trio of Luka Modric, Mateo Kovacic and Marcelo Brozovic.\n\nThe smell of smoke from flares filled the air outside the stadium as the supporters of both teams created one of the best atmospheres of the tournament so far.\n\nAlbania scored the fastest goal in European Championship history after just 23 seconds against Italy and they made another quick start.\n\nIt took until only the 11th minute for Sylvinho's men to break the deadlock this time, as Sparta Prague midfielder Laci ghosted into the area unmarked to nod home an inch-perfect, inswinging cross from Jasir Asani.\n\nCroatia tried to impose their passing game, but Albania were constantly in their faces and continued to look the more dangerous side, with right-back Elseid Hysaj firing off target.\n\nThe underdogs could have doubled their advantage just after the half-hour mark, but Kristjan Asllani was denied by Dominik Livakovic when face-to-face with the Croatia goalkeeper.\n\nAlbania striker Rey Manaj passed up another excellent opportunity, failing to get enough purchase on his free header in first-half added time to seriously trouble Livakovic.\n\nDalic responded by making two changes at the interval, bringing on 21-year-old Luka Sucic and Mario Pasalic for the ineffective Lovro Majer and Brozovic.\n\nThose substitutions brought about a quick improvement from Croatia, as Albania goalkeeper Thomas Strakosha made a good save to keep out Sucic's left-footed shot, before Pasalic headed over seconds later.\n\nAlbania continued to threaten on the counter-attack, though, with Nedim Bajrami drilling wide of the near post in the 67th minute.\n\nBut Croatia finally found a way through in the 74th minute as substitute Ante Budimir picked out Kramaric inside the box and the forward cut inside before sending a composed finish inside Strakosha's near post.\n\nThe turnaround appeared to be complete two minutes later as Sucic's close-range effort was blocked, but only against the unfortunate Gjasula and into an empty net.\n\nAlbania did not give up, missing a series of chances as it appeared Croatia would cling on.\n\nGjasula had other ideas though, sweeping a loose ball home before a chaotic denouement {"uri": "2024-06-394937422", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "16:11:44", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T16:11:44Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T14:57:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7960784435272217, "url": "https://amp.sportsmole.co.uk/football/croatia/euro-2024/result/gjasula-scores-at-both-ends-as-albania-earn-dramatic-croatia-draw-at-euro-2024_546261.html", "title": "Gjasula scores at both ends as Albania earn dramatic Croatia draw at Euro 2024", "body": "you have updates\n\nKlaus Gjasula has scored at both ends of the pitch as Albania earn a dramatic 2-2 draw with Croatia at Euro 2024.\n\nQazim Laci put Albania in front during the early stages and their advantage was deserved at the break, yet Croatia dominated for large periods of the second half in Hamburg.\n\nAndrej Kramaric and a Gjasula own goal secured the turnaround, but the drama was far from over as the latter fired home from inside the area in the 95th minute to earn his nation what is a tournament-saving point.\n\nWhile the draw keeps both nations in the competition, they face the prospect of having to defeat Italy and Spain in their final Group B fixtures to stand a realistic chance of progressing to the last 16.\n\nAlbania repeat early goal from Italy game\n\nThe notable team news from the Croatia camp was the recall for veteran Ivan Perisic, who started at left-back with Josko Gvardiol moving inside and Marin Pongracic dropping out.\n\nAs for Albania, Chelsea forward Armando Broja missed out on a starting role with free-scoring Sivasspor attacker Rey Manaj chosen in his place.\n\nIn a sun-kissed Hamburg, Croatia dominated the opening exchanges with Albania prepared to sit deep, but the minnows of the competition incredibly scored their second early goal of the tournament in the 11th minute.\n\nJasir Asani bided his time on the ball out on the right, waiting for a run from a teammate. It was Laci who took responsibility, sprinting 25 yards to get in behind Perisic and glance an inswinging delivery past goalkeeper Dominik Livakovic.\n\nThe pattern of the game remained set, with Albania remaining deep and breaking in their droves, yet it took until the 21st minute for Croatia to threaten a goal as Marcelo Brozovic sent the ball wide of the far post from distance.\n\nBruno Petkovic should have also done better with a header from eight yards out, and it almost cost Croatia as Albania squandered a golden opportunity at the other end, Kristjan Asllani somehow failing to beat Livakovic having gotten in behind the defence.\n\nIn the final moments of the half, Manaj was also guilty of failing to double Albania's lead, sending a header straight at Livakovic from in front of goal.\n\nDalic reacts to poor opening 45 minutes\n\nZlatko Dalic wasted no time in tinkering with his Croatia side, making two changes as Luka Sucic and Mario Pasalic were introduced in place of Brozovic and Lovro Majer.\n\nWithin five minutes of the restart, Sucic should have scored having found space inside the area, only for goalkeeper Thomas Strakosha to remain big and parry his effort away from danger.\n\nThat was the catalyst for a sustained spell of pressure from Croatia as Albania dropped deeper and deeper, their attackers - possibly jaded from their first-half efforts - feeding on mere scraps.\n\nTo their credit, Albania responded in brief flurries, giving their backline a well-earned breather, yet as the game entered the final quarter, Pasalic sent another header over the crossbar at the far post.\n\nCroatia's equaliser finally came with 16 minutes remaining. Kramaric had been ineffective for much of the contest, but the 33-year-old - on his birthday - showed the composure required in the big moment when needed, wrong-footing an Albania defender before slotting the ball inside the near corner from 10 yards.\n\nAlbania's hearts broke when Croatia went ahead shortly afterwards. After Kramaric combined with Ante Budimir, the latter pulled the ball back where an Albania defender struck the ball against the helpless Gjasula and into the net.\n\nThat goal knocked the stuffing out of Albania and it felt that a fourth goal of the contest was far more likely to come from Croatia as the game approached a conclusion.\n\nHowever, Sylvinho's side made a mockery of that perception. Gvardiol had bravely prevented Mirlind Daku from volleying home from close range, but it only set up Gjasula for his famous moment, the Darmstadt 98 midfielder - who had been introduced as a substitute - sweeping home from 12 yards to send Albania fans into delirium as they collected just their fourth point at a European Championship.\n\nMan of the Match\n\nBoth sides had contenders for the man of the match accolade, yet we cannot give it to anyone else but Gjasula, who was only on the pitch for 18 minutes plus seven minutes of added-on time.\n\nThe 34-year-old had never scored for his country and has just one club goal to his name since the start of 2020-21. Realistically, the veteran has just become the answer to a quiz question that will stand the test of time.\n\nWhen do Croatia, Albania play again at Euro 2024?\n\nThe remaining fixtures for Croatia and Albania will each take place on Monday at 8pm, BST, with Croatia facing Italy and Albania squaring off against Spain.\n\nbody check tags ::", "source": {"uri": "amp.sportsmole.co.uk", "dataType": secure 2-2 draw against Croatia", "body": "Albania left Croatia in danger of a group-stage exit from Euro 2024 after a thrilling 2-2 draw on Wednesday (Jun 19) as Albania's Klaus Gjasula scored at both ends, including a dramatic injury-time equaliser.\n\nAfter a disappointing 3-0 loss to Spain in their opener, Croatia were behind again when Qazim Laci gave Albania an early lead in Hamburg.\n\nBut Croatia improved after making two half-time substitutions and Andrej Kramaric levelled with 16 minutes remaining, before Gjasula put one in his own net, courtesy of a nasty deflection.\n\nThe Albania midfielder became the last-gasp hero, though, slotting into the bottom corner in the fifth minute of injury time to snatch his team a point.\n\nCroatia, World Cup semi-finalists in 2022, will now likely need to win their final Group B match against holders Italy on June 24 to reach the knockout phase for a fifth straight major tournament.\n\nAlbania have won plenty of plaudits with their performances against both Italy, in a 2-1 defeat, and Croatia, but could not hold a lead in either game and will probably have to beat Spain to keep their last-16 hopes alive.\n\nCroatia's 'golden generation' were ultimately made to pay for a poor first-half display and are in danger of bowing out from major tournament football in limp fashion.\n\nCroatia coach Zlatko Dalic opted against a change in formation from the Spain defeat, sticking with his midfield trio of Luka Modric, Mateo Kovacic and Marcelo Brozovic.\n\nBut he brought in Ivan Perisic at left-back, moving Manchester City's Josko Gvardiol into central defence.\n\nAlso read | Who is Arda G\u00fcler? The Turkish Messi who lit up Euro 2024 with wonder strike\n\nThe smell of smoke from flares filled the air outside the stadium as the supporters of both teams created one of the best atmospheres of the tournament so far.\n\nAlbania scored the fastest goal in European Championship history after just 23 seconds against Italy and they made another quick start.\n\nIt took until only the 11th minute for Sylvinho's men to break the deadlock this time, as Sparta Prague midfielder Laci ghosted into the area unmarked to nod home an inch-perfect, inswinging cross from Jasir Asani.\n\nCroatia tried to impose their passing game, but Albania were constantly in their faces and continued to look the more dangerous side, with right-back Elseid Hysaj firing off target.\n\nThe underdogs could have doubled their advantage just after the half-hour mark, but Kristjan Asllani was denied by Dominik Livakovic when face-to-face with the Croatia goalkeeper.\n\nAlbania striker Rey Manaj passed up another excellent opportunity, failing to get enough purchase on his free header in first-half added time to seriously trouble Livakovic.\n\nDalic responded by making two changes at the interval, bringing on 21-year-old Luka Sucic and Mario Pasalic for the ineffective Lovro Majer and Brozovic.\n\nThose substitutions brought about a quick improvement from Croatia, as Albania goalkeeper Thomas Strakosha made a good save to keep out Sucic's left-footed shot, before Pasalic headed over seconds later.\n\nAlbania continued to threaten on the counter-attack, though, with Nedim Bajrami drilling wide of the near post in the 67th minute.\n\nBut Croatia finally found a way through in the 74th minute as substitute Ante Budimir picked out Kramaric inside the box and the forward cut inside before sending a composed finish inside Strakosha's near post.\n\nThe turnaround appeared to be complete two minutes later as Sucic's close-range effort was blocked, but only against the unfortunate Gjasula and into an empty net.\n\nAlbania did not give up, missing a series of chances as it appeared Croatia would cling on.\n\nGjasula had other ideas though, sweeping a loose ball home before a chaotic denouement A very beautiful, historic day for me.\"\n\nIn the first-ever competitive match between the two Balkan teams, Croatia tried to set the pace from the start, but it was Albania's Qazim Laci who scored first, heading in a cross from the right flank in the 11th minute.\n\nAndrej Kramaric equalized in the 74th minute before Gjasula's own goal made it 2-1 for Croatia just two minutes later.\n\nAt that point, Croatia looked in control but a late surge by Albania changed everything once again as Gjasula redeemed himself by scoring with a low shot in the 95th minute.\n\nIt was a thrilling end-to-match that leaves both Croatia and Albania in a precarious situation in the group. Albania lost to defending champion Italy 2-1 in its first match.\n\nThe third-place Albanians, who are ahead of Croatia on goal difference, celebrated the most after the match, while Luka Modric and his teammates -- semifinalists at the 2022 World Cup -- looked disappointed as they applauded the Croatian fans.\n\n\"We would have been a lot happier if we hadn't conceded the last goal. The situation would have been totally different,\" Kramaric said. \"We turned the match, and we should have won. But that's football.\"\n\nThe Volksparkstadion in Hamburg was split evenly between red-clad Albania fans and spectators in Croatia's checkered shirt providing a loud and energetic atmosphere.\n\nFans in Croatia's section set off flares repeatedly, despite warnings over the loudspeakers that it would result in disciplinary action.\n\nCroatia struggled to create chances in the first half and could have faced a greater deficit but goalkeeper Dominik Livakovic blocked a shot from Kristjan Asllani and a header from Rey Manaj to keep it 1-0 at halftime.\n\nThe Croatians came out with more energy after the break and turned the match around in two minutes. Kramaric equalized with a shot just inside the post. And just moments later Gjasula was unlucky when Albania tried to clear the ball from the penalty area but it bounced off him and into the net for the fourth own goal of the tournament.\n\nAlbania coach Sylvinho said he was proud of his team's performance. Albania is playing only its second European Championship and was considered unlikely to advance out of the group.\n\n\"It was amazing. {"uri": "2024-06-394978209", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "16:55:19", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T16:55:19Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T11:04:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7882353067398071, "url": "https://www.usnews.com/news/sports/articles/2024-06-19/gjasula-scores-own-goal-then-last-gasp-equalizer-for-albania-in-2-2-draw-with-croatia-at-euro-2024", "title": "Gjasula Scores Own Goal Then Last-Gasp Equalizer for Albania in 2-2 Draw With Croatia at Euro 2024", "body": "HAMBURG, Germany (AP) -- Albania substitute Klaus Gjasula had the rare experience of scoring for both teams Wednesday in an intense 2-2 draw with Croatia that could make it difficult for each to survive the group stage at Euro 2024.\n\nThe Croatian players were particularly disappointed with the result in Hamburg after Gjasula's stoppage-time goal denied them a much-needed win after they lost 3-0 to Spain in their opening Group B match.\n\n\"My first minutes on the pitch were very, very difficult for me not only for the own goal but also other situations,\" Gjasula said. \"Then God wanted and gave me the opportunity to score. A very beautiful, historic day for me.\"\n\nIn the first-ever competitive match between the two Balkan teams, Croatia tried to set the pace from the start, but it was Albania's Qazim Laci who scored first, heading in a cross from the right flank in the 11th minute.\n\nAndrej Kramaric equalized in the 74th minute before Gjasula's own goal made it 2-1 for Croatia just two minutes later.\n\nAt that point, Croatia looked in control but a late surge by Albania changed everything once again as Gjasula redeemed himself by scoring with a low shot in the 95th minute.\n\nIt was a thrilling end-to-match that leaves both Croatia and Albania in a precarious situation in the group. Albania lost to defending champion Italy 2-1 in its first match.\n\nThe third-place Albanians, who are ahead of Croatia on goal difference, celebrated the most after the match, while Luka Modric and his teammates -- semifinalists at the 2022 World Cup -- looked disappointed as they applauded the Croatian fans.\n\n\"We would have been a lot happier if we hadn't conceded the last goal. The situation would have been totally different,\" Kramaric said. \"We turned the match, and we should have won. But that's football.\"\n\nThe Volksparkstadion in Hamburg was split evenly between red-clad Albania fans and spectators in Croatia's checkered shirt providing a loud and energetic atmosphere.\n\nFans in Croatia's section set off flares repeatedly, despite warnings over the loudspeakers that it would result in disciplinary action.\n\nCroatia struggled to create chances in the first half and could have faced a greater deficit but goalkeeper Dominik Livakovic blocked a shot from Kristjan Asllani and a header from Rey Manaj to keep it 1-0 at halftime.\n\nThe Croatians came out with more energy after the break and turned the match around in two minutes. Kramaric equalized with a shot just inside the post. And just moments later Gjasula was unlucky when Albania tried to clear the ball from the penalty area but it bounced off him and into the net for the fourth own goal of the tournament.\n\nAlbania coach Sylvinho said he was proud of his team's performance. Albania is playing only its second European Championship and was considered unlikely to advance out of the group.\n\n\"It was amazing. I will remember this game all my life,\" he said.\n\n___\n\nAssociated Press writer Llazar Semini in Tirana, Albania, contributed to this report.\n\nCopyright 2024 The Associated Press. All rights reserved. {"uri": "8185844805", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "19:14:36", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T19:14:36Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T19:13:50Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7882353067398071, "url": "https://sports.ndtv.com/uefa-euro-2024/albania-dent-croatias-euro-2024-hopes-with-dramatic-draw-5926664", "title": "Albania Dent Croatia's Euro 2024 Hopes With Dramatic Draw | Football News", "body": "Albania left Croatia in danger of a group-stage exit from Euro 2024 after a thrilling 2-2 draw on Wednesday as Albania's Klaus Gjasula scored at both ends, including a dramatic injury-time equaliser. After a disappointing 3-0 loss to Spain in their opener, Croatia were behind again when Qazim Laci gave Albania an early lead in Hamburg. But Croatia improved after making two half-time substitutions and Andrej Kramaric levelled with 16 minutes remaining, before Gjasula put through his own net.\n\nThe Albania midfielder became the last-gasp hero, though, slotting into the bottom corner in the fifth minute of injury time to snatch his team a point.\n\nCroatia, World Cup semi-finalists in 2022, will now likely need to win their final Group B match against holders Italy on June 24 to reach the knockout phase for a fifth straight major tournament. \"We will believe until the very end, to give our best as we did in this match,\" said forward Kramaric.\n\n\"Unfortunately we didn't win but we hope to be a bit luckier against Italy.\"\n\nAlbania have won plenty of plaudits with their performances against both Italy, in a 2-1 defeat, and Croatia, but could not hold a lead in either game and will probably have to beat Spain to keep their last-16 hopes alive. \"We have to go forward but we have to fight for every single point,\" said Albania coach Sylvinho.\n\n\"It's important for our lives, the life of the country, the federation. I'm proud of the players so we have to enjoy the moment.\"\n\nCroatia's 'golden generation' were ultimately made to pay for a poor first-half display and are on the brink of bowing out from major tournament football in limp fashion.\n\nThe smell of smoke from flares filled the air outside the stadium as the supporters of both teams created one of the best atmospheres of the tournament so far.\n\nAlbania scored the fastest goal in European Championship history after just 23 seconds against Italy and they made another quick start.\n\nIt took until only the 11th minute for Sylvinho's men to break the deadlock this time, as Sparta Prague midfielder Laci ghosted into the area unmarked to nod home an inch-perfect, inswinging cross from Jasir Asani.\n\nCroatia tried to impose their passing game, but Albania were constantly in their faces and continued to look the more dangerous side, with right-back Elseid Hysaj firing off target.\n\nThe underdogs could have doubled their advantage just after the half-hour mark, but Kristjan Asllani was denied by Dominik Livakovic when face-to-face with the Croatia goalkeeper.\n\nAlbania striker Rey Manaj passed up another excellent opportunity, failing to get enough purchase on his free header in first-half added time to seriously trouble Livakovic.\n\nDalic responded by making two changes at the interval, bringing on 21-year-old Luka Sucic and Mario Pasalic for the ineffective Lovro Majer and Brozovic.\n\nThose substitutions brought about a quick improvement from Croatia, as Albania goalkeeper Thomas Strakosha made a good save to keep out Sucic's left-footed shot, before Pasalic headed over seconds later.\n\nCroatia finally found a way through in the 74th minute as substitute Ante Budimir picked out Kramaric inside the box and he cut inside before sending a composed finish inside Strakosha's near post.\n\nThe turnaround appeared to be complete two minutes later as Sucic's close-range effort was blocked, but rebounded off the unfortunate Gjasula and into an empty net.\n\nAlbania did not give up, missing a series of late chances as it appeared Croatia would cling on.\n\nGjasula had other ideas though, sweeping a loose ball home before a chaotic denouement that saw both sides throw bodies forward in search of a winner, to no avail.", "source": {"uri": "sports.ndtv.com", "dataType": "news", (AP Photo/Ebrahim Noroozi)\n\nThe Volksparkstadion in Hamburg was split evenly between red-clad Albania fans and spectators in Croatia\u00b4s checkered shirt providing a loud and energetic atmosphere throughout the match.\n\nFans in Croatia's section set off flares repeatedly, despite warnings over the loudspeakers that it would result in disciplinary action.\n\nCroatia struggled to create chances in the first half and could have faced a greater deficit but goalkeeper Dominik Livakovic blocked a shot from Kristjan Asllani and a header from Rey Manaj to keep it 1-0 at halftime.\n\nThe Croatians came out with more energy in the second half and turned the match around in two minutes. Kramaric equalized with a shot just inside the post. And just moments later Gjasula was unlucky when Albania tried to clear the ball from the penalty area but it bounced off him and into the net for the fourth own goal of the tournament.\n\nAt that point Croatia seemed to be in control but Gjasula's strike five minutes into injury time made it 2-2 to the delight of the Albanian fans.\n\nAP Euro 2024: https://apnews.com/hub/euro-2024\n\nCroatia's scorer Andrej Kramaric, left, and his teammate Luka Sucic, right, celebrate their side's first goal during a Group B match between Croatia and Albania at the Euro 2024 soccer tournament in Hamburg, Germany, Wednesday, June 19, 2024. Croatia were pegging and pressing for the equaliser but were absolutely wasterful in the front of goal for most of the game.\n\nHowever in the 74th minute Croatia forward Andrej Kramaric finally put an end to the misery and equalised for Kroatia. Gjasula has now become the first player ever to score a goal and an own goal in the same match by coming off the bench.\n\nThe final whistle went and both Albania and Croatia shared the spoils. {"uri": "2024-06-394936514", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "16:11:06", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T16:11:06Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T15:12:14Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.772549033164978, "url": "https://www.rfi.fr/en/sports/20240619-albania-dent-croatia-s-euro-2024-hopes-with-dramatic-draw", "title": "Albania dent Croatia's Euro 2024 hopes with dramatic draw", "body": "After a disappointing 3-0 loss to Spain in their opener, Croatia were behind again when Qazim Laci gave Albania an early lead in Hamburg.\n\nBut Croatia improved after making two half-time substitutions and Andrej Kramaric levelled with 16 minutes remaining, before Gjasula put through his own net.\n\nThe Albania midfielder became the last-gasp hero, though, slotting into the bottom corner in the fifth minute of injury time to snatch his team a point.\n\nCroatia, World Cup semi-finalists in 2022, will now likely need to win their final Group B match against holders Italy on June 24 to reach the knockout phase for a fifth straight major tournament.\n\n\"We will believe until the very end, to give our best as we did in this match,\" said forward Kramaric.\n\n\"Unfortunately we didn't win but we hope to be a bit luckier against Italy.\"\n\nAlbania have won plenty of plaudits with their performances against both Italy, in a 2-1 defeat, and Croatia, but could not hold a lead in either game and will probably have to beat Spain to keep their last-16 hopes alive.\n\n\"We have to go forward but we have to fight for every single point,\" said Albania coach Sylvinho.\n\n\"It's important for our lives, the life of the country, the federation. I'm proud of the players so we have to enjoy the moment.\"\n\nCroatia's 'golden generation' were ultimately made to pay for a poor first-half display and are on the brink of bowing out from major tournament football in limp fashion.\n\nCroatia coach Zlatko Dalic opted against a change in formation from the Spain defeat, sticking with his midfield trio of Luka Modric, Mateo Kovacic and Marcelo Brozovic.\n\nBut he brought in Ivan Perisic at left-back, moving Manchester City's Josko Gvardiol into central defence.\n\nAlbania start fast again\n\nThe smell of smoke from flares filled the air outside the stadium as the supporters of both teams created one of the best atmospheres of the tournament so far.\n\nAlbania scored the fastest goal in European Championship history after just 23 seconds against Italy and they made another quick start.\n\nIt took until only the 11th minute for Sylvinho's men to break the deadlock this time, as Sparta Prague midfielder Laci ghosted into the area unmarked to nod home an inch-perfect, inswinging cross from Jasir Asani.\n\nCroatia tried to impose their passing game, but Albania were constantly in their faces and continued to look the more dangerous side, with right-back Elseid Hysaj firing off target.\n\nThe underdogs could have doubled their advantage just after the half-hour mark, but Kristjan Asllani was denied by Dominik Livakovic when face-to-face with the Croatia goalkeeper.\n\nAlbania striker Rey Manaj passed up another excellent opportunity, failing to get enough purchase on his free header in first-half added time to seriously trouble Livakovic.\n\nDalic responded by making two changes at the interval, bringing on 21-year-old Luka Sucic and Mario Pasalic for the ineffective Lovro Majer and Brozovic.\n\nThose substitutions brought about a quick improvement from Croatia, as Albania goalkeeper Thomas Strakosha made a good save to keep out Sucic's left-footed shot, before Pasalic headed over seconds later.\n\nCroatia finally found a way through in the 74th minute as substitute Ante Budimir picked out Kramaric inside the box and he cut inside before sending a composed finish inside Strakosha's near post.\n\nThe turnaround appeared to be complete two minutes later as Sucic's close-range effort was blocked, but rebounded off the unfortunate Gjasula and into an empty net.\n\nAlbania did not give up, missing a series of late chances as it appeared Croatia would cling on.\n\nGjasula had other ideas though, sweeping a loose ball home before a chaotic denouement that saw both sides throw {"uri": "8185724982", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "17:31:49", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T17:31:49Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T17:28:10Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.772549033164978, "url": "https://www.latestly.com/agency-news/sports-news-gjasula-scores-own-goal-then-last-gasp-equalizer-for-albania-in-2-2-draw-with-croatia-at-euro-2024-6050258.html", "title": "Sports News | Gjasula Scores Own Goal then Last-gasp Equalizer for Albania in 2-2 Draw with Croatia at Euro 2024 | LatestLY", "body": "Get latest articles and stories on Sports at LatestLY. Albania substitute Klaus Gjasula had the rare experience of scoring for both teams Wednesday in an intense 2-2 draw with Croatia that could make it difficult for each to survive the group stage at Euro 2024.\n\nHamurg (Germany), Jun 19 (AP) Albania substitute Klaus Gjasula had the rare experience of scoring for both teams Wednesday in an intense 2-2 draw with Croatia that could make it difficult for each to survive the group stage at Euro 2024.\n\nThe Croatian players were particularly disappointed with the result in Hamburg after Gjasula's stoppage-time goal denied them a much-needed win after they lost 3-0 to Spain in their opening Group B match.\n\nAlso Read | Copa America 2024 Schedule in IST, Free PDF Download Online: Get Fixtures, Time Table With Match Timings and Venue Details of CONMEBOL Football Tournament.\n\n\"My first minutes on the pitch were very, very difficult for me not only for the own goal but also other situations,\" Gjasula said. \"Then God wanted and gave me the opportunity to score. A very beautiful, historic day for me.\"\n\nIn the first-ever competitive match between the two Balkan teams, Croatia tried to set the pace from the start, but it was Albania's Qazim Laci who scored first, heading in a cross from the right flank in the 11th minute.\n\nAlso Read | England vs West Indies Free Live Streaming Online, ICC Men's T20 World Cup 2024 Super 8: How To Watch ENG vs WI Cricket Match Live Telecast on TV?.\n\nAndrej Kramaric equalized in the 74th minute before Gjasula's own goal made it 2-1 for Croatia just two minutes later.\n\nAt that point, Croatia looked in control but a late surge by Albania changed everything once again as Gjasula redeemed himself by scoring with a low shot in the 95th minute.\n\nIt was a thrilling end-to-match that leaves both Croatia and Albania in a precarious situation in the group. Albania lost to defending champion Italy 2-1 in its first match.\n\nThe third-place Albanians, who are ahead of Croatia on goal difference, celebrated the most after the match, while Luka Modric and his teammates -- semifinalists at the 2022 World Cup -- looked disappointed as they applauded the Croatian fans.\n\n\"We would have been a lot happier if we hadn't conceded the last goal. The situation would have been totally different,\" Kramaric said. \"We turned the match, and we should have won. But that's football.\"\n\nThe Volksparkstadion in Hamburg was split evenly between red-clad Albania fans and spectators in Croatia's checkered shirt providing a loud and energetic atmosphere.\n\nFans in Croatia's section set off flares repeatedly, despite warnings over the loudspeakers that it would result in disciplinary action.\n\nCroatia struggled to create chances in the first half and could have faced a greater deficit but goalkeeper Dominik Livakovic blocked a shot from Kristjan Asllani and a header from Rey Manaj to keep it 1-0 at halftime.\n\nThe Croatians came out with more energy after the break and turned the match around in two minutes. Kramaric equalized with a shot just inside the post. And just moments later Gjasula was unlucky when Albania tried to clear the ball from the penalty area but it bounced off him and into the net for the fourth own goal of the tournament.\n\nAlbania coach Sylvinho said he was proud of his team's performance. Albania is playing only its second European Championship and was considered unlikely to advance out of the group.\n\n\"It was amazing. I will remember this game all my life,\" he said. The late goal by Gjasula, coming in the 95th minute, changed the match's outcome and left Croatian players and fans alike in dismay.\n\n\"My first minutes on the pitch were very, very difficult for me not only for the own goal but also other situations,\" Gjasula reflected. \"Then God wanted and gave me the opportunity to score. A very beautiful, historic day for me.\"\n\nIn the first-ever competitive match between these Balkan nations, Albania struck first with Qazim Laci heading in a cross from the right flank in the 11th minute. Croatia struggled to find their rhythm in the first half and faced a 1-0 deficit at halftime, thanks to key saves by their goalkeeper Dominik Livakovic.\n\nThe second half saw Croatia come out with renewed energy. Andrej Kramaric equalized in the 74th minute with a precise shot inside the post. Just two minutes later, Gjasula inadvertently gave Croatia the lead with an own goal during a chaotic clearance attempt by Albania.\n\nCroatia appeared to be on the path to victory until Gjasula redeemed himself by scoring a low shot in stoppage time, securing a 2-2 draw and dramatically altering the group dynamics. The match's thrilling conclusion left both teams in precarious positions, with Albania slightly ahead of Croatia on goal difference.\n\nThe draw was particularly celebrated by Albania, who had lost 2-1 to defending champions Italy in their first match. "sim": 0.7686274647712708, "url": "https://africa.espn.com/football/report/_/gameId/690586", "title": "Croatia 2-2 Albania (19 Jun, 2024) Game Analysis - ESPN", "body": "Albania snatched an equaliser in added time for a stunning 2-2 draw against Croatia in a thrilling European Championship contest on Wednesday, but the result left both countries with a tall order if they are to progress to the round of 16.\n\nKlaus Gjasula proved both hero and villain, bagging the added time leveller after having earlier netted an own goal that saw Croatia go 2-1 up in the Group B clash at the Volksparkstadion.\n\nBoth countries now have a single point after their opening two matches and are left effectively needing to win their last group games on Monday if they are to progress into the knockout stage.\n\nNo team has made the next round with just two draws since the Euro finals expanded to 24 teams in 2016 -- offering a place in the last-16 to the four best third-placed finishers.\n\nAlbania had taken an early lead but the Croats scored twice in the space of two minutes to revive their hopes in a match full of twists and turns and played to a backdrop of ear-splitting noise.\n\nAndrej Kramaric grabbed a 74th minute equaliser and then followed an own goal from Gjasula 120 seconds later as an increasingly dominant Croatia, who lost 3-0 to Spain in their opening game, clawed their way back.\n\nThey had pounded away at the Albania goal in the second half after looking anxious and frustrated at halftime as their unfancied opponents went into the break ahead.\n\nQazim Laci's 11th minute header put Albania in an early lead, as had been the case against Italy in their opening game when they scored after just 23 seconds.\n\nThis time they were a touch tardy, weathering early pressure before Jasir Asani whipped in a cross from the right that Laci got a glancing head to before it slipped under goalkeeper Dominik Livakovic.\n\nThe Croat keeper could have done better but made up for the slip with two key saves later in the first half, denying Kristjan Asllani and then stopping Rey Manaj's diving header as Albania came close to doubling their lead.\n\nAlbania's gritty determination -- and the speed with which they seized counterattacking opportunities -- belied their lowly ranking, some 56 places below 10th placed Croatia.\n\nA double change at the break for Croatia was followed by intense pressure on the Albania goal with Thomas Strakosha saving from Luka Sucic and Mateo Kovacic to keep the lead intact right until the 74th minute when Kramaric, on his 33rd birthday, netted from close range.\n\nBut Albania were not to be outdone and Gjasula sidefooted into the net with five minutes of additional time already played for a dramatic conclusion to the contest.\n\n\"This is why everyone loves football. In the last seconds, sometimes you score a goal to win, sometimes you concede,\" said Kramaric.\n\nAlbania finish their group schedule against Spain in Dusseldorf on Monday and Gjasula said they held out hope.\n\n\"We know that the game with Spain is very difficult but in football everything is possible. If we will play like today everything can happen,\" he told reporters.\n\nCroatia will meet Italy in Leipzig at the same time with the odds against them.\n\n\"The first half was very bad but the second much better, which is encouraging for the match with Italy,\" added Croatia coach Zlatko Dalic. \"We are still in the game, we shall prepare and do all in our power to go on.\"", "source": trouble", "body": "Croatia held by Albania, leaving both in Euro24 troubleStaff WritersAPThu, 20 June 2024 12:16AM\n\nCroatia and Albania have drawn 2-2 in an intense battle at Euro 2024, a result that could make it difficult for both teams to survive the group stages.\n\nIn the first ever competitive match between the two Balkan teams on Wednesday, Croatia tried to set the pace from the start, but it was Albania's Qazim Laci who scored first, heading in a cross from the right flank in the 11th minute.\n\nAndrej Kramaric equalised about half an hour into the second half and an own goal by Klaus Gjasula made it 2-1 for Croatia just two minutes later.\n\nGjasula then redeemed himself by scoring Albania's equaliser in injury time.\n\nTheNightlyGet in front of tomorrow's news for FREE\n\nJournalism for the curious Australian across politics, business, culture and opinion.\n\nREAD NOW\n\nThe result leaves both sides in a precarious situation in group B after Croatia lost to Spain and Albania to Italy in their first matches.\n\nThe Albanians, who are ahead of Croatia on goal difference in the group standings, celebrated most after the match, while Luka Modric and his teammates looked disappointed as they applauded the Croatian fans.\n\nThe Volksparkstadion in Hamburg was split evenly between red-clad Albania fans and spectators in Croatia's checkered shirt providing a loud and energetic atmosphere throughout the match.\n\nFans in Croatia's section set off flares repeatedly, despite warnings over the loudspeakers that it would result in disciplinary action.\n\nCroatia struggled to create chances in the first half and could have faced a greater deficit but goalkeeper Dominik Livakovic blocked a shot from Kristjan Asllani and a header from Rey Manaj to keep it 1-0 at halftime.\n\nThe Croatians came out with more energy in the second half and turned the match around in two minutes.\n\nKramaric equalised with a shot just inside the post and, just moments later, Gjasula was unlucky when Albania tried to clear the ball from the penalty area but it bounced off him and into the net for the fourth own goal of the tournament.\n\nAt that point, Croatia seemed to be in control but Gjasula's strike five minutes into injury time made it 2-2 to the delight of the Albanian fans.\n\nGet the latest news from thewest.com.au in your inbox.\n\nSign up with dramatic draw", "body": "After a disappointing 3-0 loss to Spain in their opener, Croatia were behind again when Qazim Laci gave Albania an early lead in Hamburg.\n\nBut Croatia improved after making two half-time substitutions and Andrej Kramaric levelled with 16 minutes remaining, before Gjasula put through his own net.\n\nThe Albania midfielder became the last-gasp hero, though, slotting into the bottom corner in the fifth minute of injury time to snatch his team a point.\n\nCroatia, World Cup semi-finalists in 2022, will now likely need to win their final Group B match against holders Italy on June 24 to reach the knockout phase for a fifth straight major tournament.\n\nAlbania have won plenty of plaudits with their performances against both Italy, in a 2-1 defeat, and Croatia, but could not hold a lead in either game and will probably have to beat Spain to keep their last-16 hopes alive.\n\nCroatia's 'golden generation' were ultimately made to pay for a poor first-half display and are in danger of bowing out from major tournament football in limp fashion.\n\nCroatia coach Zlatko Dalic opted against a change in formation from the Spain defeat, sticking with his midfield trio of Luka Modric, Mateo Kovacic and Marcelo Brozovic.\n\nBut he brought in Ivan Perisic at left-back, moving Manchester City's Josko Gvardiol into central defence.\n\nAlbania start fast again\n\nThe smell of smoke from flares filled the air outside the stadium as the supporters of both teams created one of the best atmospheres of the tournament so far.\n\nAlbania scored the fastest goal in European Championship history after just 23 seconds against Italy and they made another quick start.\n\nIt took until only the 11th minute for Sylvinho's men to break the deadlock this time, as Sparta Prague midfielder Laci ghosted into the area unmarked to nod home an inch-perfect, inswinging cross from Jasir Asani.\n\nCroatia tried to impose their passing game, but Albania were constantly in their faces and continued to look the more dangerous side, with right-back Elseid Hysaj firing off target.\n\nThe underdogs could have doubled their advantage just after the half-hour mark, but Kristjan Asllani was denied by Dominik Livakovic when face-to-face with the Croatia goalkeeper.\n\nAlbania striker Rey Manaj passed up another excellent opportunity, failing to get enough purchase on his free header in first-half added time to seriously trouble Livakovic.\n\nDalic responded by making two changes at the interval, bringing on 21-year-old Luka Sucic and Mario Pasalic for the ineffective Lovro Majer and Brozovic.\n\nThose substitutions brought about a quick improvement from Croatia, as Albania goalkeeper Thomas Strakosha made a good save to keep out Sucic's left-footed shot, before Pasalic headed over seconds later.\n\nAlbania continued to threaten on the counter-attack, though, with Nedim Bajrami drilling wide of the near post in the 67th minute.\n\nBut Croatia finally found a way through in the 74th minute as substitute Ante Budimir picked out Kramaric inside the box and the forward cut inside before sending a composed finish inside Strakosha's near post.\n\nThe turnaround appeared to be complete two minutes later as Sucic's close-range effort was blocked, but only against the unfortunate Gjasula and into an empty net.\n\nAlbania did not give up, missing a series of chances as it appeared Croatia would cling on.\n\nGjasula had other ideas though, sweeping a loose ball home before a chaotic denouement that saw both sides throw bodies forward in {"uri": "2024-06-395203851", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "22:22:56", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T22:22:56Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T21:45:48Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7647058963775635, "url": "https://theshillongtimes.com/2024/06/20/albania-score-stoppage-time-equaliser-to-hold-croatia/", "title": "Albania score stoppage time equaliser to hold Croatia", "body": "Hamurg, June 19: Albania substitute Klaus Gjasula had the rare experience of scoring for both teams Wednesday in an intense 2-2 draw with Croatia that could make it difficult for each to survive the group stage at Euro 2024.\n\nThe Croatian players were particularly disappointed with the result in Hamburg after Gjasula's stoppage-time goal denied them a much-needed win after they lost 3-0 to Spain in their opening Group B match.\"My first minutes on the pitch were very, very difficult for me not only for the own goal but also other situations,\" Gjasula said. \"Then God wanted and gave me the opportunity to score. A very beautiful, historic day for me.\" In the first-ever competitive match between the two Balkan teams, Croatia tried to set the pace from the start, but it was Albania's Qazim Laci who scored first, heading in a cross from the right flank in the 11th minute.\n\nAndrej Kramaric equalized in the 74th minute before Gjasula's own goal made it 2-1 for Croatia just two minutes later.At that point, Croatia looked in control but a late surge by Albania changed everything once again as Gjasula redeemed himself by scoring with a low shot in the 95th minute.It was a thrilling end-to-match that leaves both Croatia and Albania in a precarious situation in the group. Albania lost to defending champion Italy 2-1 in its first match.\n\nThe third-place Albanians, who are ahead of Croatia on goal difference, celebrated the most after the match, while Luka Modric and his teammates - semifinalists at the 2022 World Cup - looked disappointed as they applauded the Croatian fans.\n\n\"We would have been a lot happier if we hadn't conceded the last goal. The situation would have been totally different,\" Kramaric said. \"We turned the match, and we should have won. But that's football.\"\n\nThe Volksparkstadion in Hamburg was split evenly between red-clad Albania fans and spectators in Croatia's checkered shirt providing a loud and energetic atmosphere.Fans in Croatia's section set off flares repeatedly, despite warnings over the loudspeakers that it would result in disciplinary action.\n\nCroatia struggled to create chances in the first half and could have faced a greater deficit but goalkeeper Dominik Livakovic blocked a shot from Kristjan Asllani and a header from Rey Manaj to keep it 1-0 at halftime.\n\nThe Croatians came out with more energy after the break and turned the match around. "sim": 0.7568627595901489, "url": "https://www.dailymail.co.uk/wires/reuters/article-13547525/Soccer-Albania-score-stoppage-time-equaliser-hold-Croatia.html", "title": "Soccer-Albania score stoppage time equaliser to hold Croatia", "body": "Added time equaliser for Albania\n\n*\n\nFirst points for Albania, Croatia\n\n*\n\nCroatia fought back from halftime deficit\n\n(adds details)\n\nBy Mark Gleeson\n\nHAMBURG, Germany, June 19 (Reuters) -\n\nAlbania snatched a stoppage time equaliser for a stunning 2-2 draw against Croatia in a thrilling European Championship contest on Wednesday but the result left both countries with a tall order if they are to progress to the last-16.\n\nKlaus Gjasula proved both hero and villain, bagging the added time leveller after having earlier netted an own goal that saw Croatia go 2-1 up in the Group B clash at the Volksparkstadion.\n\nThe two countries now have a single point after their opening two matches and are left effectively needing to win their last group games on Monday if they are to progress into the knockout stage.\n\nNo team has made next round with just two draws since the Euro finals expanded to 24 teams in 2016.\n\nAlbania had taken an early lead but the Croats scored twice in the space of two minutes to revive their hopes in a match full of twists and turns and played to a backdrop of ear-splitting noise.\n\nAndrej Kramaric grabbed a 74th minute equaliser and then followed an own goal from Gjasula 120 seconds later as a dominant Croatia, who lost 3-0 to Spain in their opening game, fought their way back.\n\nThey had pounded away at the Albania goal in the second half after looking anxious and frustrated at halftime as their unfancied opponents went into the break ahead.\n\nQazim Laci\u00b4s 11th minute header had Albania in an early lead, as had been the case against Italy in their opening game when they scored after just 23 seconds.\n\nThis time they were a touch tardy, weathering early pressure before Jasir Asani whipped in a cross from the right that Laci got a glancing head to before it slipped under goalkeeper Dominik Livakovic.\n\nThe Croat keeper could have done better but made up for the slip with two key saves later in the first half, denying Kristjan Asllani and then stopping Rey Manaj\u00b4s diving header as Albania came close to doubling their lead.\n\nAlbania\u00b4s gritty determination - and the speed with which they seized counterattacking opportunities - belied their lowly ranking, some 56 places below 10th placed Croatia.\n\nA double change at the break for Croatia was followed by intense pressure on the Albania goal with Thomas Strakosha saving from Luka Sucic and Mateo Kovacic to keep the lead intact right until the 74th minute when Kramaric, on his 33rd birthday, netted from close range.\n\nHe shot through the legs of Elseid Hysaj while wrongfooting Strakosha.\n\nThen came a calamitous own goal as Ante Budimir\u00b4s shot, set up by Mario Pasalic pull back from the byline, was blocked by Berat Djimsiti only for the rebound to hit Gjasula and go into his own net.\n\nBut Albania were not to be outdone and Gjasula sidefooted into the net with five minutes of additional time already played for a dramatic conclusion to the contest.\n\nAlbania finish their group schedule against Spain in Duesseldorf on Monday while Croatia meet Italy in Leipzig at the same time. against holders Italy on June 24 to reach the knockout phase for a fifth straight major tournament.\n\nAlbania have won plenty of plaudits with their performances against both Italy, in a 2-1 defeat, and Croatia, but could not hold a lead in either game and will probably have to beat Spain to keep their last-16 hopes alive.\n\nCroatia's 'golden generation' were ultimately made to pay for a poor made it 2-1 for Croatia just two minutes later.\n\nGjasula redeemed himself by scoring Albania's equalizer in injury time.\n\nThe result leaves both Croatia and Albania in a precarious situation in Group B after they lost to Spain and Italy, respectively, in their first matches.\n\nThe Albanians, who are ahead of Croatia on goal difference in the group standings, celebrated the most after the match, while Luka Modric and his teammates looked disappointed as they applauded the Croatian fans.\n\nThe Volksparkstadion in Hamburg was split evenly between red-clad Albania fans and spectators in Croatia's checkered shirt providing a loud and energetic atmosphere throughout the match.\n\nFans in Croatia's section set off flares repeatedly, despite warnings over the loudspeakers that it would result in disciplinary action.\n\nCroatia struggled to create chances in the first half and could have faced a greater deficit but goalkeeper Dominik Livakovic blocked a shot from Kristjan Asllani and a header from Rey Manaj to keep it 1-0 at halftime.\n\nThe Croatians came out with more energy in the second half and turned the match around in two minutes. {"uri": "8185663354", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "16:41:17", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T16:41:17Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T16:39:05Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7490196228027344, "url": "https://sports.yahoo.com/albania-klaus-gjasula-levels-stoppage-155550688.html", "title": "Albania equalise five minutes into stoppage time in Euro 2024 thriller against Croatia", "body": "Albania equalised five minutes into added time to claim a 2-2 draw against Croatia in a thrilling contest which left both sides with much to do to progress to the last 16.\n\nKlaus Gjasula went from villain to hero for Albania, netting the leveller after having earlier scored an own goal to put Croatia 2-1 up in the Group B clash.\n\nBoth countries now have a single point after their opening two matches and are left effectively needing to win their last group games on Monday.\n\nNo team has made the next round with two draws since the Euros expanded to 24 teams in 2016 - offering a place in the last 16 to the four best third-placed finishers.\n\nAlbania had taken an early lead but the Croats scored twice in the space of two minutes to revive their hopes in a match full of twists and turns and played to a backdrop of ear-splitting noise.\n\nAndrej Kramaric grabbed a 74th-minute equaliser and then followed an own goal from Gjasula 120 seconds later as an increasingly dominant Croatia, who lost 3-0 to Spain in their opening game, clawed their way back.\n\nQazim Laci's 11th minute header gave Albania an early lead, as had been the case against Italy in their opening game when they scored after just 23 seconds.\n\nAlbania's gritty determination - and the speed with which they seized counterattacking opportunities - belied their lowly ranking, some 56 places below 10th placed Croatia.\n\n\"This is why everyone loves football. In the last seconds, sometimes you score a goal to win, sometimes you concede,\" said Kramaric.\n\nAlbania finish their group schedule against Spain in Duesseldorf on Monday and Gjasula said they held out hope.\n\n\"We know that the game with Spain is very difficult but in football everything is possible. If we will play like today everything can happen,\" he said.\n\nCroatia will meet Italy in Leipzig at the same time with the odds against them.\n\n\"The first half was very bad but the second much better, which is encouraging for the match with Italy,\" added Croatia coach Zlatko Dalic. \"We are still in the game, we shall prepare and do all in our power to go on.\"\n\nThey've done so much for their country, the likes of Ivan Perisic, Marcelo Brozovic and Luka Modric, but sitting at the foot of Group B with a point to their name, it is looking increasingly likely they will be signing off their international careers in disappointment. They face Italy on Monday.\n\nWhat a thrilling game in Hamburg. Croatia will be kicking themselves especially after doing so well to turn things around in the second half. Albania looked tired late on but they held on and got their equaliser. The story of the day was Gjasula who came on as a substitute in a stadium he used to play in regularly with Hamburg, scored a devastating O.G. then went up the other end and salvaged a point for his country in dramatic fashion. Brilliant.\n\nAm I watching the NBA play-offs or the Euros? It's like a game of basketball now, end to end stuff. Albania have one last stab then Croatia do the same, Kovacic's shot saved and the final whistle goes. I really didn't want that game to end. This is what the Euros is all about.\n\nGjasula with a late late equaliser and redemption! It looked for a while there like Albania were dead and buried but they've pulled it out of the hat. What a game! Gvardiol is on the turf, head in hands, as are the thousands of Croatian fans in the stadium.\n\nDaku has two goes in a chaotic box scramble. He finally blasts it over.\n\nAlbania with a big chance to equalise. Hoxha's effort is parried into the path of sub Mirlind Daku but his follow-up from close range is blasted over. Flag goes up for a offside though.\n\nModric goes for one from range but it goes just wide. Would have been the cherry on top. Baturina takes on his man on the left edge of the box, he hits a shot while falling but the keeper saves.\n\nCroatia subs: Kramaric and Perisic make way for Sosa and Baturina.\n\nAll Croatia now. Albania wilting rapidly. Perisic's crossing today has been nothing short of sublime. He floats in another beauty that nearly gets to Budamir. Speaking of Budamir, he's been fantastic since coming on, making all the difference. They needed a big second half Croatia, and they have delivered.\n\nThey've turned it around! And what a calamitous goal it is. Gjasula own goal. Budamir beats his man on the end line and plays it to Pasalic with an open goal. The shot is blocked but the clearance deflects off the substitute and flies into his own net. Have to feel for the Albanians.\n\nKramaric finally finds the net! Albania's resistance broken. Kovacic flicks it to Budamir who plays in Kramaric. The former Leicester man slots home and they're level.\n\nGoalscorer Laci makes way for 34-year-old Gjasula. Juranovic loses it near his own area, its stolen by Bajrami but his effort is weak.\n\nPerisic with another cross from wide left, met by Petkovic but no luck. Budimir on for Petkovic for Croatia.\n\nBajrami takes on Gvardiol, waits for him to commit but the Manchester City defender doesn't so he tries his luck. The ball goes high, right and wide. At least the Albanians are starting to find their way back into the game now.\n\nLaci is fuming. The Albanians steal possession in the Croatian half, Laci is free in space with the potential of a one-on-one but they play the ball backwards. Dumbfounded.\n\nCroatia continue to pile on the pressure here. Albania struggling to get out of their own half, being forced backward on every attempt to break. When they do finally get out Aslani has a go from the edge of the area but it is underhit and Livakovic gathers happily.\n\nSeferi comes on for Asani for the Albanians.\n\nModric hits a piledriver right into the midriff of Amadani. The referee stops play. Andros Townsend makes his discontentment known on ITV commentary.\n\n\"I wouldn't be stopping the game for that\"\n\n\"Does a football to the stomach count as a serious injury?\"\n\nAlbania yet to threaten in this half so far but they've already shown they don't need many chances to score. Croatia very much in control at the moment though. Another cross, another header, no goal but a corner for Croatia. Modric whips it in and somehow Sutelo missed from centimeters with a free header. Modric can't believe his eyes.\n\nKovacic tries one from just outside the area. It is deflected but it doesn't phase Strakosha who stays central and catches with ease. Perisic with yet another cross into the box but no one there to head it home.\n\nThe ball finds its way to Sucic in the box, great opportunity but it is hit straight at the keeper. Perisic flies one into the danger area. It's met by Pasalic who heads wide. Croatia getting a foothold now.\n\nPerisic with another long throw into the area. Petkovic rises to meet again but it goes wide for a goal kick.\n\nSucic involved already. He crosses to Petkovic who can't connect properly with his head to guide it goalwards.\n\nSucic and Pasalic come on for Majer and Brozovic. Fresh legs clearly needed by Croatia especially in the midfield. 45 minutes left for Croatia to save their tournament - and reputation.\n\nAlbania will be more than happy with that first-half display. They've got their goal, created plenty of chances, looked dangerous whenever they've entered the Croatian half and managed to keep their oppositions attacking force at bay. More of the same in the second half one would assume.\n\nManaj has a great chance in front of goal. Cross whipped in by Hysaj onto the forehead of Manaj who heads it into the ground. Livakovic saves well again. Seconds later Croatia attack. Perisic's cross is met by Petkovic and saved wonderfully by Strakosha. The referee blows up anyway for offside. Half-time.\n\nKramaric sends in another one, this time to Majer. It looks like the Albanian defender gets a touch on it but the linesman gives a goal kick.\n\nKovacic loses possession leading to a quick Albania counter. It is quelled but they hold possession. The Albanian crowd are drowning out the Croatian chants. Kramaric beats his man a couple of times on the edge of the box before crossing it into nobody in the box.\n\nModric sends the free in but Strakosha punches away. Long ball is played over the top to Asani from a quick free but he fails to control it. Brozovic has a go down the other end but it trickles into the keepers gloves.\n\nCroatia have yet to test Albanian keeper Strakosha. They play around with the ball in the middle of the park. They certainly have players who can hurt an opposition, when will they get their first big chance of the game? They have a free on the edge of the area now. Could this be it?\n\nWhat a chance for Albania! Ball played through to Asllani who is one-on-one with Livakovic but the keeper stays tall and saves the midfielder's effort. Could so easily have been two.\n\nFree for Albania. It's a bit long but Bajrami manages to find Laci whose cross is cleared. Asani finds Manaj in the box who heads it down to Hysaj. The defender hits it first time on the half-volley but it flies over. Albania still looking the more dangerous in attack.\n\nMajer floats in another lethal cross off his left, right onto the head of Petkovic but the striker can't guide it goalwards and it goes over the crossbar.\n\nModric pulling the strings in midfield as expected. Croatia put some nice link-up play together. They're starting to look a bit more productive in possession (they currently have 63 percent of it). Twice they get close to the box but the Albanians break down their attack.\n\nEnd to end again. Bajrami in a foot race with Sutelo but the Croatian clears. Kramaric finds himself in a similar situation down the other end but the defenders do their job. Juranovic has a go from the edge of the area but it drags just wide.\n\nPerisic launches a long throw into the box, dangerous but cleared. Perisic whips in another cross seconds later but the Albanians deal.\n\nAlbania appeal for a penalty but the referee is having none of it. Down the other end Modric steals the ball from a napping Mitaj but Arlind Ajeti kicks it out, stopping a potential Croatia attack.\n\nCroatia looking so open and vulnerable at the moment. Bajrami cuts in from the left and unleashes one but the keeper palms it into the side netting. Hysaj attempts the spectacular from the outside of the box but it is blocked.\n\nIt's been a pretty fast start to the game from both sides. Hysaj curls in a cross that Sutelo fails to properly clear. The ball is played back out to the midfield. It's whipped in once more from the right hand side and met by Laci in the box who heads it past Livakovic. Another early goal for the Albanians!\n\nCroatia with their first period of pressure. Maher cross cleared from corner. Ivanovic tries to find Petkovic with another cross from wide but cleared once more. Hysaj loses the ball to Kovacic on the edge of the area but they quickly win it back.\n\nAlbania again looking sharp in the Croatian half. They win a free 35 yards out, the ball is clipped in to Asani by Manaj but Sutalo heads it back to the keeper.\n\nAlbania stringing some nice passes together in the opening phase of play, looking confident. Ball played over the top to Bajrami who crosses low but it is cleared by Gvardiol.\n\nAnd we're off...\n\nBoth teams belt out their national anthems with pride as the sun beats down in Hamburg. Kick-off in three minutes.\n\nAlbania coach Sylvinho spoke during the week, touching on his approach to games against bigger teams.\n\n\"I have seen other sides in this tournament. If you try and go toe-to-toe with them, they will score five or six against you,\" said the former Arsenal and Barcelona defender.\n\n\"It's only our second time here in the Euros. We have young players, very good players, but it's not easy.\"\n\nThe Albanian team has been announced prior to kick-off and there's is neither sight nor sound of Chelsea striker Armando Broja in the starting 11, perhaps their most recognisable player.\n\nCroatia's Euro hopes have been dealt a blow with midfielder Nikola Vlasic ruled out of the tournament through injury.\n\nThe 26-year-old Torino midfielder, formerly of West Ham and Everton, picked up a muscle injury in training. Vlasic has been capped 56 times for his country.\n\nFollowing a scan, Vlasic said he will now be heading home.\n\n\"I'm extremely sorry that this new injury will prevent me from helping the team,\" Vlasic said.\n\n\"I've done everything possible to be ready, and I'd like to thank the head coach and the coaching staff for the opportunity. I believe in this team and I'm sure they will succeed - I'll be their biggest fan!\".\n\nCroatia have lost three of their past five competitive matches, going down against Turkey, Wales and Spain in this run. It is is as many defeats as they had suffered across their previous 29 games in competitive action combined. They'll need to turn that form around if they are to escape the Euro 2024 group stages.\n\nGood afternoon everybody and welcome to the Telegraph's live blog of the Group B clash between Croatia and Albania at the Volksparkstadion in Hamburg. We will be taking you through every moment, every bulge of the net, every woodwork hit and every crunching tackle made as Croatia aim to bounce back from their disappointing 3-0 defeat to Spain in the tournament's opening round of matches.\n\nAs for the Albanians, they nearly caused a mighty upset in their opening encounter with Italy, scoring after just 23 seconds, but the current European champions turned it around in true Azzurri fashion, eventually winning 2-1 thanks to goals from Alessandro Bastoni and Nicolo Barella.\n\nDespite their underwhelming display against Spain, the Croatian squad are well used to playing on the biggest stage and will no doubt be favourites for this. Zlatko Dalic's side reached the 2018 World Cup final and the penultimate stages in Qatar in 2022.\n\nThey have recovered from slow starts before, progressing from the group stage at Euro 2020 despite losing to England in their opening game, and as previously mentioned at the last World Cup they reached the semi-finals after an opening loss to Morocco.\n\n\"There is no room for pessimism, everything is still in our hands,\" Dalic said. \"Of course, we have to be better. It's my job to turn the team around\" he continued.\n\nTheir goal difference surely isn't doing them any favours in the group but a big win in Hamburg today can make up for it, especially with Italy taking on Spain tomorrow night.\n\nEuro 2024 has brought us plenty of goals thus far, let's hope that continues today.
