{"uri": "8184158769", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-18", "time": "19:13:22", "dateTime": "2024-06-18T19:13:22Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-18T19:11:50Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7490196228027344, "url": "https://www.reformer.com/ap/sports/balkan-clash-croatia-and-albania-meet-for-the-first-time-at-euro-2024/article_ccd9b1fe-7e8c-580d-8afb-0ee64c10739a.html", "title": "Balkan clash: Croatia and Albania meet for the first time at Euro 2024", "body": "HAMBURG, Germany (AP) -- Croatia faces Albania in their second match in Group B. Both teams lost their opening matches and can't afford another defeat if they want to keep hope alive of advancing from the group stage. The match starts at 3 p.m. local time (1300 GMT) in Hamburg. Here's what to know:\n\nMatch facts\n\n-- The two Balkan teams have never met in a competitive match before. Albania is playing in only its second European Championship after qualifying for the tournament in 2016.\n\n-- Luka Modric's Croatia is looking to rebound from a confidence-bruising 3-0 loss to Spain in the group opener. Croatia is expected to control the game while Albania relies on its robust defense and quick counterattacks.\n\n-- Albania stunned defending champion Italy with an early goal but conceded two goals later in the game in the 2-1 loss on June 15.\n\n-- Albania faces disciplinary charges for the behavior of its fans in the first game. UEFA says that included a \"provocative message\" allegedly displayed by fans, the throwing of objects, use of fireworks and a field invasion by a fan near the end of the game.\n\nTeam news\n\n-- Croatia midfielder Nikola Vlasic has withdrawn from the tournament because of a muscle injury. He didn't play against Spain and didn't take part in practice this week.\n\n-- Albania coach Sylvinho on Tuesday said his squad was injury-free, with all players available for the match against Croatia.\n\n-- Both teams are treating the match as crucial for their ability to advance from the group stage.\n\nBy the numbers\n\n-- Croatia had 54% possession in its first match against Spain, becoming the first team to hold the ball more than Spain in a competitive match since 2008. Croatia completed 528 passes to Spain's 392.\n\n-- Albania's Nedim Bajrami scored against Italy after just 23 seconds, the fastest goal in the history of the European Championship.\n\n-- Croatia forward Andrej Kramaric will celebrate his 33rd birthday on the day of the match.\n\nWhat they're saying\n\n-- \"For me, personally, it's a dream come true to play in front of that many Croatian fans at a major tournament. It was beautiful. I can only promise that we'll give our best in the next games, and fight for our country.\" - Croatia midfielder Lovro Majer about the support of Croatia fans in Germany.\n\n-- \"We are not going to underestimate our opponents. We are in a 'group of death' and we know it is going to be hard to go through. Croatia are a tough team but we are preparing to give it our best.\" - Albania defender Mario Mitaj.\n\nAP Euro 2024: https://apnews.com/hub/euro-2024", "source": {"uri": "reformer.com", "dataType": Euro24 trouble", "body": "Croatia and Albania have drawn 2-2 in an intense battle at Euro 2024, a result that could make it difficult for both teams to survive the group stages.\n\nIn the first ever competitive match between the two Balkan teams on Wednesday, Croatia tried to set the pace from the start, but it was Albania's Qazim Laci who scored first, heading in a cross from the right flank in the 11th minute.\n\nAndrej Kramaric equalised about half an hour into the second half and an own goal by Klaus Gjasula made it 2-1 for Croatia just two minutes later.\n\nGjasula then redeemed himself by scoring Albania's equaliser in injury time.\n\nThe result leaves both sides in a precarious situation in group B after Croatia lost to Spain and Albania to Italy in their first matches.\n\nThe Albanians, who are ahead of Croatia on goal difference in the group standings, celebrated most after the match, while Luka Modric and his teammates looked disappointed as they applauded the Croatian fans.\n\nThe Volksparkstadion in Hamburg was split evenly between red-clad Albania fans and spectators in Croatia's checkered shirt providing a loud and energetic atmosphere throughout the match.\n\nFans in Croatia's section set off flares repeatedly, despite warnings over the loudspeakers that it would result in disciplinary action.\n\nCroatia struggled to create chances in the first half and could have faced a greater deficit but goalkeeper Dominik Livakovic blocked a shot from Kristjan Asllani and a header from Rey Manaj to keep it 1-0 at halftime.\n\nThe Croatians came out with more energy in the second half and turned the match around in two minutes.\n\nKramaric equalised with a shot just inside the post and, just moments later, Gjasula was unlucky when Albania tried to {"uri": "8183368482", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-18", "time": "10:11:26", "dateTime": "2024-06-18T10:11:26Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-18T10:09:38Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7372549176216125, "url": "https://www.eagletribune.com/balkan-clash-croatia-and-albania-meet-for-the-first-time-at-euro-2024/article_1e4b91cd-679f-5728-9d63-e547fc5b3071.html", "title": "Balkan clash: Croatia and Albania meet for the first time at Euro 2024", "body": "Spain's head coach Luis de la Fuente gives instructions during a Group B match between Spain and Croatia at the Euro 2024 soccer tournament in Berlin, Germany, Saturday, June 15, 2024. Spain defeated Croatia 3-0.\n\nHAMBURG, Germany (AP) -- Croatia faces Albania in their second match in Group B. Both teams lost their opening matches and can't afford another defeat if they want to keep hope alive of advancing from the group stage. The match starts at 3 p.m. local time (9 a.m. EST) in Hamburg. Here's what to know:\n\nMatch facts\n\n-- The two Balkan teams have never met in a competitive match before. Albania is playing in only its second European Championship after qualifying for the tournament in 2016.\n\n-- Luka Modric's Croatia is looking to rebound from a confidence-bruising 3-0 loss to Spain in the group opener. Croatia is expected to control the game while Albania relies on its robust defense and quick counterattacks.\n\n-- Albania stunned defending champion Italy with an early goal but conceded two goals later in the game in the 2-1 loss on June 15.\n\n-- Albania faces disciplinary charges for the behavior of its fans in the first game. UEFA says that included a \"provocative message\" allegedly displayed by fans, the throwing of objects, use of fireworks and a field invasion by a fan near the end of the game.\n\nTeam news\n\n-- Croatia midfielder Nikola Vlasic didn't take part in the team's training session on Monday but is expected to be fit for Wednesday's match. Vlasic came on as a second-half substitute against Spain.\n\n-- Albania striker Jasir Asani has an ankle injury and could be in doubt for the match. However, the Albanian Football Federation said all players took part in training on Monday.\n\n-- Both teams are treating the match as crucial for their ability to advance from the group stage.\n\nBy the numbers\n\n-- Croatia had 54% possession in its first match against Spain, becoming the first team to hold the ball more than Spain in a competitive match since 2008. Croatia completed 528 passes to Spain's 392.\n\n-- Albania's Nedim Bajrami scored against Italy after just 23 seconds, the fastest goal in the history of the European Championship.\n\n-- Croatia forward Andrej Kramaric will celebrate his 33rd birthday on the day of the match\n\nWhat they're saying\n\n-- \"For me, personally, it's a dream come true to play in front of that many Croatian fans at a major tournament. It was beautiful. I can only promise that we'll give our best in the next games, and fight for our country.\" - Croatia midfielder Lovro Majer about the support of Croatia fans in Germany.\n\n-- \"We are not going to underestimate our opponents. We are in a 'group of death' and we know it is going to be hard to go through. Croatia are a tough team but we are preparing to give it our best.\" - Albania defender Mario Mitaj.\n\nAP Euro 2024: https://apnews.com/hub/euro-2024", "source": {"uri": "eagletribune.com", Both teams were looking to bounce back after opening game defeats in Group B -- Croatia to a strong Spain side and Albania thrilling early against Italy but struggling to maintain momentum.\n\nA defeat here would almost certainly end either team's hopes of progressing to the round of 16. The match started cautiously, but Qazim Laci broke the deadlock on 11 minutes, heading Albania into the lead.\n\nDespite dominating possession, Croatia struggled to create clear chances against a resilient Albanian defense, spurred on by passionate fans. Albania pushed for a second goal and came close with La\u00e7i's effort just over the bar.\n\nRey Manaj missed a great chance to double Albania's lead just before halftime. Croatia made attacking substitutions at the start of the second half, and Luka Susic's effort was well saved.\n\nCroatia pressed hard for an equaliser in the last half-hour, with Luka Modri\u0107 leading the charge, but Albania held firm. Andrej Kramari\u0107 finally broke through, scoring with a low effort from 12 yards out.\n\nWithin 30 seconds, Croatia took the lead through an own goal by Klaus Gjasula. Klaus Gjasula scored in the 90+5th minute to secure a 2-2 draw against a lacklustre Croatian side. Croatia had 22 shots with 10 on target, while Albania had 15 shots with 7 shots on target. Croatia dominated the possession, keeping 68 per cent of the ball compared to Albania's 32 per cent possession.\n\nAlbania took the lead in the 11th minute after Jasir Asani crossed the ball to Qazim Laci, who expertly headed it home to send the travelling fans into delirium. The midfielder from Sparta Prague took the opportunity, running behind Croatia's defence line and beautifully headed the ball into the goal.\n\nIn the first half, Croatia held up possession of the game but were not clinical in the final third. In the second half though, Croatia picked up the pace and started driving the ball towards the goal, playing direct football instead of side passing. Albania were struggling to defend against the persistent Croatian attacks and inevitably conceded when Kramaric finished off a Croatian build-up, slotting past Thomas Strakosha and scoring Croatia's first goal in the Euro 2024 campaign in the 74th minute.\n\nKramaric's goal fuelled the Croatian players, who were struggling to impose themselves in the first half. After the 74th-minute equaliser, Croatia began playing aggressive direct football and forced an error out of Albanian midfielder Gjasula, who unintentionally put the ball into his own net. Croatia came back from a goal down in the first half to score 2 goals in 2 minutes in the second half.\n\nCroatia dominated the possession in the second half and were continuously threatening Albania's goal. The Albanian defence held off the dangerous Croatian attacks in the second half. It seemed like all hope was lost as the match entered the injury time of an additional 5 minutes.\n\nBut the spirited Albanian side never lost hope and pressed hard for the equaliser in the dying stages. They were eventually rewarded in the last minute of the match, securing an unbelievable late comeback to draw against Croatia. Klaus Gjasula, the man who scored an own goal to give Croatia the lead in the 76th minute, redeemed himself with an emphatic finish to end the match in a stalemate.\n\nWhat's Next For Croatia and Albania?\n\nThe 2-2 draw result might have just crushed Croatia's hopes of qualifying for the UEFA Euro 2024 Round Of 16 stage. With a draw and a loss each and a -3 goal difference, Croatia are placed fourth with 1 point in their group. They now face the daunting task of overcoming the Italian challenge in the final game of Group B on 25th Jun, Tuesday at 12:30 AM IST.\n\nAlbania, on the other hand, might have a chance to come second if they beat Spain in their last match of Group B. The European minnows sit in third position with 1 point in their group as they also have 1 draw and 1 loss but only a -1 goal difference. {"uri": "8185638577", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "16:19:29", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T16:19:29Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T16:18:28Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7333333492279053, "url": "https://www.channelnewsasia.com/sport/albania-score-stoppage-time-equaliser-hold-careless-croatia-4422111", "title": "Albania score stoppage time equaliser to hold careless Croatia", "body": "HAMBURG, Germany :Albania snatched an equaliser in added time for a stunning 2-2 draw against Croatia in a thrilling European Championship contest on Wednesday, but the result left both countries with a tall order if they are to progress to the last-16.\n\nKlaus Gjasula proved both hero and villain, bagging the added time leveller after having earlier netted an own goal that saw Croatia go 2-1 up in the Group B clash at the Volksparkstadion.\n\nBoth countries now have a single point after their opening two matches and are left effectively needing to win their last group games on Monday if they are to progress into the knockout stage.\n\nNo team has made the next round with just two draws since the Euro finals expanded to 24 teams in 2016 - offering a place in the last-16 to the four best third-placed finishers.\n\nAlbania had taken an early lead but the Croats scored twice in the space of two minutes to revive their hopes in a match full of twists and turns and played to a backdrop of ear-splitting noise.\n\nAndrej Kramaric grabbed a 74th minute equaliser and then followed an own goal from Gjasula 120 seconds later as an increasingly dominant Croatia, who lost 3-0 to Spain in their opening game, clawed their way back.\n\nThey had pounded away at the Albania goal in the second half after looking anxious and frustrated at halftime as their unfancied opponents went into the break ahead.\n\nQazim Laci's 11th minute header put Albania in an early lead, as had been the case against Italy in their opening game when they scored after just 23 seconds.\n\nThis time they were a touch tardy, weathering early pressure before Jasir Asani whipped in a cross from the right that Laci got a glancing head to before it slipped under goalkeeper Dominik Livakovic.\n\nThe Croat keeper could have done better but made up for the slip with two key saves later in the first half, denying Kristjan Asllani and then stopping Rey Manaj's diving header as Albania came close to doubling their lead.\n\nAlbania's gritty determination - and the speed with which they seized counterattacking opportunities - belied their lowly ranking, some 56 places below 10th placed Croatia.\n\nA double change at the break for Croatia was followed by intense pressure on the Albania goal with Thomas Strakosha saving from Luka Sucic and Mateo Kovacic to keep the lead intact right until the 74th minute when Kramaric, on his 33rd birthday, netted from close range.\n\nHe shot through the legs of Elseid Hysaj while wrongfooting Strakosha.\n\nThen came the own goal as Ante Budimir's shot, set up by Mario Pasalic's pull back from the byline, was blocked by Berat Djimsiti only for the rebound to hit Gjasula and go into his own net.\n\nBut Albania were not to be outdone and Gjasula sidefooted into the net with five minutes of additional time already played for a dramatic conclusion to the contest.\n\n\"This is why everyone loves football. In the last seconds, sometimes you score a goal to win, sometimes you concede,\" said Kramaric.\n\nAlbania finish their group schedule against Spain in Duesseldorf on Monday and Gjasula said they held out hope.\n\n\"We know that the game with Spain is very difficult but in football everything is possible. If we will play like today everything can happen,\" he told reporters.\n\nCroatia will meet Italy in Leipzig at the same time with the odds against them.\n\n\"The first half was very bad but the second much better, which is encouraging for the match with Italy,\" added Croatia coach Zlatko Dalic. \"We are still in the game, we shall prepare and do all in our power to go on.\"\n\n(Additional Both teams lost their opening matches and can't afford another defeat if they want to keep hope alive of advancing from the group stage. The match starts at 3 p.m. local time (9 a.m. EST) in Hamburg. Here's what to know:\n\nMatch facts\n\n-- The two Balkan teams have never met in a competitive match before. Albania is playing in only its second European Championship after qualifying for the tournament in 2016.\n\n-- Luka Modric's Croatia is looking to rebound from a confidence-bruising 3-0 loss to Spain in the group opener. Croatia is expected to control the game while Albania relies on its robust defense and quick counterattacks.\n\n-- Albania stunned defending champion Italy with an early goal but conceded two goals later in the game in the 2-1 loss on June 15.\n\n-- Albania faces disciplinary charges for the behavior of its fans in the first game. UEFA says that included a \"provocative message\" allegedly displayed by fans, the throwing of objects, use of fireworks and a field invasion by a fan near the end of the game.\n\nTeam news\n\n-- Croatia midfielder Nikola Vlasic didn't take part in the team's training session on Monday but is expected to be fit for Wednesday's match. Vlasic came on as a second-half substitute against Spain.\n\n-- Albania striker Jasir Asani has an ankle injury and could be in doubt for the match. However, the Albanian Football Federation said all players took part in training on Monday.\n\n-- Both teams are treating the match as crucial for their ability to advance from the group stage.\n\nBy the numbers\n\n-- Croatia had 54% possession in its first match against Spain, becoming the first team to hold the ball more than Spain in a competitive match since 2008. Croatia completed 528 passes to Spain's 392.\n\n-- Albania's Nedim Bajrami scored against Italy after just 23 seconds, the fastest goal in the history of the European Championship.\n\n-- Croatia forward Andrej Kramaric will celebrate his 33rd birthday on the day of the match\n\nWhat they're saying\n\n-- \"For me, personally, it's a dream come true to play in front of that many Croatian fans at a major tournament. It was beautiful. I can only promise that we'll give our best in the next games, and fight for our country.\" - Croatia midfielder Lovro Majer about the support of Croatia fans in Germany.\n\n-- \"We are not going to underestimate our opponents. We are in a 'group of death' and we know it is going to be hard to go through. Croatia are a tough team but we are preparing to give it our best.\" - Albania defender Mario Mitaj.\n\nAP Euro 2024: https://apnews.com/hub/euro-2024", "source": {"uri": "register-herald.com", Will they punch above their weight once more?\n\nFind out why I see this one being a wide-open affair in my Croatia vs. Albania predictions and Euro 2024 picks for Wednesday, June 19.\n\nCroatia vs Albania picks, predictions, and betting tips\n\nDespite Nedim Bajrami recording the fastest-ever goal at the Euros after just 23 seconds, Albania fell behind Italy in just 15 minutes. What followed the Italian goal was an even fight, with Albania looking always dangerous and ready to trouble the opposition. Sylvinho's side kept harassing its opponent, but no goal was scored until the end of the match.\n\nAlbania doesn't try to do anything revolutionary. They keep it simple and direct, showing their feisty approach can cause headaches even to the most glamorous opponents. Albania didn't top their qualifying group for nothing, as they left the likes of the Czech Republic and Poland behind them. Sylvinho will look to see his side grow in this tournament. If Albania are to stand any chance of progress, they must maximize the outcome of the match against Croatia.\n\nLuka Modric and his teammates are also desperate to win. {"uri": "8185564028", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "15:26:15", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T15:26:15Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T15:24:42Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7137255072593689, "url": "https://ca.sports.yahoo.com/news/klaus-gjasula-strikes-own-goal-152000094.html", "title": "Klaus Gjasula strikes late after own goal to snatch Albania draw with Croatia", "body": "Just when it seemed they had done it again,when it seemed they had somehow ridden out the storm to find an implausible win, Klaus Gjasula, the substitute whose own goal seemed to have given Croatia victory, found an equaliser. A remarkable game ended in a draw greeted with euphoria by Albania, but which at half-time would have seemed a dreadful disappointment.\n\nRelated: Croatia 2-2 Albania: Euro 2024 - live\n\nCroatia had lost to Spain. They had been largely outplayed by a younger and sharper Albania side in the first half. But they have a capacity to hang in games and tournaments until their talent eventually blossoms. At half-time here there seemed a very real possibility they could go out in the group stage. Albania deserved their lead. But something always happens: Argentina try to play a high press with Nicol\u00e1s Otamendi, Scotland panic at the thought of at last getting out of a group, Romelu Lukaku suffers one of the all-time days of profligacy, Gjasula scores a ludicrous own goal. For once, though, that was not the end of the story.\n\nAlbania deserve great credit not only for their first-half performance but for holding their nerve. The build-up to Gjasula's equaliser was clam and incisive. They had already had a couple of late opportunities but there was no panic. They trusted their talent and got their rewards. Once again they had impressed. Once again they had taken the lead. But as against Italy, they then conceded twice. This time, though, they converted their late opportunity. Even if they lose to Spain, they will leave this tournament having made more of an impression than they did in France eight years ago in their one previous Euros, even though they won a game then.\n\nThe Croatia coach, Zlatko Dalic, had complained that his side deserve more respect having achieved three podium finishes in the past six years (he includes the Nations League). He may have a point, but Croatia might seem more convincing challengers for this tournament if they weren not still, Josko Gvardiol aside, so dependent on the side that lost in the 2018 World Cup final.\n\nUsually when three men with the combined age of Croatia's midfield get together, it's for a game of bowls, some reminiscing about a wild night a couple of decades ago (\"Luka, tell us that one about Scott Carson again\"), or a couple of gentle pints and a proper grumble about the scourge of progress. The midfield is becoming a problem for them. Sublimely gifted as their trio were, they lack the bite or energy of a modern group. It couldn't endure and Marcelo Brozovic was one of two players replaced at half-time as Croatia switched to a 4-2-3-1.\n\nWhat Spain had done, so did Albania before half-time. Their three attacking midfielders all found space repeatedly and were able to isolate Croatian defenders and drive at them. That was what brought the opening goal, after 11 minutes. With Ivan Perisic, slightly surprisingly deployed at left-back, slow to get out, Jasir Asani was granted a remarkable amount of space to bend in a cross from the right, picking out Qazim Laci. His header bounced awkwardly for Dominik Livakovic but the keeper should still surely have kept it out. Given Laci's only previous competitive goal for his country had come in a World Cup qualifier against San Marino, it's safe to say this was by some margin the most important goal he has ever scored.\n\nAlbania could have been further ahead by half-time as well, Kristjan Asllani slightly snatching at a chance as Asani's pass was deflected into his path after Luka Modric had, unthinkably, conceded possession, and then Rey Manaj could not get sufficient purchase on a header to beat Livakovic. You cannot afford not to finish off Croatia if you have the chance.\n\nIn the first half on Wednesday, Croatia were not even generating opportunities. They had more of the ball but struggled to break Albania down. Only after the break with the change of shape did they begin to create. One substitute Luka Sucic forced a plunging save from Thomas Strakosha and another substitute Mario Pasalic headed a decent chance over, before Andrej Kramaric levelled with 16 minutes remaining, his shot squeezing between the legs of Elseid Hysaj. Having resisted for so long, Albania buckled. Although Pasalic's shot was blocked it cannoned back off the luckless Gjasula and in.\n\nBut there was one twist left. Albania found a second wind. Croatia were left clinging on. Croatia faces Albania in their second match in Group B. Both teams lost their opening matches and can't afford another defeat if they want to keep hope alive of advancing from the group stage.\n\nHamburg (Germany), Jun 18 (AP) Croatia faces Albania in their second match in Group B. Both teams lost their opening matches and can't afford another defeat if they want to keep hope alive of advancing from the group stage.\n\nHere's what to know:\n\nAlso Read | Turkey vs Georgia, UEFA Euro 2024 Live Streaming and Match Time in IST: How to Watch Free Live Telecast of TUR vs GEO on TV and Online Stream Details of Football Match in India.\n\nMatch facts\n\n-- The two Balkan teams have never met in a competitive match before. Albania is playing in only its second European Championship after qualifying for the tournament in 2016.\n\nAlso Read | ICC T20 World Cup 2024: Head Coach Jonathan Trott Expresses Disappointment With Afghanistan's Batting After Loss Against West Indies.\n\n-- Luka Modric's Croatia is looking to rebound from a confidence-bruising 3-0 loss to Spain in the group opener. Croatia is expected to control the game while Albania relies on its robust defense and quick counterattacks.\n\n-- Albania stunned defending champion Italy with an early goal but conceded two goals later in the game in the 2-1 loss on June 15.\n\n-- Albania faces disciplinary charges for the behavior of its fans in the first game. UEFA says that included a \"provocative message\" allegedly displayed by fans, the throwing of objects, use of fireworks and a field invasion by a fan near the end of the game.\n\nTeam news\n\n-- Croatia midfielder Nikola Vlasic didn't take part in the team's training session on Monday but is expected to be fit for Wednesday's match. Vlasic came on as a second-half substitute against Spain.\n\n-- Albania striker Jasir Asani has an ankle injury and could be in doubt for the match. However, the Albanian Football Federation said all players took part in training on Monday.\n\n-- Both teams are treating the match as crucial for their ability to advance from the group stage.\n\nBy the numbers\n\n-- Croatia had 54% possession in its first match against Spain, becoming the first team to hold the ball more than Spain in a competitive match since 2008. Croatia completed 528 passes to Spain's 392.\n\n-- Albania's Nedim Bajrami scored against Italy after just 23 seconds, the fastest goal in the history of the European Championship.\n\n-- Croatia forward Andrej Kramaric will celebrate his 33rd birthday on the day of the match\n\nWhat they're saying\n\n-- \"For me, personally, it's a dream come true to play in front of that many Croatian fans at a major tournament. It was beautiful. I can only promise that we'll give our best in the next games, and fight for our country.\" - Croatia midfielder Lovro Majer about the support of Croatia fans in Germany.\n\n-- \"We are not going to underestimate our opponents. We are in a group of death' and we know it is going to be hard to go through. Croatia are a tough team but we are preparing to give it our best.\" - Albania defender Mario Mitaj. {"uri": "8185576485", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "15:34:50", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T15:34:50Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T15:34:05Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7098039388656616, "url": "https://www.channelnewsasia.com/sport/albania-score-stoppage-time-equaliser-hold-croatia-4422111", "title": "Albania score stoppage time equaliser to hold Croatia", "body": "HAMBURG, Germany :Albania snatched a stoppage time equaliser for a stunning 2-2 draw against Croatia in a thrilling European Championship contest on Wednesday but the result left both countries with a tall order if they are to progress to the last-16.\n\nKlaus Gjasula proved both hero and villain, bagging the added time leveller after having earlier netted an own goal that saw Croatia go 2-1 up in the Group B clash at the Volksparkstadion.\n\nThe two countries now have a single point after their opening two matches and are left effectively needing to win their last group games on Monday if they are to progress into the knockout stage.\n\nNo team has made next round with just two draws since the Euro finals expanded to 24 teams in 2016.\n\nAlbania had taken an early lead but the Croats scored twice in the space of two minutes to revive their hopes in a match full of twists and turns and played to a backdrop of ear-splitting noise.\n\nAndrej Kramaric grabbed a 74th minute equaliser and then followed an own goal from Gjasula 120 seconds later as a dominant Croatia, who lost 3-0 to Spain in their opening game, fought their way back.\n\nThey had pounded away at the Albania goal in the second half after looking anxious and frustrated at halftime as their unfancied opponents went into the break ahead.\n\nQazim Laci's 11th minute header had Albania in an early lead, as had been the case against Italy in their opening game when they scored after just 23 seconds.\n\nThis time they were a touch tardy, weathering early pressure before Jasir Asani whipped in a cross from the right that Laci got a glancing head to before it slipped under goalkeeper Dominik Livakovic.\n\nThe Croat keeper could have done better but made up for the slip with two key saves later in the first half, denying Kristjan Asllani and then stopping Rey Manaj's diving header as Albania came close to doubling their lead.\n\nAlbania's gritty determination - and the speed with which they seized counterattacking opportunities - belied their lowly ranking, some 56 places below 10th placed Croatia.\n\nA double change at the break for Croatia was followed by intense pressure on the Albania goal with Thomas Strakosha saving from Luka Sucic and Mateo Kovacic to keep the lead intact right until the 74th minute when Kramaric, on his 33rd birthday, netted from close range.\n\nHe shot through the legs of Elseid Hysaj while wrongfooting Strakosha.\n\nThen came a calamitous own goal as Ante Budimir's shot, set up by Mario Pasalic pull back from the byline, was blocked by Berat Djimsiti only for the rebound to hit Gjasula and go into his own net.\n\nBut Albania were not to be outdone and Gjasula sidefooted into the net with five minutes of additional time already played for a dramatic conclusion to the contest.\n\nAlbania finish their group schedule against Spain in Duesseldorf on Monday while Croatia meet Italy in Leipzig at the same time.\n\n(Additional reporting by {"uri": "8184649235", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "04:42:28", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T04:42:28Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T04:40:35Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7058823704719543, "url": "https://www.tsn.ca/soccer/croatia-albania-meet-looking-for-first-win-at-uefa-euro-2024-on-tsn-1.2136492", "title": "Croatia, Albania meet looking for first win at UEFA Euro 2024 on TSN | TSN", "body": "After suffering losses in their opening games, Croatia and Albania will meet in a Group B clash that will be critical if either team still has hopes of advancing to the knockout stage at UEFA Euro 2024.\n\nCatch Croatia vs. Albania LIVE on Wednesday with coverage getting underway at 8:30 a.m. ET/5:30 a.m. PT on TSN1/4, streaming on the TSN App and on TSN.ca.\n\nNedim Bajrami made history for Albania in their tournament opener when he collected an errant throw-in from Italy left back Federico Dimarco and fired it into the net just 23 seconds into the contest.\n\nThe 25-year-old's marker was the fastest goal scored in the European Championship's 64-year history and staked Albania to a shock 1-0 lead over Italy.\n\nUnfortunately, an upset was not on the cards. Italy equalized 10 minutes later and had a lead they would not relinquish at the 16-minute mark of the opening half.\n\n\"To score for Albania in the European Championship for me was a dream,\" said Bajrami. \"I dreamed this like a kid, and I worked hard for this. I didn't know that I scored the quickest goal in [Euro] history, but I need to keep going. In the coming days we need to prepare for the Croatia game.\"\n\nDespite the fact that Italy controlled the play, finishing with 66 per cent possession, Albania was able to stay in the game and even had a late chance through Rey Manaj that flashed across an open goal but did not find the target.\n\n\"The fans were incredible, inside and outside the stadium,\" said Albania head coach Sylvinho. \"It's a shame we couldn't get an equalizer [against Italy]. If we hadn't conceded the second goal, we'd have been well placed to hit them on the counterattack.\"\n\nUnlike Albania, Croatia had the majority of the possession in their opener, but were not able to make it count as they slumped to a 3-0 defeat against Spain.\n\nAfter withstanding an early barrage from their opponents, Croatia was working their way into the game when they conceded the opening marker in the 29th minute.\n\nThings went from bad to worse when they gave up two more goals before getting to the locker room for halftime.\n\nBruno Petkovic won a penalty for Croatia in the 78th minute, but Spain's keeper Unai Simon made the save and a rebound goal was ruled out for encroachment on the initial shot.\n\n\"We are analyzing Albania, and we will look at what we need to do while being aware that this is a crucial match for us that we have to win, and that our opponents have confidence after a good performance against Italy,\" said Croatia's head coach Zlatko Dalic. \"They took the lead in the first minute and they put up a good fight. Another difficult match and a tough fight is ahead of us, but we are used to that. The Croatian fans will surely not leave us hanging - they will stand with us in Hamburg as well.\"\n\nCroatia has reached the knockout stage of the past two European Championships, falling in the Round of 16 to Portugal in 2016 and Spain in 2020, with both matches needing extra time.\n\nAlbania was eliminated in the Group Stage of UEFA Euro 2016, the only other time they have qualified for the "news", "sim": 0.7058823704719543, "url": "https://www.capitalfm.co.ke/sports/2024/06/19/brave-albanians-hold-fancied-croatia-in-euro-2024-thriller/", "title": "Brave Albanians hold fancied Croatia in Euro 2024 thriller", "body": "HAMBURG, Germany, June 19 - Albania scored a dramatic stoppage-time equaliser to deny Croatia a victory that severely dents the 2018 World Cup finalists' hopes of reaching the knockout stage of Euro 2024.\n\nIn what was a chaotic but entertaining end to the game, the Albanians rescued a point when Klaus Gjasula side-footed home in the 95th minute to send their supporters wild.\n\nIt had looked like the game would finish in heartbreak for Albania, having let slip another early lead.\n\nQazim Laci struck in the 11th minute and his side then defended superbly for over an hour as they looked on the verge of producing a major upset.\n\nBut Croatia turned around an incredible game at Hamburg's Volksparkstadion when former Leicester forward Andrej Kramaric drove in an equaliser, before Luka Sucic's shot deflected off Gjasula and into the Albania net.\n\nBut Gjasula had the final say with his late strike, which means Croatia will now need to beat defending champions Italy in their final Group B game to have a chance of progressing.\n\nAlbania face a tough test in their next game against Spain, but this is a performance and result that will live long in the memory of their fans.\n\nAlbania rewarded for no-fear display\n\nThere have been some hugely entertaining games at this European Championship and this stands among the best of them.\n\nThat is in a large part down to Albania and the determination their side has put in so far in Germany to show they are not here to make up the numbers.\n\nThis is their second appearance at a Euros after qualifying in 2016, and their fans have certainly made the most of their return.\n\nIn Hamburg before kick-off supporters packed out walkways on the harbourfront, and when in the stadium they produced incredible noise throughout the game.\n\nThat energy was clearly transferred to the players, whose fast-paced counter-attacking football had Croatia rattled, and their 1-0 lead at half-time was fully deserved.\n\nWhen Croatia scored twice to turn things around, it will have sparked a sense of deja vu among the Albania fans, having seen Italy fight back to beat them in their first game.\n\nBut this time they did not wilt and instead pushed hard for the equaliser in the closing stages, before Gjasula got the reward his side's battling display deserved.\n\nEnd of an era approaching for Croatia?\n\nHaving finished runners-up at the World Cup in 2018, then reaching the semi-final of the tournament four years later, it seems unthinkable that this Croatia team could fall at the first hurdle in Germany.\n\nGranted, they were drawn in a tough group with Spain and Italy but they would have targeted this game as a must-win to at least give them the chance of progressing as one of the best third-placed sides.\n\nThey are a side brimming with talented players, led by the talismanic Luka Modric, who have taken them far at past tournaments.\n\nBut many of those are now over 30 and it is starting to look like time might be catching up on the veteran players.\n\nFor too long in this game they failed to match the mobility and tempo of their opponents and, while the turnaround was impressive - if somewhat fortunate through the own goal - they should then have had enough to see the game out.\n\nBut instead they sat back and that proved costly as Albania once again {"uri": "8184814495", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "07:07:00", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T07:07:00Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T07:04:47Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7058823704719543, "url": "https://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/sports/football/uefa-euro-2024/uefa-euro-2024-croatia-vs-albania-when-and-where-to-watch-in-india-usa-and-uk/articleshow/111105228.cms", "title": "UEFA EURO 2024 Croatia vs Albania: When and where to watch in India, USA and UK | Football News - Times of India", "body": "NEW DELHI: Croatia will face Albania in their second Group B match, with both teams eager for a win after their initial losses. The match will kick off at 3 p.m. local time (1300 GMT) in Hamburg. This encounter is critical for both sides.\n\nThis game marks the first competitive meeting between Croatia and Albania. Croatia experienced a tough 3-0 loss to Spain in their opener.Conversely, Albania showed resilience against Italy, taking an early lead before falling 2-1.\n\nLed by the seasoned Luka Modric, Croatia is expected to dominate possession. Albania, however, will likely focus on their strong defense and quick counterattacks.\n\nAlbania is participating in its second European Championship, having first qualified in 2016. Croatia has a more established track record in major tournaments, highlighted by their 2018 World Cup final appearance.\n\nUEFA has initiated disciplinary proceedings against Albania following incidents involving their fans during a match with Italy. These accusations include displaying provocative messages, throwing objects, using fireworks, and a fan invading the pitch near the game's end.\n\nCroatia will be missing midfielder Nikola Vlasic due to a muscle injury. Meanwhile, Albania's coach, Sylvinho, assured that his team is injury-free and all players are ready for selection.\n\nDuring their game against Spain, Croatia achieved a rare accomplishment by holding 54% possession, the first team to out-possess Spain in a competitive match since 2008. Croatia also completed 528 passes compared to Spain's 392. In another highlight, Albania's Nedim Bajrami scored the fastest goal in the history of the European Championship by netting a goal just 23 seconds into the match against Italy.\n\nBoth teams are fighting to keep their tournament hopes alive. The Croatia vs. Albania match promises to be an exciting contest. Croatia is looking to redeem themselves after an initial defeat, while Albania aims to build on their strong showing against Italy. With high stakes, this game is set to be a thrilling showdown between two determined teams.\n\nCroatia vs Albania match details\n\nWhen will Croatia vs Albania start?\n\nThe UEFA European Championship 2024 Group B match between Croatia vs Albania is set for June 19, Wednesday.\n\nWhen and where to watch Croatia vs Albania in India?\n\nThe game is set to take place in Hamburg, Germany, with kickoff at 6:30 PM IST.\n\nIn India and the Indian subcontinent, UEFA Euro 2024 matches will be available on the Sony Sports Network, which holds the event's broadcast rights.\n\nCoverage will be in English on Sony Sports Ten 2 SD & HD. For those who prefer Hindi, matches can be watched on Sony Sports Ten 3 SD & HD.\n\nFans interested in regional languages have options too. Sony Sports Ten 4 SD & HD will broadcast in Tamil and Telugu, while Sony Sports Ten 5 SD & HD will offer commentary in Bengali and Malayalam.\n\nAdditionally, all UEFA Euro 2024 matches can be streamed live on the SonyLIV app and website.\n\nWhen and where to watch Croatia vs Albania in the UK?\n\nThe Croatia vs Albania Group B match will be available to watch on BBC TV Sports.\n\nViewers in the UK can stream the game live through the ITV app and website. Coverage starts at 2 pm BST on Monday.\n\nWhen and where to watch Croatia vs Albania in the USA?\n\nIn the USA, the match between Croatia and Albania will be broadcast on Fox Sports.\n\nFans can also stream the game live through the Fubo TV App or its website.\n\nThe game kicks off at 1 pm GMT in the USA, with adjusted times applicable for different time zones.\n\nThe TOI Sports Desk excels in a myriad of roles that capture the essence of live sporting events and deliver compelling content to readers worldwide. {"uri": "8185594560", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "15:48:01", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T15:48:01Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T15:46:59Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7019608020782471, "url": "https://www.aa.com.tr/en/sports/albania-draw-2-2-with-croatia-with-late-equalizer/3253607", "title": "Albania draw 2 - 2 with Croatia with late equalizer", "body": "Klaus Gjasula (8) of Albania celebrates with teammates after scoring a goal during the 2024 European Football Championship (EURO 2024) Group B football match between Croatia and Albania at Volksparkstadion in Hamburg, Germany on June 19, 2024.\n\nAlbania's Klaus Gjasula struck late Wednesday to salvage a crucial 2 - 2 draw with Croatia in Group B of EURO 2024.\n\nQazim Laci scored a header to put Albania 1 - 0 up on Croatia in the 11th minute in Hamburg's Volksparkstadion. Jasir Asani had an assist on the goal.\n\nThe Croatians leveled with a close-range finish from Andrej Kramaric in the 74th minute.\n\nCroatia took the lead two minutes later when Gjasula scored an own {"uri": "8185605353", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "15:55:35", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T15:55:35Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T15:54:56Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6980392336845398, "url": "https://www.thescottishsun.co.uk/sport/12964193/croatia-albania-match-report-euro-2024/", "title": "Croatia 2 Albania 2: Underdogs score late equaliser to leave Croats on the brink", "body": "ALBANIA salvaged a stunning last-minute point in a Euros epic against Croatia in Hamburg.\n\nQazim Laci had given the Albanians a shock 11th minute lead to boost their chances of advancing from the group stages for the first time in their 94-year history.\n\nYet with the Croats close to croaking, two goals in the 74th and 76th minute acted as a much-needed lifeline after a hellish performance.\n\nBut it did not end there as this ballsy Albania outfit pushed for a leveller and got their rewards thanks to Klaus Gjasula's 95th minute strike.\n\nGjasula had initially handed Croatia the lead with a bizarre own goal two minutes after ex-Leicester man Andrej Kramaric's equaliser.\n\nThis topsy-turvy game had everything, but agonisingly for both nations, not the three points they needed as they sit with one a piece.\n\nWith Group B now tightly poised, a final day miracle from either side is required to reach the last 16.\n\nCroatia face Italy in Leipzig and Albania take on Spain in Dusseldorf on June 24.\n\nAlbania will be heartbroken, and rightly so, having also taken the lead against Italy only to crumble in a similarly painful way. For large periods, they had Croatia on the ropes.\n\nAnd make no mistake, Croatia were woeful at times and should consider themselves lucky to still have a pulse in Germany.\n\nTheir starting XI average age of 30 years and one day points to the fact that their Golden Generation of talent looks to be at an end.\n\nAnd skipper Luca Modric - who turns 39 in September - may well be retiring off the back of this miserable Euros campaign, perhaps sooner than expected.\n\nBefore this one, the greatest Euros upset in terms of world rankings came on Monday, as Slovakia in 48th beat Belgium in third.\n\nAlbania - the second lowest ranked in the competition in 66th - came agonisingly close to smashing that record out of the water against tenth-placed Croatia.\n\nWhat a job former Arsenal full-back Sylvinho has done since taking charge of Albania in January 2023. Guiding them here was success in itself, but taking Italy and Croatia all the way in the toughest of groups? Ludicrous.\n\nThe Albanians were ahead against the Italians after just 23 seconds before losing 2-1.\n\nThey could not replicate that speed against Croatia, but it was still a fast start via Laci - one of two changes Sylvinho made alongside Armando Broja dropping out for Rey Manaj.\n\nLaci drifted into the box unmarked and glanced Jasir Asani's superb cross towards goal. Domink Livakovic was behind it but unable to stop it dribbling through his hands.\n\nCroatia simply were not at the races, bizarre considering the magnitude of this result. Dalic had tried to spice things with three changes from the Spain disappointment.\n\nIvan Perisic returned at left-back with Josko Gvardiol shifting to a more familiar centre back role while Bruno Petkovic led the line in place of Ante Budimir.\n\nThere was experience and nous all over the park, but Albania were covering the grass like their lives depended on it, hitting Croatia on the counter and defending valiantly.\n\nWhile Croatia were toothless and lacking ideas, Albania should have doubled their lead in the 30th minute as Kristjan Asllani raced through but Livakovic stood firm.\n\nRemarkably, another chance went begging as Gvardiol clumsily lost the ball but Manaj's subsequent header lacked power.\n\nDalic responded at half time with two changes - Mario Pasalic and Luka Sucic on for Marcelo Brozovic and Lovro Majer.\n\nCroatia began to dominate proceedings with Albania dropping deep and defending their lead. Petkovic and Mateo Kovacic were denied by Thomas Strakosha.\n\nAnd then, the comeback. Kramaric was fed by another sub in Budimir, cutting inside before finding the bottom corner - a first Euros goal to celebrate his 33rd birthday.\n\nGjasula's own goal has to be seen to be believed, Budimir's cut-back cleared by Berat Djimsiti but into his own man as it ballooned into his own net.\n\nAlbania found a second wind, however, and Gjasula responded in the best possible way, belting past Livakovic with seconds remaining.\n\nDalic demanded the same amount of respect that England get before this game. Respectfully, this Croatian lot are no where near the Three Lions.", "source": {"uri": "thescottishsun.co.uk", "dataType": "news", "title": "The Scottish Sun"}, "authors": [{"uri": {"uri": "8185556321", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "15:20:33", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T15:20:33Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T15:19:30Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6980392336845398, "url": "https://www.nytimes.com/athletic/5572674/2024/06/19/croatia-albania-euro-2024/", "title": "The Briefing: Croatia 2 Albania 2 - How did Croatia turn it around? Unluckiest own goal? Can Albania go through?", "body": "Just when it looked as though Croatia had disproved their doubters by coming from behind to beat Albania, they let it slip at the end.\n\nAs against Italy in their first game, Albania scored with their first shot. Against Italy, it was after just 23 seconds. This time, it came after 11 minutes. But despite struggling in the first half, Croatia took the lead in the second half, with Andrej Kramaric equalising before an unfortunate own goal shortly after.\n\nBut then Klaus Gjasula, who had scored the own goal, equalised to rescue a 2-2 draw for Albania.\n\nBoth sides, with one point each and one game to play, can still reach the knockouts.\n\nThe Athletic's Carl Anka, Tim Spiers and Dermot Corrigan break down the action.\n\nFor much of this game, there was an 'end of an era' mood about this Croatia performance.\n\nDespite the 3-0 defeat against Spain in the opener, Croatia's ageing midfield three of Luka Modric, Marcelo Brozovic and Mateo Kovacic started again together today, and their opening half was again disappointing.\n\nCroatia's attacks were either too slow or had too many players haring forward helter-skelter. Every time a move broke down, the better-organised Albanians counter-attacked dangerously.\n\nDalic has shown a lot of faith in players he knows so well, but he knew changes were required. Brozovic, now at Al Sadd in Saudi Arabia, was hooked at half-time, along with Lovro Majer.\n\nAs the half progressed, Croatia started to push Albania deeper and deeper. Modric especially kept looking to make things happen, but the 38-year-old saw a shot blocked, while Kovacic hit his chance too close to Albania goalkeeper Thomas Strakosha.\n\nDalic kept making changes, and gradually they started to open up gaps in the Albania defence, with the addition of another centre-forward in Osasuna's Ante Budimir proving crucial.\n\nFive minutes after entering, Budimir teed up Kramaric, to wrongfoot Strakosha from 15 yards. Now the momentum was all with Croatia, as a squad who have been through so many battles together rallied once more. Budimir's run and cross led to panic in the Albanian defence, and defender Klaus Gjasula had the final touch to his own net.\n\nAll the changes left Croatia even more disorganised however, and Albania were not done yet either. 2-2 was probably a fair result given how the game went and kept both side's hopes alive going into their final games.\n\nCroatia had not lost consecutive games at a major tournament since Euro 1996 - a run that remained intact amid all the late drama. Whether Dalic's side go much further remains in question, they will probably now need to beat Italy on Monday to progress.\n\nDermot Corrigan\n\nOh Albania. You can praise Croatia for persistence and spirit and generating the most quickfire of turnarounds, but for the goal that gave them the lead, Albania panicked and crumbled under pressure.\n\nAfter Kramaric's equaliser the Albanians were trying to get set in their defensive shape as Croatia attacked again, flailing their arms appealing for a foul that never came, but goodness did they have a stroke of huge misfortune too.\n\nElseid Hysaj was too weak in the challenge, allowing Ante Budimir the chance to pull back for Luka Sucic, but his free shot was heroically blocked by captain Berat Djimsiti only for the ball to ricochet off substitute Klaus Gjasula and into the net. (Gjasula, however, would redeem himself in added time.)\n\nHe was unlucky, the ball could have gone anywhere, but it rolled over the line and became the latest hugely unlucky own goal at this tournament.\n\nThink Germany's Antonio Rudiger heading a cut back into his own net, Austrian Maximilian Wober doing the same or Robin Hranac for the Czech Republic against Portugal.\n\nThis one felt like the cruellest. Albania, just like against Italy, were ahead and could have pulled off the greatest result in their footballing history. Though they missed out on that chance, they at least rescued a point through that man again, Gjasula.\n\nTim Spiers\n\nGjasula made up for his own goal by sweeping home the equaliser from the penalty spot. The celebrations were just as raucous as you would expect, with Albania coach Sylvinho racing down the sideline and jumping into the arms of an assistant.\n\nWith both teams now completely disorganised, Gjasula had another chance from the edge of the box, but the shot was blocked. Seconds later it was Croatia on the attack, with Modric breaking dangerously from half-way, and up popped Gjasula with a lunge which did not make contact, but the evasive action required to save his legs meant the Madrid midfielder lost the ball.\n\nIt was a deserved yellow card for the Darmstadt midfielder, who had quite a second half. It was yet another barnstorming game at this tournament, and Gjasula is another previously unheralded name to have made a big impact on everyone watching.\n\nThere's the seed of something good in this Albania side. Sylvinho and Pablo Zabaleta have made for one of the more entertaining dugout duos in a while, and they have helped construct a side that battles hard, but can encounter difficulties in both penalties areas.\n\nBajrami's early goal against Italy, and Laci's lovely near post header against Croatia showed us what this team can do at their peak, but there is only so far a counter-attacking team can go when they lack a clinical edge in front of goal. Mirlind Daku spooned mis-hit in the 88th minute was the sort of chance a team looking to go through as third-place qualifiers cannot miss.\n\nAnother goalline scramble in the 90th minute, ending with Daku inadvertently volleying the side of Josko Gvardiol's head, looked to be the rubber stamp on a gutting defeat.\n\nBut then, minutes from time, they got their angles right on the cross. The pull-back pass from Mitaj on the left was delightful. Gjasula's late run into the penalty box was perfect. The goal saw Hamburg's stadium erupt in noise and hugs.\n\nIf Albania manage to get out of this group as third-place qualifiers, then they would face either the winner of Group E (the chaos group containing Belgium), or F (which could be topped by Turkey or Portugal).\n\nThere's a good Plan A to this Albania team. For much of the first half they carefully contained Croatia's play and often outfought them for second balls. Kristijan Allani gave a glimpse as to why he will likely be Marcelo Brozovic's successor at Inter Milan. The 22-year-old is composed in possession and combative out of it. There's clever passing between all the physical counter-pressing. All they need is a more dynamic goalscoring option up front (it was telling that Armando Broja was an unused sub).", "source": {"uri": "nytimes.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The New York {"uri": "8185634706", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "16:16:50", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T16:16:50Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T16:15:50Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6980392336845398, "url": "https://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/sports/football/uefa-euro-2024/albania-score-stoppage-time-equaliser-to-hold-croatia-2-2-in-euro-2024/articleshow/111119409.cms", "title": "Albania score stoppage time equaliser to hold Croatia 2-2 in Euro 2024 | Football News - Times of India", "body": "Albania held Croatia to a 2-2 draw in a thrilling Euro 2024 group-stage match in Hamburg on Wednesday, leaving the latter at risk of an early exit from the tournament. Klaus Gjasula of Albania scored at both ends, including a dramatic equaliser in injury time.\n\nAlbania took an early lead through Qazim Laci, but Croatia improved in the second half after making two substitutions at half-time.\n\nAndrej Kramaric levelled the score with 16 minutes remaining, and Gjasula then put through his own net. However, the Albania midfielder redeemed himself by scoring in the fifth minute of injury time to secure a point for his team.\n\nCroatia, semi-finalists at the 2022 World Cup, will likely need a victory against holders Italy in their final Group B match on June 24 to progress to the knockout phase for a fifth consecutive major tournament.\n\nAlbania, despite earning praise for their performances against Italy and Croatia, have been unable to hold onto leads in both games and will probably need to defeat Spain to keep their last-16 hopes alive.\n\nCroatia's lacklustre first-half display ultimately cost them, and their 'golden generation' is now in danger of exiting the tournament in disappointing fashion.\n\nCoach Zlatko Dalic made no changes to his formation from the Spain defeat, but brought in Ivan Perisic at left-back and moved Josko Gvardiol into central defence.\n\nThe atmosphere inside the stadium was electric, with supporters of both teams creating one of the best ambiences of the tournament so far. Albania started quickly, as they did against Italy, with Laci scoring in the 11th minute from a Jasir Asani cross.\n\nCroatia struggled to impose their passing game, and Albania continued to look more dangerous, with Kristjan Asllani and Rey Manaj missing excellent opportunities to extend their lead.\n\nDalic's half-time substitutions, Luka Sucic and Mario Pasalic, brought about an improvement in Croatia's performance. However, Albania remained a threat on the counter-attack, with Nedim Bajrami going close in the 67th minute.\n\nKramaric finally found the equaliser for Croatia in the 74th minute, cutting inside and finishing into the near post. Two minutes later, Gjasula's own goal appeared to complete the turnaround, but Albania refused to give up.\n\nGjasula made amends by scoring the equaliser in injury time, and both sides threw bodies forward in search of a winner, but to no avail.\n\nThe TOI Sports Desk excels in a myriad of roles that capture the essence of live sporting events and deliver compelling content to readers worldwide. "body": "EURO 2024 has been sensational so far and with the second round of group stages matches getting underway, it's about to get even better.\n\nYou can follow all of Wednesday's action right here.\n\nScorers: Kramari\u0107 75', Gjasula (OG) 77'; La\u00e7i 11', Gjasula 90+5'\n\nKlaus Gjasula went from zero to hero for Albania as his own goal was followed by an injury time equaliser to secure a 2-2 with Croatia.\n\nBoth of these sides lost their opening game in Group B with Croatia going down to a strong Spain side, whilst Albania thrilled early on against Italy but struggled to keep up that momentum.\n\nA defeat here then, would almost certainly end one of these teams' chances of getting to the round of 16.\n\nAs such, it was a fairly cagey opening but that was blown wide open on 11 minutes as Qazim Laci found space inside the area headed Albania into a lead.\n\nDespite enjoying nearly 70 per cent of the ball, Croatia were struggling to create any sort of meaningful chances with the Albanian defence roared by their fans and remaining resolute.\n\nDespite going into the lead, Albania were still pushing for a second and almost got it as La\u00e7i's first time effort from the edge of the area just went over the bar.\n\nWith almost the least kick of the half Rey Manaj had a great chance to double Albania's advantage but his close range header was saved.\n\nInto the second half and immediately Croatia made two attacking substitutions as they went for broke.\n\nOne of those subs, Luka Susic went close straightaway as his effort from the right-hand side of the area was palmed away well.\n\nThings just weren't working for Zlatko Dali\u0107's side as they went into the last half hour desperate to find an equaliser from somewhere.\n\nIt really was all Croatia with 20 minutes to go but despite Luka Modri\u0107's best efforts, there was simply no way through, over or around this Albania backline.\n\nEventually all that pressure told however as Andrej Kramari\u0107 cut back on his right foot and rifled in a low effort from 12 yards out.\n\nAnd then just 30 seconds later Croatia took the lead as Klaus Gjasula put the ball into his "sim": 0.686274528503418, "url": "https://theprint.in/sport/soccer-albania-score-stoppage-time-equaliser-to-hold-careless-croatia/2138703/", "title": "Soccer-Albania score stoppage time equaliser to hold careless Croatia", "body": "Both countries now have a single point after their opening two matches and are left effectively needing to win their last group games on Monday if they are to progress into the knockout stage.\n\nNo team has made the next round with just two draws since the Euro finals expanded to 24 teams in 2016 -- offering a place in the last-16 to the four best third-placed finishers.\n\nAlbania had taken an early lead but the Croats scored twice in the space of two minutes to revive their hopes in a match full of twists and turns and played to a backdrop of ear-splitting noise.\n\nAndrej Kramaric grabbed a 74th minute equaliser and then followed an own goal from Gjasula 120 seconds later as an increasingly dominant Croatia, who lost 3-0 to Spain in their opening game, clawed their way back.\n\nThey had pounded away at the Albania goal in the second half after looking anxious and frustrated at halftime as their unfancied opponents went into the break ahead.\n\nQazim Laci's 11th minute header put Albania in an early lead, as had been the case against Italy in their opening game when they scored after just 23 seconds.\n\nThis time they were a touch tardy, weathering early pressure before Jasir Asani whipped in a cross from the right that Laci got a glancing head to before it slipped under goalkeeper Dominik Livakovic.\n\nThe Croat keeper could have done better but made up for the slip with two key saves later in the first half, denying Kristjan Asllani and then stopping Rey Manaj's diving header as Albania came close to doubling their lead.\n\nAlbania's gritty determination - and the speed with which they seized counterattacking opportunities - belied their lowly ranking, some 56 places below 10th placed Croatia.\n\nA double change at the break for Croatia was followed by intense pressure on the Albania goal with Thomas Strakosha saving from Luka Sucic and Mateo Kovacic to keep the lead intact right until the 74th minute when Kramaric, on his 33rd birthday, netted from close range.\n\nHe shot through the legs of Elseid Hysaj while wrongfooting Strakosha.\n\nThen came the own goal as Ante Budimir's shot, set up by Mario Pasalic's pull back from the byline, was blocked by Berat Djimsiti only for the rebound to hit Gjasula and go into his own net.\n\nBut Albania were not to be outdone and Gjasula sidefooted into the net with five minutes of additional time already played for a dramatic conclusion to the contest.\n\n\"This is why everyone loves football. In the last seconds, sometimes you score a goal to win, sometimes you concede,\" said Kramaric.\n\nAlbania finish their group schedule against Spain in Duesseldorf on Monday and Gjasula said they held out hope.\n\n\"We know that the game with Spain is very difficult but in football everything is possible. If we will play like today everything can happen,\" he told reporters.\n\nCroatia will meet Italy in Leipzig at the same time with the odds against them.\n\n\"The first half was very bad but the second much better, which is encouraging for the match with Italy,\" added Croatia coach Zlatko Dalic. \"We are still in the game, we shall prepare and do all in our power to go on.\"\n\n(Additional {"uri": "8185667763", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "16:43:46", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T16:43:46Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T16:42:17Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.686274528503418, "url": "https://www.sportbible.com/football/football-news/croatia-albania-euro-2024-world-cup-record-stats-448606-20240619", "title": "Croatia vs Albania thriller helped create unique piece of Euros AND World Cup history that may never be matched", "body": "Croatia and Albania played out a 2-2 thriller on Wednesday afternoon.\n\nThe 2-2 thriller between Croatia and Albania helped to create a unique piece of football history that has never been achieved at a European Championship or World Cup.\n\nAlbania, who had won one Euros game in their history before the fixture, went 1-0 up in the first half through Sparta Prague midfielder Qazim Laci.\n\nCroatia equalised on 66 minutes through Andrej Kramaric, before an own goal from Albania substitute Klaus Gjasula two minutes later made it 2-1.\n\nThat, it turned out, was to be far from Gjasula's last contribution in the fixture.\n\nThe 34-year-old, who plays his club football in Germany for Darmstadt, equalised with a picture-perfect left-footed finish into the bottom left corner on 92 minutes.\n\nThere was still time for the midfielder to do his bit defensively, as he hauled down a Croatia attacker in a desperate attempt to stop them from creating one final chance. Gjasula was subsequently booked.\n\nAnd as per OptaJoe, Gjasula's trio of contributions means he has set a European Championship and World Cup record that may never be matched.\n\nHe is the first substitute in the history of both competitions to come off the bench and score a goal and an own goal in the same match. By default, therefore, he is also the first player to record both of those feats and collect a yellow card.\n\nThe 2-2 draw means both sides have one point to their name in Group B, with Albania losing 2-1 to Italy and Croatia falling 3-0 to Spain on matchday one.\n\nAlbania are currently third on goal difference, and face Spain in their final group game as they attempt to qualify for the knockout stages for the first time in their history.\n\nCroatia, meanwhile, will hope to avoid the ignominy of being knocked out in the group stage after finishing as runners-up at the 2018 World Cup, Albania's defenders did well to block a shot but the ball ricocheted off Klaus Gjasula who inadvertently scored the cruellest of own goals.\n\nHaving lost its opening game against Italy, the defeat would have left Albania on the brink of elimination from the tournament, but there was one more twist to come.\n\nWith the clock ticking down, Gjasula redeemed himself in the final moments, leveling the score with a calm finish which sparked jubilant scenes from Albania's traveling fans.\n\nCroatia, ranked 56 places higher than Albania, looked disappointed by the result at full-time but a draw was probably a fair result.\n\nAlbania now sits third in Group B with one point, ahead of Croatia only on goal difference.
