{"uri": "8185612548", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "16:01:35", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T16:01:35Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T16:00:27Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6745098233222961, "url": "https://ca.sports.yahoo.com/news/albania-klaus-gjasula-levels-stoppage-155550243.html", "title": "Albania's Klaus Gjasula levels in stoppage time in Euro 2024 thriller against Croatia", "body": "Klaus Gjasula struck five minutes into stoppage time to rescue a 2-2 draw for Albania against Croatia in Hamburg and keep alive their hopes of reaching the Euro 2024 knockout stages.\n\nThe 2022 World Cup semi-finalists looked to have secured a fine comeback win after Andrej Kramaric scored in the 74th minute to cancel out Qazim Laci's early goal for Albania, then midfielder Gjasula inadvertently turned the ball past his own goalkeeper two minutes later.\n\nBut with time almost up, Albania attacked down the left and the ball was crossed to Gjasula who fired left-footed into the corner to stun Croatia and set up a tense finale to Group B.\n\nThey've done so much for their country, the likes of Ivan Perisic, Marcelo Brozovic and Luka Modric, but sitting at the foot of Group B with a point to their name, it is looking increasingly likely they will be signing off their international careers in disappointment. They face Italy on Monday.\n\nWhat a thrilling game in Hamburg. Croatia will be kicking themselves especially after doing so well to turn things around in the second half. Albania looked tired late on but they held on and got their equaliser. The story of the day was Gjasula who came on as a substitute in a stadium he used to play in regularly with Hamburg, scored a devastating O.G. then went up the other end and salvaged a point for his country in dramatic fashion. Brilliant.\n\nAm I watching the NBA play-offs or the Euros? It's like a game of basketball now, end to end stuff. Albania have one last stab then Croatia do the same, Kovacic's shot saved and the final whistle goes. I really didn't want that game to end. This is what the Euros is all about.\n\nGjasula with a late late equaliser and redemption! It looked for a while there like Albania were dead and buried but they've pulled it out of the hat. What a game! Gvardiol is on the turf, head in hands, as are the thousands of Croatian fans in the stadium.\n\nDaku has two goes in a chaotic box scramble. He finally blasts it over.\n\nAlbania with a big chance to equalise. Hoxha's effort is parried into the path of sub Mirlind Daku but his follow-up from close range is blasted over. Flag goes up for a offside though.\n\nModric goes for one from range but it goes just wide. Would have been the cherry on top. Baturina takes on his man on the left edge of the box, he hits a shot while falling but the keeper saves.\n\nCroatia subs: Kramaric and Perisic make way for Sosa and Baturina.\n\nAll Croatia now. Albania wilting rapidly. Perisic's crossing today has been nothing short of sublime. He floats in another beauty that nearly gets to Budamir. Speaking of Budamir, he's been fantastic since coming on, making all the difference. They needed a big second half Croatia, and they have delivered.\n\nThey've turned it around! And what a calamitous goal it is. Gjasula own goal. Budamir beats his man on the end line and plays it to Pasalic with an open goal. The shot is blocked but the clearance deflects off the substitute and flies into his own net. Have to feel for the Albanians.\n\nKramaric finally finds the net! Albania's resistance broken. Kovacic flicks it to Budamir who plays in Kramaric. The former Leicester man slots home and they're level.\n\nGoalscorer Laci makes way for 34-year-old Gjasula. Juranovic loses it near his own area, its stolen by Bajrami but his effort is weak.\n\nPerisic with another cross from wide left, met by Petkovic but no luck. Budimir on for Petkovic for Croatia.\n\nBajrami takes on Gvardiol, waits for him to commit but the Manchester City defender doesn't so he tries his luck. The ball goes high, right and wide. At least the Albanians are starting to find their way back into the game now.\n\nLaci is fuming. The Albanians steal possession in the Croatian half, Laci is free in space with the potential of a one-on-one but they play the ball backwards. Dumbfounded.\n\nCroatia continue to pile on the pressure here. Albania struggling to get out of their own half, being forced backward on every attempt to break. When they do finally get out Aslani has a go from the edge of the area but it is underhit and Livakovic gathers happily.\n\nSeferi comes on for Asani for the Albanians.\n\nModric hits a piledriver right into the midriff of Amadani. The referee stops play. Andros Townsend makes his discontentment known on ITV commentary.\n\n\"I wouldn't be stopping the game for that\"\n\n\"Does a football to the stomach count as a serious injury?\"\n\nAlbania yet to threaten in this half so far but they've already shown they don't need many chances to score. Croatia very much in control at the moment though. Another cross, another header, no goal but a corner for Croatia. Modric whips it in and somehow Sutelo missed from centimeters with a free header. Modric can't believe his eyes.\n\nKovacic tries one from just outside the area. It is deflected but it doesn't phase Strakosha who stays central and catches with ease. Perisic with yet another cross into the box but no one there to head it home.\n\nThe ball finds its way to Sucic in the box, great opportunity but it is hit straight at the keeper. Perisic flies one into the danger area. It's met by Pasalic who heads wide. Croatia getting a foothold now.\n\nPerisic with another long throw into the area. Petkovic rises to meet again but it goes wide for a goal kick.\n\nSucic involved already. He crosses to Petkovic who can't connect properly with his head to guide it goalwards.\n\nSucic and Pasalic come on for Majer and Brozovic. Fresh legs clearly needed by Croatia especially in the midfield. 45 minutes left for Croatia to save their tournament - and reputation.\n\nAlbania will be more than happy with that first-half display. They've got their goal, created plenty of chances, looked dangerous whenever they've entered the Croatian half and managed to keep their oppositions attacking force at bay. More of the same in the second half one would assume.\n\nManaj has a great chance in front of goal. Cross whipped in by Hysaj onto the forehead of Manaj who heads it into the ground. Livakovic saves well again. Seconds later Croatia attack. Perisic's cross is met by Petkovic and saved wonderfully by Strakosha. The referee blows up anyway for offside. Half-time.\n\nKramaric sends in another one, this time to Majer. It looks like the Albanian defender gets a touch on it but the linesman gives a goal kick.\n\nKovacic loses possession leading to a quick Albania counter. It is quelled but they hold possession. The Albanian crowd are drowning out the Croatian chants. Kramaric beats his man a couple of times on the edge of the box before crossing it into nobody in the box.\n\nModric sends the free in but Strakosha punches away. Long ball is played over the top to Asani from a quick free but he fails to control it. Brozovic has a go down the other end but it trickles into the keepers gloves.\n\nCroatia have yet to test Albanian keeper Strakosha. They play around with the ball in the middle of the park. They certainly have players who can hurt an opposition, when will they get their first big chance of the game? They have a free on the edge of the area now. Could this be it?\n\nWhat a chance for Albania! Ball played through to Asllani who is one-on-one with Livakovic but the keeper stays tall and saves the midfielder's effort. Could so easily have been two.\n\nFree for Albania. It's a bit long but Bajrami manages to find Laci whose cross is cleared. Asani finds Manaj in the box who heads it down to Hysaj. The defender hits it first time on the half-volley but it flies over. Albania still looking the more dangerous in attack.\n\nMajer floats in another lethal cross off his left, right onto the head of Petkovic but the striker can't guide it goalwards and it goes over the crossbar.\n\nModric pulling the strings in midfield as expected. Croatia put some nice link-up play together. They're starting to look a bit more productive in possession (they currently have 63 percent of it). Twice they get close to the box but the Albanians break down their attack.\n\nEnd to end again. Bajrami in a foot race with Sutelo but the Croatian clears. Kramaric finds himself in a similar situation down the other end but the defenders do their job. Juranovic has a go from the edge of the area but it drags just wide.\n\nPerisic launches a long throw into the box, dangerous but cleared. Perisic whips in another cross seconds later but the Albanians deal.\n\nAlbania appeal for a penalty but the referee is having none of it. Down the other end Modric steals the ball from a napping Mitaj but Arlind Ajeti kicks it out, stopping a potential Croatia attack.\n\nCroatia looking so open and vulnerable at the moment. Bajrami cuts in from the left and unleashes one but the keeper palms it into the side netting. Hysaj attempts the spectacular from the outside of the box but it is blocked.\n\nIt's been a pretty fast start to the game from both sides. Hysaj curls in a cross that Sutelo fails to properly clear. The ball is played back out to the midfield. It's whipped in once more from the right hand side and met by Laci in the box who heads it past Livakovic. Another early goal for the Albanians!\n\nCroatia with their first period of pressure. Maher cross cleared from corner. Ivanovic tries to find Petkovic with another cross from wide but cleared once more. Hysaj loses the ball to Kovacic on the edge of the area but they quickly win it back.\n\nAlbania again looking sharp in the Croatian half. They win a free 35 yards out, the ball is clipped in to Asani by Manaj but Sutalo heads it back to the keeper.\n\nAlbania stringing some nice passes together in the opening phase of play, looking confident. Ball played over the top to Bajrami who crosses low but it is cleared by Gvardiol.\n\nAnd we're off...\n\nBoth teams belt out their national anthems with pride as the sun beats down in Hamburg. Kick-off in three minutes.\n\nAlbania coach Sylvinho spoke during the week, touching on his approach to games against bigger teams.\n\n\"I have seen other sides in this tournament. If you try and go toe-to-toe with them, they will score five or six against you,\" said the former Arsenal and Barcelona defender.\n\n\"It's only our second time here in the Euros. We have young players, very good players, but it's not easy.\"\n\nThe Albanian team has been announced prior to kick-off and there's is neither sight nor sound of Chelsea striker Armando Broja in the starting 11, perhaps their most recognisable player.\n\nCroatia's Euro hopes have been dealt a blow with midfielder Nikola Vlasic ruled out of the tournament through injury.\n\nThe 26-year-old Torino midfielder, formerly of West Ham and Everton, picked up a muscle injury in training. Vlasic has been capped 56 times for his country.\n\nFollowing a scan, Vlasic said he will now be heading home.\n\n\"I'm extremely sorry that this new injury will prevent me from helping the team,\" Vlasic said.\n\n\"I've done everything possible to be ready, and I'd like to thank the head coach and the coaching staff for the opportunity. I believe in this team and I'm sure they will succeed - I'll be their biggest fan!\".\n\nCroatia have lost three of their past five competitive matches, going down against Turkey, Wales and Spain in this run. It is is as many defeats as they had suffered across their previous 29 games in competitive action combined. They'll need to turn that form around if they are to escape the Euro 2024 group stages.\n\nGood afternoon everybody and welcome to the Telegraph's live blog of the Group B clash between Croatia and Albania at the Volksparkstadion in Hamburg. We will be taking you through every moment, every bulge of the net, every woodwork hit and every crunching tackle made as Croatia aim to bounce back from their disappointing 3-0 defeat to Spain in the tournament's opening round of matches.\n\nAs for the Albanians, they nearly caused a mighty upset in their opening encounter with Italy, scoring after just 23 seconds, but the current European champions turned it around in true Azzurri fashion, eventually winning 2-1 thanks to goals from Alessandro Bastoni and Nicolo Barella.\n\nDespite their underwhelming display against Spain, the Croatian squad are well used to playing on the biggest stage and will no doubt be favourites for this. Zlatko Dalic's side reached the 2018 World Cup final and the penultimate stages in Qatar in 2022.\n\nThey have recovered from slow starts before, progressing from the group stage at Euro 2020 despite losing to England in their opening game, and as previously mentioned at the last World Cup they reached the semi-finals after an opening loss to Morocco.\n\n\"There is no room for pessimism, everything is still in our hands,\" Dalic said. \"Of course, we have to be better. It's my job to turn the team around\" he continued.\n\nTheir goal difference surely isn't doing them any favours in the group but a big win in Hamburg today can make up for it, especially with Italy taking on Spain tomorrow night.\n\nEuro 2024 has brought us plenty of goals thus far, let's hope that continues today. "sim": 0.6745098233222961, "url": "https://newmail-ng.com/albania/", "title": "Albania equalise in injury time in Croatia thriller", "body": "Albania scored a dramatic stoppage-time equaliser to deny Croatia a victory that severely dents the 2018 World Cup finalists' hopes of reaching the knockout stage of Euro 2024.\n\nContentsAlbania rewarded for no-fear displayEnd of an era approaching for Croatia?\n\nIn what was a chaotic but entertaining end to the game, the Albanians rescued a point when Klaus Gjasula side-footed home in the 95th minute to send their supporters wild.\n\nIt had looked like the game would finish in heartbreak for Albania, having let slip another early lead.\n\nQazim Laci struck in the 11th minute and his side then defended superbly for over an hour as they looked on the verge of producing a major upset.\n\nBut Croatia turned around an incredible game at Hamburg's Volksparkstadion when former Leicester forward Andrej Kramaric drove in an equaliser, before Luka Sucic's shot deflected off Gjasula and into the Albanian net.\n\nBut Gjasula had the final say with his late strike, which means Croatia will now need to beat defending champions Italy in their final Group B game to have a chance of progressing.\n\nAlbania face a tough test in their next game against Spain, but this is a performance and result that will live long in the memory of their fans.\n\nAlbania rewarded for no-fear display\n\nThere have been some hugely entertaining games at this European Championship and this stands among the best of them.\n\nThat is in a large part down to Albania and the determination their side has put in so far in Germany to show they are not here to make up the numbers.\n\nThis is their second appearance at the Euros after qualifying in 2016, and their fans have certainly made the most of their return.\n\nIn Hamburg, before kick-off, supporters packed out walkways on the harbourfront, and when in the stadium, they produced incredible noise throughout the game.\n\nThat energy was clearly transferred to the players, whose fast-paced counter-attacking football had Croatia rattled, and their 1-0 lead at half-time was fully deserved.\n\nWhen Croatia scored twice to turn things around, it will have sparked a sense of deja vu among the Albanian fans, having seen Italy fight back to beat them in their first game.\n\nBut this time they did not wilt and instead pushed hard for the equaliser in the closing stages, before Gjasula got the reward his side's battling display deserved.\n\nEnd of an era approaching for Croatia?\n\nHaving finished runners-up at the World Cup in 2018, then reaching the semi-final of the tournament four years later, it seems unthinkable that this Croatian team could fall at the first hurdle in Germany.\n\nGranted, they were drawn in a tough group with Spain and Italy but they would have targeted this game as a must-win to at least give them the chance of progressing as one of the best third-placed sides.\n\nThey are a side brimming with talented players, led by the talismanic Luka Modric, who have taken them far at past tournaments.\n\nBut many of those are now over 30 and it is starting to look like time might be catching up on the veteran players.\n\nFor too long in this game, they failed to match the mobility and tempo of their opponents and, while the turnaround was impressive -- if somewhat fortunate through their own goal -- they should then have had enough to see the game out.\n\nBut instead they sat back and that proved costly as Albania once again found Croatia pushed hard for an equaliser but struggled to create clear chances as Albania defended resolutely and looked threatening on the counter-attack.\n\nCroatia finally levelled in the 74th minute when Andrej Kramari\u0107 fired home on his birthday. Substitute Ante Budimir then turned the game around, his cut-back leading to an own goal by Klaus Gjasula. Yet, there was late drama as Gjasula atoned for his error by heading home deep into stoppage time to snatch an unlikely point for Albania.\n\nWhile Croatia avoided their first back-to-back losses at a major tournament since Euro 96, they will likely need a result against defending champions Italy to secure a knockout round spot. As for Albania, Sylvinho's side have it all to play for against Spain after this morale-boosting fightback.\n\nThe final Group B games take place on Monday, with Croatia facing Italy and Albania {"uri": "8185822489", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "18:54:27", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T18:54:27Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T18:53:34Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6627451181411743, "url": "https://www.rediff.com/sports/report/euro-2024-whats-going-wrong-for-croatia-pix/20240620.htm", "title": "Euro 2024: What's going wrong for Croatia?", "body": "IMAGE: Albania's Klaus Gjasula and Croatia's Mario Pasalic react after the match against Albania on Wednesday. Photograph: Carmen Jaspersen/Reuters\n\nCroatia's fans have been spoiled for success in recent years, but they could be forgiven for wondering whether the side that turns up at the European Championships bears any resemblance to their World Cup overachievers.\n\nTheir Euro 2024 hopes were left hanging by a thread after another sleepy display against Albania on Wednesday in which they switched off at key moments and failed to put their opponents to the sword in a 2-2 draw.\n\nFor a brief time in the second half, they played with the same style and thrust as the teams that reached the World Cup final in 2018 and the semis four years later.\n\nBut for all of the first half and the final 10 minutes of the second they resembled the Croatia that has never been past the quarter-finals at the European Championship and fell in the last 16 at the previous two editions.\n\nAfter their 3-0 defeat by Spain in their Group B opener, Croatia needed a fast start. Instead they produced the opposite, falling behind after 11 minutes when Qazim Laci ghosted in and glanced home a header that Croatia keeper Dominik Livakovic should have kept out.\n\nWhat followed was a soporific display of the art of passing for passing's sake. If passing teams to death was a successful strategy then Croatia would be football's most lethal executioners. But hogging the ball in the first half with over 60% possession got them nowhere.\n\nIt was a similar story in their opener when they had more possession than Spain -- the first team to do so in 136 competitive matches since the Euro 2008 final -- but ended up losing 3-0.\n\nLike a medieval army picking an elevated spot to engage in battle, Albania were happy to concede territory up the field in favour of packing the final third, safe in the knowledge that Croatia would not hurt them.\n\nIMAGE: Albania's Klaus Gjasula celebrates scoring their equaliser. Photograph: Fabian Bimmer/Reuters\n\nThat strategy fell apart in the second half, however, after Croatia brought on substitutes Luka Sucic and Mario Pasalic in the break and looked almost unrecognisable as they tore into their opponents.\n\nThey levelled when Andrej Kramaric shot through the legs of Elseid Hysaj into the bottom corner in the 73rd minute and took the lead when Albania's Klaus Gjasula saw the ball bounce off him into his own goal.\n\nThat should have been the cue for Croatia to twist the knife or at least shut up shop. Instead they seemed to slacken off and invite the Albanians back into the match.\n\nIt was deep in stoppage time when Albania drew level, with Gjasula drilling his finish hard and low into net to make up for his earlier own goal.\n\nCroatia's fans were silenced and no doubt thinking they had seen this all before at the Euros.\n\nAt Euro 2020, Zlatko Dalic's side conceded twice in extra time in a 5-3 last-16 defeat to Spain, while in 2016 they conceded with three minutes left of extra time against eventual champions Portugal at the same stage.\n\nIn 2012 they didn't escape the group stage after Spain bagged an 88th-minute winner in their final game and there was a similar tale of woe in 2008 when they lost on penalties in the quarters.\n\nThey will now almost certainly need to beat Italy in their final group game on Monday to have any chance of reaching the knockouts.\n\nCroatian fans will be hoping it's their World Cup side who turn up in Leipzig rather than the Euros one that After Croatia's shock defeat to Spain in Berlin, Croatia needed to win against Albania -- and the fans were out in all of their red-and-white-checkered glory once again. But the Albania fans were out in full force, too.\n\nDali\u0107 made some changes to the lineup compared to the Spain match. Ivan Peri\u0161i\u0107 started from the first minute at left back, Gvardiol and \u0160utali were paired back at center back, and Juranovi\u0107 at right back. The midfield line stayed the same, and Petkovi\u0107 replaced Budimir up top.\n\nLineups\n\nCroatia: Livakovi\u0107, Juranovi\u0107, \u0160utalo, Gvardiol, Peri\u0161i\u0107, Modri\u0107, Brozovi\u0107, Kova\u010di\u0107, Majer, Kramari\u0107, Petkovi\u0107\n\nAlbania: Strakosha, Hysaj, Djimsiti, Arlind Ajeti, Mitaj, Asllani, Ramadani, Laci, Asani, Manaj, Bajrami\n\nMatch Report\n\nAlbania looked dangerous in the first few minutes of the match and pressured Croatia's defense. From the 5th minute, Croatia regained possession and pushed into Albania's half. A corner kick was played short, and a free kick for Croatia was unsuccessful.\n\nThe stadium had never been louder. Brozovi\u0107 had the first shot on target in the 20th minute.\n\nPetkovi\u0107 missed a chance over the goal in the 26th, and then a dangerous free kick was awarded to Albania the following minute. Another great chance for Albania finished over the goal.\n\nMdori\u0107 lost the ball in Croatia's half which almost resulted in another goal for Albania, but luckily Gvardiol was there to save the day.\n\nCroatia played possession from the 30th minute and was granted a foul on the left edge of the box, but no one was in front of the Albania keeper to knock it in.\n\nThe match was 1-0 for Albania at halftime.\n\nSucic and Pasalic were subbed on for Majer and Brozovic to start the second half. Let's hope this helps Croatia's game.\n\nJuranovic launched the ball into the box from the right but it ended in the keeper's hands.\n\nSucic had a shot on goal in the 50th minute and Croatia was definitely more active in Albania's half for the first 10 minutes.\n\nKova took a shot in the 53rd minute that went into the keeper's hands. Budimir was subbed on for Petkovic in the 68th minute.\n\nAnother corner was awarded for Croatia in the 70th minute, but it was cleared by the Albania defense.\n\nAnd then finally, right as we were beginning to lose hope - Kramaric saves the day to score for 1-1 in the 74th minute!\n\nPasalic missed a sitter in front of the keeper in the next minute, but another miracle for Croatia - an own goal in the 76th minute for 2-1 Croatiaaaaaaaa!\n\nOkay, okay - and the fans started screaming again. Sosa was subbed on for Perisic and Baturina for Kramaric in the 85th minute.\n\nLuka shot from just outside the box in the 88th minute, but went wide of the goal. We were counting down the seconds to the final whistle.\n\nBaturina wowed with an incredible run up the left side in the 89th minute and shot at the keeper - but well done to the 21-year-old - what a way to arrive at your first Euros.\n\nFive minutes of stoppage time were added to the end of the match. All Croatia needed to do was hold onto their lead, but not even that was possible. Albania scored a last-minute goal for 2-2.\n\nCroatia plays Italy on Monday at 9 pm in the most decisive game of Group B. Can the Vatreni make magic happen again? First, Andrej Kramaric cut a lovely finish into the bottom corner before a clinical move down the left ended with substitute Gjasula turning an unfortunate ricochet into his own net 14 minutes from time.\n\nHowever, Gjasula would redeem himself in the fifth minute of stoppage time as he finished off a flowing move down the left to earn the minnows a priceless point.\n\nThe result sees Albania take third spot behind Italy and leaders Spain , who both have three points ahead of the top two in Group B facing off on Wednesday evening. It was amazing and represents our people.\"\n\nWhile they shared the same result, the mood was very different for Croatia.\n\nJust two years after they beat Brazil to reach the semi-final of the World Cup in Qatar, they are facing the very real prospect of exiting this tournament at the group stage.\n\nAt the final whistle, Croatia players dropped to their knees, knowing just how damaging the blow will be.\n\nAfter two games in Group B they have just one point and must beat Italy in their final game on Monday to have a chance of progressing.\n\n\"The Croatian players were fuming,\" ex-Premier League footballer Clinton Morrison said on BBC Radio 5 Live.\n\n\"They know they have a tough game against Italy, they have to keep believing, but their body language looks like they are out.\"\n\nAs deserved as the result was for Albania's determined and spirited display, it also raised questions about this Croatia team.\n\nPreviously, they had been in a position somewhat similar to the one Albania now finds themselves in.\n\nThey were the underdogs who shocked big sides, although did possess some big name individuals to help them go far in major tournaments.\n\nAt the World Cup in 2018 they beat Argentina and England on their way to reaching the final, then four years later they knocked out Brazil before ultimately finishing third.\n\nCroatia's inability to match Albania's tempo suggests that the country's key players, considered their golden generation, could be on their way out.\n\n\"The World Cup was two years ago and our players are getting older,\" said Croatia boss Zlatko Dalic.\n\n\"But this tournament has shown us that everyone is having a hard time.\n\n\"For Portugal it was difficult for them to get a win against Czech Republic and also for England against Serbia, so this tournament is really open and all teams are pretty equal.\"\n\nWhile this result and performance against Albania was disappointing for Croatia, it was a different story in their 3-0 loss in their opening game against Spain.\n\nThat game was evenly matched, but the difference was the Spanish took their chances.\n\n\"Football is not something you can predict,\" Croatia forward Kramaric said.\n\n\"They [Spain] had three situations and scored three goals. If you look at the statistics we had more expected goals than them.\n\n\"Sometimes you win, but sometimes you don't take the goal chance.\"\n\nCroatia's situation puts them exactly where they have been at major tournaments in recent years - the underdogs.\n\nThat is what could serve them well as they look to keep alive their hopes of avoiding an early exit by beating Italy.\n\n\"We will believe "sim": 0.6549019813537598, "url": "https://theprint.in/sport/soccer-albania-score-stoppage-time-equaliser-to-hold-croatia/2138609/", "title": "Soccer-Albania score stoppage time equaliser to hold Croatia", "body": "The two countries now have a single point after their opening two matches and are left effectively needing to win their last group games on Monday if they are to progress into the knockout stage.\n\nNo team has made next round with just two draws since the Euro finals expanded to 24 teams in 2016.\n\nAlbania had taken an early lead but the Croats scored twice in the space of two minutes to revive their hopes in a match full of twists and turns and played to a backdrop of ear-splitting noise.\n\nAndrej Kramaric grabbed a 74th minute equaliser and then followed an own goal from Gjasula 120 seconds later as a dominant Croatia, who lost 3-0 to Spain in their opening game, fought their way back.\n\nThey had pounded away at the Albania goal in the second half after looking anxious and frustrated at halftime as their unfancied opponents went into the break ahead.\n\nQazim Laci's 11th minute header had Albania in an early lead, as had been the case against Italy in their opening game when they scored after just 23 seconds.\n\nThis time they were a touch tardy, weathering early pressure before Jasir Asani whipped in a cross from the right that Laci got a glancing head to before it slipped under goalkeeper Dominik Livakovic.\n\nThe Croat keeper could have done better but made up for the slip with two key saves later in the first half, denying Kristjan Asllani and then stopping Rey Manaj's diving header as Albania came close to doubling their lead.\n\nAlbania's gritty determination - and the speed with which they seized counterattacking opportunities - belied their lowly ranking, some 56 places below 10th placed Croatia.\n\nA double change at the break for Croatia was followed by intense pressure on the Albania goal with Thomas Strakosha saving from Luka Sucic and Mateo Kovacic to keep the lead intact right until the 74th minute when Kramaric, on his 33rd birthday, netted from close range.\n\nHe shot through the legs of Elseid Hysaj while wrongfooting Strakosha.\n\nThen came a calamitous own goal as Ante Budimir's shot, set up by Mario Pasalic pull back from the byline, was blocked by Berat Djimsiti only for the rebound to hit Gjasula and go into his own net.\n\nBut Albania were not to be outdone and Gjasula sidefooted into the net with five minutes of additional time already played for a dramatic conclusion to the contest.\n\nAlbania finish their group schedule against Spain in Duesseldorf on Monday while Croatia meet Italy in Leipzig at the same time.\n\n(Additional reporting by Andrew Cawthorne; Editing by Toby Chopra)", "source": That ended a good run of form for the Croats, who were undefeated in six prior to that clash, but will expect to get back to winning ways here.\n\nAlbania could not have dreamt of a better start to their campaign, scoring the fastest goal in European Championship history just 23 seconds into their 2-1 defeat to Italy. {"uri": "8185685975", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "16:57:40", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T16:57:40Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T16:56:20Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6470588445663452, "url": "https://www.khaleejtimes.com/sports/football/croatia-just-cant-seem-to-get-it-right-at-the-euros", "title": "Croatia just can't seem to get it right at the Euros", "body": "Albania's Arber Hoxha consoles Croatia's Luka Modric after the match. -- Reuters\n\nCroatia's fans have been spoiled for success in recent years, but they could be forgiven for wondering whether the side that turns up at the European Championships bears any resemblance to their World Cup overachievers.\n\nTheir Euro 2024 hopes were left hanging by a thread after another sleepy display against Albania on Wednesday in which they switched off at key moments and failed to put their opponents to the sword in a 2-2 draw.\n\nFor a brief time in the second half, they played with the same style and thrust as the teams that reached the World Cup final in 2018 and the semis four years later.\n\nBut for all of the first half and the final 10 minutes of the second they resembled the Croatia that has never been past the quarterfinals at the European Championship and fell in the last 16 at the previous two editions.\n\nAfter their 3-0 defeat by Spain in their Group B opener, Croatia needed a fast start. Instead they produced the opposite, falling behind after 11 minutes when Qazim Laci ghosted in and glanced home a header that Croatia keeper Dominik Livakovic should have kept out.\n\nWhat followed was a soporific display of the art of passing for passing's sake. If passing teams to death was a successful strategy then Croatia would be football's most lethal executioners. But hogging the ball in the first half with over 60% possession got them nowhere.\n\nIt was a similar story in their opener when they had more possession than Spain - the first team to do so in 136 competitive matches since the Euro 2008 final - but ended up losing 3-0.\n\nLike a medieval army picking an elevated spot to engage in battle, Albania were happy to concede territory up the field in favour of packing the final third, safe in the knowledge that Croatia would not hurt them.\n\nThat strategy fell apart in the second half, however, after Croatia brought on substitutes Luka Sucic and Mario Pasalic in the break and looked almost unrecognisable as they tore into their opponents.\n\nThey levelled when Andrej Kramaric shot through the legs of Elseid Hysaj into the bottom corner in the 73rd minute and took the lead when Albania's Klaus Gjasula saw the ball bounce off him into his own goal.\n\nThat should have been the cue for Croatia to twist the knife or at least shut up shop. Instead they seemed to slacken off and invite the Albanians back into the match.\n\nIt was deep in stoppage time when Albania drew level, with Gjasula drilling his finish hard and low into net to make to Gjasula who fired left footed into the corner to stun Croatia and set up a tense finale to Group B.\n\nCroatia thought they had won it when they went 2-1 ahead with 14 minutes to go (Ebrahim half with renewed urgency and should have levelled after 57 minutes when defender Josip Sutalo headed a near-post corner wide from two yards.\n\nKlaus Gjasula produced a fine finish to salvage Albania {"uri": "8185912310", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "20:25:19", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T20:25:19Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T20:24:09Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6392157077789307, "url": "https://sportal.co.in/2024/06/albania-squander-lead-but-claw-their-way-back-for-dramatic-draw/", "title": "Albania squander lead but claw their way back for dramatic draw", "body": "June 19 - After losing their opening matches in the Group of Death (Group B) to Romania and Italy respectively, Croatia and Albania knew that a win at the Volksparkstadion in Hamburg would reignite their Euro2024 dreams.\n\nA loss by either side and the taxi to the airport would be waiting at the stadium when they play their respective final group matches on Monday. The 2-2 draw keeps both sides alive.\n\nConventional tournament wisdom says you cannot lose your first game and expect to advance except when there is a 24-team tournament. This means four teams have the chance to sneak through to the knockout phase as a best 3rd place team and in this group one win with goal difference might just be enough.\n\nAfter smashing the Euro record for scoring the fastest ever goal in the competition's history (23 seconds against Italy), Albania started with the same kind of intensity.\n\nModric majestic in second half\n\nThey pinned Croatia back in their defensive third of the field and that pressure paid off in the 10th minute. Jasir Asani lofted a beautiful cross from the right side onto the head of Qazim Laci who had ghosted into the box like the invisible man as the Croatian backline stood around and watched. Dominik Livakovic the Croatian goalkeeper will look back on his effort to keep the ball out and not be a happy man.\n\nYou had to wonder whether Zlatko Dalic's men were still shellshocked from the waxing inflicted on them by Spain or perhaps father time has finally caught up with this magnificent but aging team.\n\nCroatia though are dogged, and they have taken body blows from the best. Ivan Perisic is the epitome of that mentality and he looked to put his team on his back working tirelessly down the left-hand side trying to carve open opportunities.\n\nLuka Sucic gave Croatia the lead\n\nAs Croatia pushed forward though, Albania started looking increasingly dangerous on the counterattack.\n\nIn the 31st minute Luka Modric did the unthinkable and gave the ball away initiating a 4 on 3 break. Asani's pass deflected into the path of Kristjan Asllani who's blistering drive was brilliantly saved by Livakovic, who redeemed himself for his earlier faux pas.\n\nWhat was becoming increasingly clear is that Albania's defensive set up had been cleverly devised by their coach, Sylvinho. The Brazilian obviously had learned from Arsene Wenger during his illustrious Arsenal playing career.\n\nThey were compact, narrow and difficult to play through. Croatia started resorting to hopeful balls into the box, which was nothing but food and drink for the back four and goalkeeper, Thomas Strakosha who was becoming more composed and assured by the minute.\n\nJust before the half, another counterattack and this time Roy Manaj drifting unnoticed into the area. His header though was weak and Livakovic easily collected but warning signs were there, and they were being ignored.\n\nWith a shrill blast of his whistle, referee Francois Letexier, signaled the end of the first half and we had the potential of another shock result as Albania ranked 66th by FIFA deservedly took a 1-0 lead into the dressing room against 10th ranked Croatia.\n\nZlatko Dalic made two changes to liven up his team sending on Mario Pasalic and Luka Sucic and the impact was immediate.\n\nKlaus Gjasula celebrates Albania's equaliser\n\nIn the 50th minute, Sucic worked Strakosha with a low strike that the Albanian keeper pushed away to his right. Then Pasalic found space, but his header was misdirected when it looked easier to hit the target. Three minutes later Mateo Kovacic took his turn to bring his country back into the game, but his deflected effort wasn't hit hard enough to wrongfoot Strakosha.\n\nNow it was time for Modric to step up and the maestro began to conduct the play with the majesty of his younger years.\n\nIf anyone can create tempo, it's the Croatian captain, and his probing passes started splitting that tight Albanian back four for the first time on a consistent basis. Wave after wave of Croatian attacks. Pressure, crosses, shots. Bend but don't break was the Albanian motto as Sylvinho was becoming increasingly animated in the coaching box.\n\nBreak they did though. In the 74th minute the constant, overwhelming pressure finally paid off. A smart interchange of passes released Andrej Kramaric, and once he cut inside and wrongfooted Strakosha the game was tied, and Croatia could take themselves off the life support system that was keeping them in the Euros.\n\nTwo minutes later they were more than breathing, they were celebrating as 2nd half substitute Ante Budmir bullied his way to the by-line pulling the ball back for Susic. His shot was blocked but the rebound cruelly hit Klaus Gjasula who hadn't been on the pitch for more than three minutes and bounced apologetically into the back of the goal. What a turnaround...and so unlucky for Albania.\n\nIn football if you have belief there is always time for one more chance and in the 89th minute, Albania had theirs after a storming run by Arber Hoxha who alluded what seemed like the entire Croatian back line and firing in a line drive that Livakovic did well to parry. The follow up was smashed over the bar and Livakovic took a boot to the face for his pains.\n\nYou just had to admire Albania though, because there is no quit in them.\n\nWith just one minute remaining they somehow summoned the desire and produced a brilliant team goal, expertly finished by Gjasula. Cue delirium from Sylvinho and his substitutes, coaching staff and anyone close enough to hug.\n\nStill both teams weren't finished and in a madcap three minutes both had opportunities to win it. With the final whistle the only thought was to let them keep playing. Change the rules. Last goal wins.\n\nUltimately, a point a piece was probably fair. Albania took the first half, Croatia the second, but Albania's incredible spirit kept them alive for now. With Spain up next, they'll need a proper miracle as will Croatia as they take on Italy. Yet another breathtaking game at these Euros that keep on giving.\n\nContact the writer, Nick Webster, at moc.l1718819287labto1718819287ofdlr1718819287owedi1718819287sni@o1718819287fni1718819287", {"uri": "2024-06-395084919", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "19:08:30", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T19:08:30Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T19:01:11Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6352941393852234, "url": "https://www.france24.com/en/live-news/20240619-hosts-germany-through-to-last-16-of-euros-croatia-hopes-in-balance", "title": "Hosts Germany through to last 16 of Euros, Croatia hopes in balance", "body": "Stuttgart (Germany) (AFP) - Hosts Germany became the first team to qualify for the knockout phase of Euro 2024 on Wednesday thanks to a 2-0 win over Hungary, while Croatia's hopes of progressing hang in the balance after they were held by Albania.\n\nGermany followed up their 5-1 demolition of Scotland in the tournament's opening game by seeing off the Hungarians in Stuttgart, with Jamal Musiala and Ilkay Gundogan scoring either side of half-time.\n\nJulian Nagelsmann's team have a maximum six points with one game still to come in Group A, and are certain to progress to the last 16 at least as one of the four best third-place finishers.\n\nHungary put up a fight but the hosts had too much quality in the final third, with Musiala firing in the opener midway through the first half after captain Gundogan refused to give up a lost cause in the box.\n\nThe Hungarians had an equaliser ruled out for offside just before the break, and Germany doubled their lead on 67 minutes as Gundogan swept home an assist by Maximilian Mittelstaedt.\n\nGermany's recent struggles appear to be a thing of the past, and they have now won their opening two games at a World Cup or European Championship for the first time since Euro 2012.\n\n\"We were determined to win today and confirm our performance against Scotland,\" said goalkeeper Manuel Neuer.\n\n\"We were dominant and deserved to win. You could see the euphoria in the stadium.\"\n\nHungary's hopes of progressing to the last 16 now hang by a thread, while group rivals Switzerland and Scotland meet in Wednesday's late match in Cologne.\n\nSwitzerland, quarter-finalists at Euro 2020, will be through to the last 16 with a win in that game.\n\nScotland are aiming to win a match at a major tournament for the first time since beating the Swiss 1-0 at Euro 96.\n\nGjasula saves Albania\n\nElsewhere on Wednesday, Albania's Klaus Gjasula scored at both ends, including a dramatic injury-time equaliser as his side drew 2-2 with Croatia in Hamburg.\n\nAfter a disappointing 3-0 loss to Spain in their opening game in Group B, Croatia were behind again when Qazim Laci gave Albania an early lead.\n\nBut Croatia improved after the break and Andrej Kramaric levelled with 16 minutes remaining, before Gjasula put through his own net.\n\nThe Albania midfielder became the last-gasp hero, though, slotting into the bottom corner in the fifth minute of injury time to snatch his team a point.\n\nCroatia, World Cup semi-finalists in 2022, will now likely need to win their final Group B match against holders Italy on June 24 to reach the knockout phase for a fifth straight major tournament.\n\n\"We will believe until the very end, to give our best as we did in this match,\" said forward Kramaric.\n\n\"Unfortunately we didn't win but we hope to be a bit luckier against Italy.\"\n\nAlbania have won plenty of plaudits with their performances against both Italy, in a 2-1 defeat, and Croatia, but could not hold a lead in either game and will probably have to beat Spain to keep their last-16 hopes alive.\n\n\"We have to go forward but we have to fight for every single point,\" said Albania's Brazilian coach, Sylvinho.\n\n\"It's important for our lives, the life of the country, the federation. I'm proud of the players so we have to enjoy the moment.\"\n\nGroup rivals Spain and Italy meet in Gelsenkirchen in the standout tie on Thursday, while England face Denmark and Slovenia take on Serbia Jasir Asani collected the ball wide on the right midway inside the Croatia half and launched a reaching cross that was met with a glancing header by Laci, his effort squeezing through the hands of goalkeeper Dominik Livakovic and in at the near post.\n\nThe advantage was nearly doubled on the half-hour mark when Kristjan Asllani went through but was denied by a superb low stop from Livakovic, then on the stroke of half-time the goalkeeper was again called upon to keep out Rey Manaj's close-range header.\n\nCroatia began the second half with renewed urgency and should have levelled after 57 minutes when defender Josip Sutalo headed a near-post corner wide from two yards.\n\nThe equaliser finally arrived from Kramaric, the striker finding himself in space inside the penalty area from Ante Budimir's pass and striking the ball through the legs of Elseid Hysaj. {"uri": "8185788645", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "18:25:23", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T18:25:23Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T18:22:06Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6352941393852234, "url": "https://theprint.in/sport/analysis-soccer-croatia-just-cant-seem-to-get-it-right-at-the-euros/2138768/", "title": "Analysis-Soccer-Croatia just can't seem to get it right at the Euros", "body": "For a brief time in the second half, they played with the same style and thrust as the teams that reached the World Cup final in 2018 and the semis four years later.\n\nBut for all of the first half and the final 10 minutes of the second they resembled the Croatia that has never been past the quarter-finals at the European Championship and fell in the last 16 at the previous two editions.\n\nAfter their 3-0 defeat by Spain in their Group B opener, Croatia needed a fast start. Instead they produced the opposite, falling behind after 11 minutes when Qazim Laci ghosted in and glanced home a header that Croatia keeper Dominik Livakovic should have kept out.\n\nWhat followed was a soporific display of the art of passing for passing's sake. If passing teams to death was a successful strategy then Croatia would be football's most lethal executioners. But hogging the ball in the first half with over 60% possession got them nowhere.\n\nIt was a similar story in their opener when they had more possession than Spain - the first team to do so in 136 competitive matches since the Euro 2008 final - but ended up losing 3-0.\n\nLike a medieval army picking an elevated spot to engage in battle, Albania were happy to concede territory up the field in favour of packing the final third, safe in the knowledge that Croatia would not hurt them.\n\nThat strategy fell apart in the second half, however, after Croatia brought on substitutes Luka Sucic and Mario Pasalic in the break and looked almost unrecognisable as they tore into their opponents.\n\nThey levelled when Andrej Kramaric shot through the legs of Elseid Hysaj into the bottom corner in the 73rd minute and took the lead when Albania's Klaus Gjasula saw the ball bounce off him into his own goal.\n\nThat should have been the cue for Croatia to twist the knife or at least shut up shop. Instead they seemed to slacken off and invite the Albanians back into the match.\n\nIt was deep in stoppage time when Albania drew level, with Gjasula drilling his finish hard and low into net to make up for his earlier own goal.\n\nCroatia's fans were silenced and no doubt thinking they had seen this all before at the Euros.\n\nAt Euro 2020, Zlatko Dalic's side conceded twice in extra time in a 5-3 last-16 defeat to Spain, while in 2016 they conceded with three minutes left of extra time against eventual champions Portugal at the same stage.\n\nIn 2012 they didn't escape the group stage after Spain bagged an 88th-minute winner in their final game and there was a similar tale of woe in 2008 when they lost on penalties in the quarters.\n\nThey will now almost certainly need to beat Italy in their final group game on Monday to have any chance of reaching the knockouts.\n\nCroatian fans will be hoping it's their World Cup side who turn up in Leipzig rather than the Euros one that {"uri": "8185665304", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "16:43:23", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T16:43:23Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T16:40:22Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6313725709915161, "url": "https://www.dailymail.co.uk/wires/reuters/article-13547681/Soccer-Croatia-just-right-Euros.html", "title": "Soccer-Croatia just can't seem to get it right at the Euros", "body": "HAMBURG, Germany, June 19 (Reuters) - Croatia's fans have been spoiled for success in recent years, but they could be forgiven for wondering whether the side that turns up at the European Championships bears any resemblance to their World Cup overachievers.\n\nTheir Euro 2024 hopes were left hanging by a thread after another sleepy display against Albania on Wednesday in which they switched off at key moments and failed to put their opponents to the sword in a 2-2 draw.\n\nFor a brief time in the second half, they played with the same style and thrust as the teams that reached the World Cup final in 2018 and the semis four years later.\n\nBut for all of the first half and the final 10 minutes of the second they resembled the Croatia that has never been past the quarter-finals at the European Championship and fell in the last 16 at the previous two editions.\n\nAfter their 3-0 defeat by Spain in their Group B opener, Croatia needed a fast start. Instead they produced the opposite, falling behind after 11 minutes when Qazim Laci ghosted in and glanced home a header that Croatia keeper Dominik Livakovic should have kept out.\n\nWhat followed was a soporific display of the art of passing for passing's sake. If passing teams to death was a successful strategy then Croatia would be football's most lethal executioners. But hogging the ball in the first half with over 60% possession got them nowhere.\n\nIt was a similar story in their opener when they had more possession than Spain - the first team to do so in 136 competitive matches since the Euro 2008 final - but ended up losing 3-0.\n\nLike a medieval army picking an elevated spot to engage in battle, Albania were happy to concede territory up the field in favour of packing the final third, safe in the knowledge that Croatia would not hurt them.\n\nThat strategy fell apart in the second half, however, after Croatia brought on substitutes Luka Sucic and Mario Pasalic in the break and looked almost unrecognisable as they tore into their opponents.\n\nThey levelled when Andrej Kramaric shot through the legs of Elseid Hysaj into the bottom corner in the 73rd minute and took the lead when Albania's Klaus Gjasula saw the ball bounce off him into his own goal.\n\nThat should have been the cue for Croatia to twist the knife or at least shut up shop. Instead they seemed to slacken off and invite the Albanians back into the match.\n\nIt was deep in stoppage time when Albania drew level, with Gjasula drilling his finish hard and low into net to make up for his earlier own goal.\n\nCroatia's fans were silenced and no doubt thinking they had seen this all before at the Euros.\n\nAt Euro 2020, Zlatko Dalic's side conceded twice in extra time in a 5-3 last-16 defeat to Spain, while in 2016 they conceded with three minutes left of extra time against eventual champions Portugal at the same stage.\n\nIn 2012 they didn't escape the group stage after Spain bagged an 88th-minute winner in their final game and there was a similar tale of woe in 2008 when they lost on penalties in the quarters.\n\nThey will now almost certainly need to beat Italy in their final group game on Monday to have any chance of reaching the knockouts.\n\nCroatian fans will be hoping it's their World Cup side who turn up in Leipzig rather than the Euros one that just can't seem to get it right. {"uri": "8185844768", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "19:14:38", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T19:14:38Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T19:13:46Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6313725709915161, "url": "https://today.rtl.lu/sport/international/a/2206518.html", "title": "Hosts Germany through to last 16 of Euros, Croatia hopes in balance", "body": "Hosts Germany became the first team to qualify for the knockout phase of Euro 2024 on Wednesday thanks to a 2-0 win over Hungary, while Croatia's hopes of progressing hang in the balance after they were held by Albania.\n\nGermany followed up their 5-1 demolition of Scotland in the tournament's opening game by seeing off the Hungarians in Stuttgart, with Jamal Musiala and Ilkay Gundogan scoring either side of half-time.\n\nJulian Nagelsmann's team have a maximum six points with one game still to come in Group A, and are certain to progress to the last 16 at least as one of the four best third-place finishers.\n\nHungary put up a fight but the hosts had too much quality in the final third, with Musiala firing in the opener midway through the first half after captain Gundogan refused to give up a lost cause in the box.\n\nThe Hungarians had an equaliser ruled out for offside just before the break, and Germany doubled their lead on 67 minutes as Gundogan swept home an assist by Maximilian Mittelstaedt.\n\nGermany's recent struggles appear to be a thing of the past, and they have now won their opening two games at a World Cup or European Championship for the first time since Euro 2012.\n\n\"We were determined to win today and confirm our performance against Scotland,\" said goalkeeper Manuel Neuer.\n\n\"We were dominant and deserved to win. You could see the euphoria in the stadium.\"\n\nHungary's hopes of progressing to the last 16 now hang by a thread, while group rivals Switzerland and Scotland meet in Wednesday's late match in Cologne.\n\nSwitzerland, quarter-finalists at Euro 2020, will be through to the last 16 with a win in that game.\n\nScotland are aiming to win a match at a major tournament for the first time since beating the Swiss 1-0 at Euro 96.\n\n- Gjasula saves Albania -\n\nElsewhere on Wednesday, Albania's Klaus Gjasula scored at both ends, including a dramatic injury-time equaliser as his side drew 2-2 with Croatia in Hamburg.\n\nAfter a disappointing 3-0 loss to Spain in their opening game in Group B, Croatia were behind again when Qazim Laci gave Albania an early lead.\n\nBut Croatia improved after the break and Andrej Kramaric levelled with 16 minutes remaining, before Gjasula put through his own net.\n\nThe Albania midfielder became the last-gasp hero, though, slotting into the bottom corner in the fifth minute of injury time to snatch his team a point.\n\nCroatia, World Cup semi-finalists in 2022, will now likely need to win their final Group B match against holders Italy on June 24 to reach the knockout phase for a fifth straight major tournament.\n\n\"We will believe until the very end, to give our best as we did in this match,\" said forward Kramaric.\n\n\"Unfortunately we didn't win but we hope to be a bit luckier against Italy.\"\n\nAlbania have won plenty of plaudits with their performances against both Italy, in a 2-1 defeat, and Croatia, but could not hold a lead in either game and will probably have to beat Spain to keep their last-16 hopes alive.\n\n\"We have to go forward but we have to fight for every single point,\" said Albania's Brazilian coach, Sylvinho.\n\n\"It's important for our lives, the life of the country, the federation. I'm proud of the players so we have to enjoy the moment.\"\n\nGroup rivals Spain and Italy meet in Gelsenkirchen in the standout tie on Thursday, while England face Denmark and Slovenia take on Serbia And thus, a cagey opening ensued on Wednesday.\n\nContent to slow the tempo, Albania soon became comfortable in possession. And then, almost out of nowhere, Qazim Lac\u0327i broke free at the near post to glance at Jasir Asani's pinpoint delivery from the right. Another quick-opening goal for Sylvinho's men.\n\nCroatia were momentarily shaken, and the Eagles saw their opportunity to go again. This time, Nedim Bajrami darted into the danger zone, but to the relief of Zlatko Dali\u0107, failed to test Dominik Livakovic\u0301.\n\nNow pressing higher up the pitch, Croatia engineered their first real threat as Marcelo Brozovic's anxious snap-shot flew well wide. Unfazed, Albania continued to push for a second, and in the 31st minute Livakovic\u0301 was forced to deny Kristjan Asllani.\n\nDespite sitting deep to protect their advantage, Albania breached the Brozovic-protected Vatreni back line once more before half-time; however, Livakovic\u0301 dealt with Rey Manaj's close-range header.\n\nWith the interval introduction of Mario Pasalic\u0301 and Luka Succic, Croatia produced two decent chances. Thomas Strakosha got a strong hand to Succic\u0301's powerful shot before Pasalic fired over.\n\nDalic's team were now enjoying their best spell of the game, and as Albania's energy levels waned, Croatia's threat increased.\n\nThe Vatreni were probing for a chink in the Albanian armour, and eventually, in the 74th minute, their breakthrough came. As Albania switched off, Andrej Kramaric found the bottom corner to restore parity - his first EURO goal on his 33rd birthday. Two minutes later, Croatia struck again, Klaus Gjasula deflecting into his own net amid a goalmouth scramble.\n\nStill turning the screw until the full-time whistle, Croatia's tremendous second-half performance looked to have secured them all three points. However, in a dramatic twist, Gjasula - who only came on in the 72nd minute - found redemption by driving in a low last-gasp leveller. {"uri": "8185793375", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "18:26:59", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T18:26:59Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T18:26:27Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6196078658103943, "url": "https://www.cbssports.com/soccer/news/uefa-euro-2024-scores-results-highlights-standings-germany-remain-perfect-albania-and-croatia-draw/", "title": "UEFA Euro 2024 scores, results, highlights, standings: Germany remain perfect; Albania and Croatia draw - CBSSports.com", "body": "Getty Images\n\nThe tournament may only be six days old but already the Euro 2024 knockout stages has its first team with Germany booking their passage to the last 16 with a handy 2-0 win over Hungary. It may have lacked the drama of the game that came before it but that will suit Julian Nagelsmann to a tee, his side coming through an altogether greater test than they had against Scotland.\n\nGermany's win came after perhaps the stand-out game of Euro 2024 so far, Croatia recovering after conceding early to lead Albania 2-1 only to be pegged back late on. Qazim Laci looked to have given Sylvinho's Kuqezinjt\u00eb a narrow win at Volksparkstadion in Hamburg before a late two-minute blitz from Andrej Kramaric and then a Klaus Gajsula own goal turned things Vatreni's way. However, there was still time for drama as Gjasula equalized for Albania deep into injury time and received a late booking in a big Group B result.\n\nScotland vs. Switzerland is still to come this Wednesday, here's everything you need to know so far from day six in Germany.\n\nEuro 2024 scores for WednesdayCroatia 2, Albania 2Germany 2, Hungary 0Scotland vs. Switzerland at 3 p.m. ET (preview)Germany 2, Hungary 0: Hosts wobble but reach last 16\n\nIt was hardly the first half shellacking that they meted out on Scotland in the Euro 2024 opener but Germany got the job done, a Jamal Musiala goal enough to take them through to the knockout stages. It might have gone rather differently on another day, from the outset Hungary were testing the German defense. Indeed the first half was bookended by the threat of Roland Sallai, who might have found the net in the opening exchanges and did just before the break, semi-automated offside technology confirming the Freiburg forward had just drifted offside.\n\nBetween those two openings came Germany's goal, Ilkay Gundogan pouncing on a mess in the box that Willi Orban ought to have dealt with and then teeing up Musiala to strike. The Bayern Munich playmaker might have had another, a fierce shot ricocheting off the side netting, but the hosts also had Manuel Neuer to thank for a bouncy save off a Dominik Szoboszlai free kick. From a tight angle, Bendeguz Bolla couldn't quite turn in the rebound.\n\nGermany's struggles didn't ease in a second half when Barnabas Varga drifted away from Jonathan Tah to flick a cross over the bar, a chance from which he ought to have tested Neuer. Their profligacy was punished in the 67th minute, Maximilian Mittelstadt delivering a fine low cross for Gundogan to turn in. Leroy Sane's added spark off the bench nearly brought a third for Germany, who will be assured of a top-two finish if Switzerland avoid defeat later on Wednesday. Even if they were to finish third they would be guaranteed a place in the last 16.\n\nThey will be hoping for much more than just that, however. Not since 1984 has a host nation lifted the Henri Delaunay Trophy. With seven goals to their name through two games, Germany must surely figure among the contenders to do exactly that.\n\nCroatia 2, Albania 2: Gjasula goes from villain to hero\n\nCroatia have become synonymous over the years for their dramatic and occasionally fortunate ways of avoiding defeat at international tournaments. Vatreni regularly rely on extra time and penalties when on deep runs such as their FIFA 2018 World Cup final journey in Russia. Obviously, there are no games going beyond the regulation 90 minutes plus extra time in the group stage of UEFA Euro 2024, yet Zlatko Dalic's men found a way to play with fire regardless.\n\nQazim Laci was allowed to head home after just 11 minutes in Hamburg and until the final quarter of an hour, it looked as if it might be enough for Sylvinho's side who were unlucky to lose out narrowly to Italy in their opening game. Cue Andrej Kramaric with an turn and finish equalizer on 74 minutes before a Klaus Gjasula own goal two minutes late for the full Croatia international tournament experience condensed into a matter of 120 seconds or so. Unlike in previous years, though, there was a late twist in favor of Kuqezinjt\u00eb as Gjasula found himself on hand to turn home five minutes into added time before picking up a trademark booking.\n\nThe result means that Croatia are now up against it to advance with a draw between Italy and Spain on Thursday possibly already putting a top-two finish out of reach for both Dalic's side and Albania. Only a win over the Azzurri could see this Croatia side advance and even that might require being one of the best third-placed sides while the winner between the Italians and La Roja could reach the round of 16 with a game to spare.\n\nIt seems to be one tournament too far for this golden generation of Croatian talent with Luka Modric suddenly looking every bit his 38 years of age and former stalwarts Ivan Perisic and Marcelo Brozovic also declining forces. It did look as if their black magic touch had not entirely deserted them, but Gjasula's late equalizer appeared to not only deny Croatia the win but also break their mental resolve at the end of another thrilling game of soccer at this Euro.\n\nGroup B state of playTEAMMPWDLGFGAPTSSpain\n\n1\n\n0\n\n03Italy\n\n1\n\n0\n\n13Albania\n\n1\n\n41Croatia\n\n1\n\n51\n\nThe winner of Italy vs. Spain on Thursday could be assured of a knockout round place after just two games played while any potential loser in that one would be the team to catch for Croatia and Albania. A draw in the Azzurri clash with La Roja is actually the most likely result to see both through as they will be three points clear ahead of the final games, but the task is tough for Croatia against Italy and Albania against Spain. Should one of the two be able to pull off an unexpected win in the third and final game then advancing as one of the best third-placed sides could still be on the cards but another draw is unlikely to suffice.\n\nGroup A state of playTEAMMPWDLGFGAPTS\n\nGermany\n\n2\n\n0\n\n7\n\n16\n\nSwitzerland\n\n1\n\n0\n\n13\n\nHungary\n\n0\n\n50\n\nScotland\n\n0\n\n1\n\n50\n\nGermany are through, that much is certain, while Scotland will surely have been toasting their success as they ready themselves for their meeting with Switzerland later on Wednesday. Any points that Steve Clarke's side can pick up would put them in the driving seat for what is shaping up to be a battle for third place with the Magyars in Sunday's final round of games. Of course, all that could change if they beat the Swiss, who know they will guarantee their qualification with a win. Hungary will have to win their final game if they are to have any chance of qualifying. Having lost to the top two, the best they can now hope for is a third-place finish.\n\nWhat happened on TuesdayTurkiye 3, Georgia 1Portugal 2, Czechia 1\n\nDay 5 was a thoroughly entertaining round of games despite there only being two Group F fixtures with wins for both Turkiye and Portugal to open their campaigns. A pulsating four-goal encounter at Signal Iduna Park saw Turkiye come out on top of a game which Georgia could have quite easily drawn before going on to lose out by a two-goal margin with Mert Muldur and Arda Guler scoring goal of the Euro contenders. Elsewhere, Czechia threatened an upset when Lukas Provod opened the scoring before a late Francisco Conceicao winner after a Robin Hranac own goal and a marginal Diogo Jota offside. Turkiye and Portugal meet next so Georgia and Czechia's game before that is of even more significant importance.\n\nThursday's schedule\n\nAll times Eastern\n\nSlovenia vs. Serbia, 9 a.m. Denmark vs. {"uri": "8185612864", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "16:01:49", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T16:01:49Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T16:00:45Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6196078658103943, "url": "https://www.90min.com/luka-modric-croatia-euro-2024-heartbreak-albania", "title": "Luka Modric and Croatia facing Euro 2024 heartbreak after late Albania drama", "body": "Luka Modric and Croatia are up against it after failing to beat Albania / Dan Mullan/GettyImages\n\nCroatia's Euro 2024 campaign hangs in the balance after conceding a 95th minute equaliser against Albania on matchday two, threatening to end what will likely be legendary midfielder Luka Modric's last international tournament at the group stage.\n\nZlatko Dalic's side looked like they had done enough to claim a comeback victory after a humbling defeat to Spain four days earlier when Andrej Kramaric cancelled out Albania's early opener, followed by a quick-fire second courtesy of an unwitting ricochet off Klaus Gjasula.\n\nBut it was Gjasula who became the Albanian hero deep into stoppage time when he arrived in the box to break Croatian hearts and pile considerable pressure on them going into a matchday three clash with Italy early next week. With just one point from two games, only victory in that one will be enough to reach the knockout stages. Albania could even get through if they can shock Spain.\n\nCroatia roared into life in the second half after Qazim Laci's glancing header put Albania ahead after only 11 minutes. They even squandered a few chances to extend that lead before the break.\n\nBy that stage, Modric had struggled to get control of the game, despite racking up impressive passing statistics. Manchester City's Mateo Kovacic had been a little brighter during a brief spell of pressure, but again not involved enough to warrant any more for his side.\n\nBoth Champions League-winning midfielders made a better start to the second half as Croatia finally registered a shot on target from Luka Sucic. Kovacic then saw the sting taken out of his shot by a deflection, with Modric delivering a corner that centre-back Josip Sutalo somehow headed wide.\n\nIt was Kovacic whose attempt to break the Albanian lines created the space Croatia needed to get back level, feeding Ante Budimir, who in turn slid in former Leicester City striker Andrej Kramaric for the finish.\n\nCity's Josko Gvardiol had already been increasingly stepping into midfield with the ball for Croatia and that helped made the quick-fire second possible with a pass in the build-up, although it still relied on Budimir keeping the attack alive and a huge slice of fortune when Sucic's shot was initially blocked but then bounced into the net off Gjasula.\n\nA late Albanian onslaught looked like it would peter out until Gjasula converted a cutback from the left with a first-time effort near the penalty spot.\n\nCroatia finished third at the World Cup less than two years ago, having also been to the final in 2018, but their European Championship record is sketchy by comparison to those global displays. Since the Euros expanded into a 24-team format, Croatia haven't gone beyond the last 16, while they failed to get out of the group stage at all in both 2004 and 2012.", "source": {"uri": "90min.com", {"uri": "8185876418", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "19:47:38", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T19:47:38Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T19:46:33Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6196078658103943, "url": "https://www.nytimes.com/athletic/5570712/2024/06/19/albania-croatia-group-b/", "title": "\"This is Albania; it's a bit crazy\": Outsiders making Group B rivals sweat", "body": "He may not have been focusing purely on his side's tussles with Italy and Spain but, when many others spoke pre-tournament of a 'Group of Death', it was probably not really with Albania in mind.\n\nFew will have expected them to be the group's most combative element, yet Albania - ranked 66th in the world - have become the fun variable in the quartet. With a game to play, they still have a chance of progression.\n\nManaged by former Arsenal, Barcelona and Brazil full-back Sylvinho, Albania are a physical counter-attacking side that look to make up any perceived talent gap between themselves and their opponents through hard running. It took 23 seconds for this side to make a mark at Euro 2024 as Nedim Bajrami set a new record for the fastest goal scored in European Championship history when opening the scoring against Italy. While Albania eventually lost that match 2-1, their early goal served as a warning; underestimate this team at your peril.\n\nIt was a warning that Croatia struggled to heed. Wednesday's encounter between the two sides was an unexpected and entertaining romp. It again saw Albania go ahead early - Qazim Laci nodding in a superb cross from Jasir Asani in the 11th minute - before stubbornly battling to protect their lead. At half-time, Croatia had registered 69 per cent possession, but Albania had the game's better chances.\n\nKristjan Asllani went off-target following a quick attacking move sparked by Luka Modric losing the ball. Albanian striker Rey Manaj also looked forlorn after failing to get a proper connection on a header. This has been a running theme for Sylvinho's side, who have lacked attacking fluency at points throughout his 18-month spell in charge.\n\nInjuries to Manaj and Armando Broja throughout the qualifying games meant neither striker built the sort of playing chemistry a team needs to be a potent counter-attacking side. The manager's decision to leave regulars Myrto Uzuni, Keidi Bare and Sokol Cikalleshi out of the 26-man squad for the tournament also caused a stir. Cikalleshi - a striker for Turkish club Konyaspor - was not the most prolific goalscorer, but his hold-up play gave Albania a valuable foothold in qualifying matches.\n\nYet this side finds a way to forge its own path through the tournament; one that frequently sees it roughing up bigger and more established football players. Mario Mandzukic - now an assistant coach with Croatia - could be seen leaping from the dugout to demand his players match Albania's intensity in the first half.\n\nIt took a handful of second-half changes for Croatia to swing the game's momentum in their favour. Marcelo Brozovic and Lovro Majer were replaced by Mario Pasalic and Luka Sucic at half-time. Twenty minutes later, striker Ante Budimir was introduced to give his team a better target for their crosses. Croatia grew in confidence. Their full-backs crept further and further up the field while the build-up patterns of Modric and Mateo Kovacic became more dangerous. Budimir teed up Andrej Kramaric for their equaliser in the 74th minute. Two minutes later, the duo teamed up for another. A cross intended for Luka Sucic pinballed in the penalty area before being turned in by Albania's defensive midfielder Klaus Gjasula.\n\nAlbania could have collapsed, but they somehow found a second wind. In Asllani, they have a midfielder who is composed when in possession, and nicely combative when out of it. The 22-year-old is fast emerging as Brozovic's eventual successor for the defensive midfield role at Inter Milan and was the heartbeat of his side.\n\n\"We have to fight for every point,\" was Sylvinho's post-match assessment of the game. \"For our country and for our federation.\"\n\nThe Brazilian often makes mention of sweat and respect in press conferences. Hard work is the bare minimum and the most important ingredient for this Albania side. They can be iffy in front of goal (Mirlind Daku was booked late in stoppage time when an attempted volley missed the ball and hit Josko Gvardiol in the side of the head), but what is most important to the manager, and the thousands of fans who travelled to Hamburg on Wednesday, is their ability to keep trying. That hard work eventually paid off deep in stoppage time, when Mitaj pulled back a wonderful low cross for Gjasula.\n\nThe time read 94 minutes and 23 seconds when Albania got their equaliser (the latest goal to be scored at a Euros outside of extra time). It was an equalising goal that felt like a last-minute winner. The noise in the Volksparkstadion was deafening. Gjasula - only the second player to score an own goal and a goal within the same game at the Euros - had given his side a slender chance of making it to the round of 16.\n\n\"This is Albania; it's a bit crazy,\" said Asllani after the 2-2 draw.\n\n\"We started off on the right foot, and then I can say I missed a big chance, but I thought Modric would get on the ball before me. I think we conceded two avoidable goals. We'll review them, surely. The game was crazy in the last 15 minutes.\"\n\nSylvinho's scrappers will need to be at their very best to get a result against Spain in their final group game, but they are a team that has never been afraid of hard work. Albania doesn't quit, and that makes them a difficult opponent at this tournament.", "source": {"uri": "nytimes.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The New York Times"}, "authors": [{"uri": their first matches.\n\nThe Albanians, who are ahead of Croatia on goal difference in the group standings, celebrated the most after the match, while Luka Modric and his teammates looked disappointed as they applauded the Croatian fans.\n\nThe Volksparkstadion in Hamburg was split evenly between red-clad Albania fans and spectators in Croatia's checkered shirt providing a loud and energetic atmosphere throughout the match.\n\nFans in Croatia's section set off flares repeatedly, despite warnings over the loudspeakers that it would result in disciplinary action.\n\nCroatia struggled to "sim": 0.6078431606292725, "url": "https://www.westmeathindependent.ie/2024/06/19/klaus-gjasula-goes-from-zero-to-hero-as-albania-snatch-late-draw-against-croatia/", "title": "Klaus Gjasula goes from zero to hero as Albania snatch late draw against Croatia | Westmeath Independent", "body": "Klaus Gjasula goes from zero to hero as Albania snatch late draw against Croatia RSS Syndicated Content Published: Wed 19 Jun 2024, 4:53 PM Last updated: Wed 19 Jun 2024, 5:10 PM\n\nBy PA Sport Staff\n\nKlaus Gjasula struck five minutes into stoppage time to rescue a 2-2 draw for Albania against Croatia in Hamburg and keep alive their hopes of reaching the Euro 2024 knockout stages.\n\nThe 2022 World Cup semi-finalists looked to have secured a fine comeback win after Andrej Kramaric scored in the 74th minute to cancel out Qazim Laci's early goal for Albania, then midfielder Gjasula inadvertently turned the ball past his own goalkeeper two minutes later.\n\nBut with time almost up, Albania attacked down the left and the ball was crossed to Gjasula who fired left footed into the corner to stun Croatia and set up a tense finale for Group B.\n\nAlbania took the lead after 10 minutes.\n\nJasir Asani collected the ball wide on the right midway inside the Croatia half and launched a reaching cross that was met with a glancing header by Laci, his effort squeezing through the hands of goalkeeper Dominik Livakovic and in at the near post.\n\nThe advantage was nearly doubled on the half-hour mark when Kristjan Asllani went through but was denied by a superb low stop from Livakovic, then on the stroke of half-time the goalkeeper was again called upon to keep out Rey Manaj's close-range header.\n\nCroatia began the second half with renewed urgency and should have levelled after 57 minutes when defender Josip Sutalo headed a near-post corner wide from two yards.\n\nThe equaliser finally arrived from Kramaric, the striker finding himself in space inside the penalty area from Ante Budimir's pass and striking the ball through the legs of Elseid Hysaj.\n\nAnd minutes later they led, Budimir's cutback was hit low at goal by Luka Sucic, his blocked effort rebounding into the net off the unfortunate Gjasula.\n\nThen, when all looked lost, Gjasula redeemed himself in dramatic fashion, left free near the penalty spot to sweep the ball into the corner to save Albania.\n\nRSS Syndicated Content Published: Wed 19 Jun 2024, 4:53 PM Last updated: Wed 19 Jun 2024, 5:10 PM", "source": {"uri": "westmeathindependent.ie", "dataType": "news", "title":
