{"uri": "8186029965", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "22:39:31", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T22:39:31Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T22:38:32Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5803921818733215, "url": "https://www.whittierdailynews.com/2024/06/19/euro-2024-germany-blanks-hungary-to-reach-knockout-stage/", "title": "Euro 2024: Germany blanks Hungary to reach knockout stage", "body": "STUTTGART, Germany -- Jamal Musiala is lighting up the European Championship and showing just why his teammates think the 21-year-old forward can go on to become one of the best players in the world.Musiala scored his second goal of the tournament on Wednesday to help Germany beat Hungary 2-0 and book its spot in the knockout stage.\n\n\"For me it's incredible to play with him, he can do the unexpected in every single situation,\" Germany captain \u0130lkay G\u00fcndo\u011fan said. \"Maybe he's the most important one at the moment for us and at such a young age as well.\n\n\"And, I love him. He's such a complete player and such a nice guy as well. Very humble. And if he keeps doing his thing, the way he's doing right now, he can be one of the best.\"\n\nMusiala opened the scoring in the 22nd minute with a goal that was furiously protested by Hungary.\n\nG\u00fcndo\u011fan had set that up and got on the scoresheet himself in the second half.\n\nMusiala had netted Germany's second goal in the 5-1 opening victory over Scotland on Friday to kick off Euro 2024. Hungary lost 3-1 to Switzerland on Saturday and now faces an uphill challenge to advance.\n\n\"He did brilliant in both games,\" Germany coach Julian Nagelsmann said. \"Not only the two goals, I think every situation or offensive proposition is pretty tough for the opponent to defend.\n\n\"I think it's important for him not to deal with the pressure, just to deal with his capability to solve any offensive one-on-one situations ... He should not think about the pressure, because he's brilliant in just playing soccer.\"\n\nHungary plays Scotland in the final Group A match on Sunday, when Nagelsmann's team takes on Switzerland.\n\nHungary was unbeaten in its previous three matches against Germany and it put up a good fight against the host nation in Stuttgart.\n\nCoach Marco Rossi said his players paid the price for what he felt was unbalanced refereeing.\n\n\"Throughout my career, first as player and then as coach, I have never looked for alibis,\" Rossi said. \"But what the referee did tonight ... I think even the Germans saw that he used two different measurements.\"Germany would have still won, it's stronger and it would have won, but the referee was the worst on the field.\"\n\nRossi's side started aggressively and stunned Germany by almost taking the lead inside 20 seconds.\n\nGoalkeeper Manuel Neuer had to be quick off his line to slide to the ball to stop Roland Sallai.\n\nThe noise level ramped up every time Musiala had the ball and the Stuttgart-born forward opened the scoring in chaotic fashion.\n\nMusiala tried to set up G\u00fcndo\u011fan but Hungary defender Willi Orb\u00e1n got to the ball first. However, he stumbled -- following what Hungary protested was a shove by G\u00fcndo\u011fan -- and as shotstopper P\u00e9ter Gul\u00e1csi tried to help him, G\u00fcndo\u011fan poked it on to Musiala, who smashed it into the net with the goalkeeper still on the ground.\n\n\"I was quite surprised that the Hungarian player and his teammates were angry about it,\" G\u00fcndo\u011fan said. \"I played in the Premier League for seven years and if you gave that in the Premier League as a foul I think everyone would have been laughing on the floor.\"\n\nHungary almost leveled immediately but Neuer did brilliantly to parry Dominik Szoboszlai's free kick and then keep out a follow-up with his foot. The crowd celebrated the save almost as loudly as it had done the goal.\n\nThe loud home fans thought Musiala had doubled his tally at the end of the half but his shot was deflected, hitting the side netting and making it ripple so that even Nagelsmann appeared to think it had gone in.\n\nGermany was seemingly in control in the second half and did get a second in the 68th minute when Maximilian Mittelst\u00e4dt rolled the ball across from the left and G\u00fcndo\u011fan drove it into the bottom right corner.\n\nAlbania substitute Klaus Gjasula had the rare experience of scoring for both teams Wednesday in an intense 2-2 draw with Croatia in Hamburg, Germany, that could make it difficult for each to survive the group stage at Euro 2024.\n\nThe Croatian players were particularly disappointed with the result in Hamburg after Gjasula's stoppage-time goal denied them a much-needed win after they lost 3-0 to Spain in their opening Group B match.\n\n\"My first minutes on the pitch were very, very difficult for me not only for the own goal but also other situations,\" Gjasula said. \"Then God wanted and gave me the opportunity to score. A very beautiful, historic day for me.\"\n\nIn the first-ever competitive match between the two Balkan teams, Croatia tried to set the pace from the start, but it was Albania's Qazim Laci who scored first, heading in a cross from the right flank in the 11th minute.\n\nAndrej Kramaric equalized in the 74th minute before Gjasula's own goal made it 2-1 for Croatia just two minutes later.\n\nAt that point, Croatia looked in control but a late surge by Albania changed everything once again as Gjasula redeemed himself by scoring with a low shot in the 95th minute.\n\nIt was a thrilling end-to-match that leaves both Croatia and Albania in a precarious situation in the group. Albania lost to defending champion Italy 2-1 in its first match.\n\nThe third-place Albanians, who are ahead of Croatia on goal difference, celebrated the most after the match, while Luka Modric and his teammates -- semifinalists at the 2022 World Cup -- looked disappointed as they applauded the Croatian fans.\n\n\"We would have been a lot happier if we hadn't conceded the last goal. The situation would have been totally different,\" Kramaric said. \"We turned the match, and we should have won. But that's football.\"\n\nThe Volksparkstadion in Hamburg was split evenly between red-clad Albania fans and spectators in Croatia's checkered shirt providing a loud and energetic atmosphere.\n\nFans in Croatia's section set off flares repeatedly, despite warnings over the loudspeakers that it would result in disciplinary action.\n\nCroatia struggled to create chances in the first half and could have faced a greater deficit but goalkeeper\n\nDominik Livakovic blocked a shot from Kristjan Asllani and a header from Rey Manaj to keep it 1-0 at halftime.\n\nThe Croatians came out with more energy after the break and turned the match around in two minutes.\n\nKramaric equalized with a shot just inside the post. And just moments later Gjasula was unlucky when Albania tried to clear the ball from the penalty area but it bounced off him and into the net for the fourth own goal of the tournament.\n\nAlbania coach Sylvinho said he was proud of his team's performance. Albania is playing only its second European Championship and was considered unlikely to advance out of the group.\n\n\"It was amazing. I will remember this game all my life,\" he said.\n\nXherdan Shaqiri's stunning first-half strike secured a 1-1 draw for Switzerland against Scotland at Euro 2024 on Wednesday in Cologne, Germany.\n\nThe 32-year-old Chicago Fire forward rolled back the years with a first-time curling effort from about 20 meters out at Cologne Stadium.\n\nScotland had led from the 13th minute when Scott McTominay's shot took a wicked deflection off Fabian Schar to beat Switzerland goalkeeper Yann Sommer.\n\nBut Shaqiri pounced on Anthony Ralston's loose pass in the 26th to even the match.\n\nThe draw leaves Switzerland second in Group B on four points and likely to advance to the round of 16, while Scotland's hopes of making the knockout round depend on its final game against Hungary on Sunday and results elsewhere.\n\nBoth teams had chances to win the game.\n\nThe Swiss should have taken the lead just before the hour mark when Dan Ndoye turned Kieran Tierney on the edge of the box. With just goalkeeper Angus Gunn to beat, Ndoye fired wide of goal.\n\nGrant Hanley then headed against the post from a Scotland free kick and Switzerland's Zeki Amdouni headed wide at the far post late on.\n\nScotland has never advanced beyond the group stage of a World Cup or Euros on 11 previous attempts.\n\nBut repeated disappointment doesn't seem to dampen optimism among its fans, who filled Cologne's square before the game.\n\nSwiss fans were out in numbers, too, creating a raucous atmosphere in the stadium.\n\nThe Scots were the first ones cheering when Schar stuck out a boot to try to block McTominay's effort, but diverted it into his own net.\n\nThe lead didn't last long as Ralston was guilty of a wayward pass at the back. Even then, it took a moment of brilliance from Shaqiri to sweep a left-footed shot into the top corner and past Gunn.\n\nIt was the sixth straight major international tournament in which Shaqiri has as Qazim Laci burst through the middle and headed home from six yards.\n\nHowever, an inspired second half performance from Zlatko Dalic's Croatia saw them turn it around with two goals in three minutes.\n\nThat looked to be enough to win it, until a dramatic 95th minute equaliser ensured a share of the spoils.\n\nEuro 2024 | Group stage guide\n\nStriker Andre Kramaric netted the equaliser in the 74th minute before an unfortunate Klaus Gjasula own goal two minutes later, following a move started by Gvardiol, completed the turnaround.\n\nGjasula made amends though, sliding the ball home with just seconds left on the clock to earn an historic point for his country.\n\nHaving played as a marauding left-back in Croatia's opening defeat to Spain, Gvardiol was at the heart of the defence for this game.\n\nThat didn't deter the 22-year-old from stepping out from the back with the ball at his feet, confidently getting numerous attacks under way and completing a total of 60 passes.\n\nHe {"uri": "8185622597", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "16:13:41", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T16:13:41Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T16:07:08Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5607843399047852, "url": "https://www.dailymail.co.uk/wires/reuters/article-13547621/Soccer-Reaction-2-2-draw-Croatia-Albania-Euro-2024.html", "title": "Soccer-Reaction to the 2-2 draw between Croatia and Albania at Euro...", "body": "HAMBURG, Germany, June 19 (Reuters) - The following is reaction to the 2-2 draw between Croatia and Albania in Euro 2024 Group B on Wednesday.\n\nAlbania manager Sylvinho: \"I am very happy with the team, I think we have deserved (the result). We played with heart. We fought with heart and it is exactly what represents this nation.\n\n\"This point will serve this team for the rest of their life. We are a young national team, this is only the second time being in this competition, we have to enter the pitch and use every moment to fight with heart and to take lessons from Euro.\n\n\"This is a game that I will remember all my life.\"\n\nCroatia coach Zlatko Dalic: \"This was a difficult match, with two totally different halves. A lot of energy was invested to lead 2-1 and then we get goal in added time. It is difficult to get a goal in the last minute.\n\n\"The first half was very bad and the second much better, which is encouraging for the match with Italy, the victory over Italy will take us further. We are still in game, we shall prepare and do all in our power to go on.\"\n\nCroatia's Andrej Kramaric, player of the match: \"In the first half, we couldn't create anything. In the second half, of course it was a different image. We were much more aggressive, dominant.\n\n\"What I want to say is that this is football, this is why everyone loves football. In the last seconds, sometimes you score a goal to win, sometimes you concede, unfortunately that is what happened to us.\"\n\nAlbanian midfielder Qazim Laci who opened the scoring in the 11th minute: \"This result will give us a confidence to move forward, to believe in ourselves.\n\n\"The game with Spain will be more difficult but we will give the maximum to have a victory.\"\n\nAlbanian midfielder Klaus Gjasula, whose own goal put Croatia ahead before he netted the added time equaliser: \"2-2 is okay. With a little luck we could had scored the third one also.\n\n\"We know that the game with Spain is very difficult but in football everything is possible. If we will play like today everything can happen.\"\n\nLuka Sucic, Croatian midfielder: \"The disappointment is huge, something like this must not happen to a team like us, we were leading and should have ended this calmly, but this is a lesson to learn.\n\n\"The second half was better, it is a direction how to start against the Italians. It should have been a moment for Albania to fear and retreat, but they stepped forward and intercepted Modric's rather feeble through ball attempt. Seconds later, Kristjan Asllani was in on goal, only to be denied by Dominik Livakovic.\n\nIt was a moment that summed up not only the pattern of the first half, but Modric and Croatia's struggles to control Albania. Alongside Mateo Kovacic and Marcelo Brozovic, possession was always likely to come easily, but not only did Croatia struggle to muster inspiration after going a goal behind, but they failed to stop a string of good chances being created from similar avenues before half time.\n\nUltimately, that lack of control cost them in the end, conceding a late equaliser after taking a 2-1 lead in the second half. Now it looks like a tall order to qualify; they need to beat Italy, but on this showing and that against Spain, they do not have the energy.\n\nThrough long balls over the top or central through balls, Albania should have been out of sight; Qazim Laci opened the scoring with a header on 11 minutes, Asllani failed to double the lead before Rey Manej's header was thwarted by another Livakovic save.\n\nEverything was coming through the same structure for Sylvinho's side, who had clearly learnt a lot from their opening defeat to Italy.\n\nThey countered using their pace and power to overwhelm Croatia and Modric in particular. What has looked effortless and second nature for 15 years - control, dictation, tempo setting - suddenly looked a challenge for the Real Madrid man. If they are knocked out, it may take a while to recover and go again.\n\nEventually, we can look back and marvel at the sheer relentlessness of Luka Modric's quality. {"uri": "8185544552", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "15:12:22", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T15:12:22Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T15:11:22Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5529412031173706, "url": "https://www.cbssports.com/soccer/news/uefa-euro-2024-scores-results-highlights-standings-albania-hold-sluggish-croatia-to-draw-on-day-6/", "title": "UEFA Euro 2024 scores, results, highlights, standings: Albania hold sluggish Croatia to draw on Day 6 - CBSSports.com", "body": "Klaus Gjasula's redemption act rescues Kuqezinjte a draw in Hamburg after Vatreni comeback Getty Images\n\nAn international soccer tournament would not feel complete without Croatia flirting with disaster before heroically pulling a result out of the fire -- or at least thinking that they have. UEFA Euro 2024 now has that after Zlatko Dalic's men recovered after conceding early to lead Albania 2-1 only to be pegged back late on. Qazim Laci looked to have given Sylvinho's Kuqezinjt\u00eb a narrow win at Volksparkstadion in Hamburg before a late two-minute blitz from Andrej Kramaric and then a Klaus Gajsula own goal turned things Vatreni's way. However, there was still time for drama as Gjasula equalized for Albania deep into injury time and received a late booking in a big Group B result.\n\nHosts Germany vs. Hungary and then Scotland vs. Switzerland are still to come this Wednesday, here's everything you need to know so far from day six in Germany.\n\nEuro 2024 scores for MondayCroatia 2, Albania 2Germany vs. Hungary at 12 p.m. ETScotland vs. Switzerland at 3 p.m. ETCroatia 2, Albania 2: Gjasula goes from villain to hero\n\nCroatia have become synonymous over the years for their dramatic and occasionally fortunate ways of avoiding defeat at international tournaments. Vatreni regularly rely on extra time and penalties when on deep runs such as their FIFA 2018 World Cup final journey in Russia. Obviously, there are no games going beyond the regulation 90 minutes plus extra time in the group stage of UEFA Euro 2024, yet Zlatko Dalic's men found a way to play with fire regardless.\n\nQazim Laci was allowed to head home after just 11 minutes in Hamburg and until the final quarter of an hour, it looked as if it might be enough for Sylvinho's side who were unlucky to lose out narrowly to Italy in their opening game. We have to go for the win against Italy,\" coach Zlatko Dalic said after his side's 2-2 draw in Hamburg left them with one point and bottom of Group B on goal difference.\n\nAgainst Albania, ranked 56 places lower, they were shocked by an early goal and did not recover until the second half when they flooded forward and scored twice in quick succession - before Klaus Gjasula snatched a stoppage-time equaliser.\n\n\"First half we played badly. We were very slow. In the second half we played a lot better, a lot more decisive,\" added Dalic.\n\n\"We gave our all to get to 2-1 and for 45 minutes our opponent couldn\u00b4t pass the half-way line, and then in extra time we allowed them to come at us and we conceded this goal.\"\n\nDIFFICULT STORY\n\nDalic, whose team lost their opening game 3-0 to Spain, said he had not expected the tournament to be so hard for Croatia but noted other teams with big pedigree had struggled too.\n\n\"We didn\u00b4t expect to have such a difficult story in these two matches, it has been a struggle,\" he said.\n\n\"The World Cup was two years ago and slowly our players are getting older, and this whole tournament has shown us that everyone is having a hard time ... It is very open and the teams are pretty equal.\"\n\nHis players acknowledged they must improve.\n\n\"The disappointment is huge. Something like this must not happen to a team like us. We were leading and should have ended this calmly, but this is a lesson to learn,\" midfielder Luka Sucic said.\n\n\"The second half was better, it shows how to start against Italy ... If we play like in the second half we will surely get through this group.\"\n\nMan of the match Andrej Kramaric, who scored Croatia's first goal, was philosophical.\n\n\"This is why everyone loves football. In the last seconds, sometimes you score a winner, sometimes you concede, unfortunately that is what happened to us,\" he said.\n\n\"We should have won. But that\u00b4s football. Croatia can't do anything the easy way. Everything is still open. We are well aware we are playing against a top team Italy. In a punchy press conference, Dalic said he is fed up of his team being patronised and took aim at those writing off his side after a difficult start in Germany. Croatia, whose base is in Neuruppin, an hour northwest of Berlin, lost their opening Group B match 3-0 to Spain.\n\n\"It wasn't a pretty sight, it wasn't great to watch, we didn't get a great feeling,\" Dalic said of the defeat, before airing his frustrations. \"But we are always the dark horse, we are always not among the favourites, nobody believes in us but in the past six years we have won three medals. After France, our national team is the first team to have done this so I always keep saying that Croatia deserves greater respect from everyone else for what we have managed to do.\n\n\"We have won three medals, England won one [more than] 50 years ago but they are a great team, we are not, we are always the dark horse. We are little but we are brave, we will fight and we have the evidence of thousands of Croats in Berlin. We are a nation that is entitled to feel proud and our results show that we are better than our perception.\n\n\"I know after this defeat [to Spain] there is a lot of pessimism and negativity but we will give our best and we are doing the best to be the best we can. Everything we have done in the past six, seven years, we have to look at that and feel proud. Croatia is much better than is said and seen in the public.\"\n\nCroatia were runners-up at the World Cup in Russia in 2018, third in Qatar in 2022 and Nations League runners-up last year. England, who won the World Cup in 1966, were runners-up at the delayed Euro 2020 and finished third in the Nations League in 2019.\n\nThe forward Bruno Petkovic, a substitute against Spain, is in line {"uri": "8185692789", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "17:03:02", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T17:03:02Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T17:02:06Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5333333611488342, "url": "https://www.thestar.com.my/sport/football/2024/06/20/soccer-sore-at-lost-points-croatia-gun-for-italy", "title": "Soccer-Sore at lost points, Croatia gun for Italy", "body": "HAMBURG, Germany (Reuters) - Disappointed at squandering a lead to Albania in the dying seconds of a pulsating Euro 2024 match, Croatia's focus turned straight to beating Italy in their final group game to secure a place in the knockout stages.\n\nCroatia reached the World Cup final in 2018 and the semi-finals in Qatar two years ago, but are again struggling to reproduce that form at the European Championship despite boasting such talents as Luka Modric and Josko Gvardiol.\n\n\"The most important thing is that we're still alive. We have to go for the win against Italy,\" coach Zlatko Dalic said after his side's 2-2 draw in Hamburg left them with one point and bottom of Group B on goal difference.\n\nAgainst Albania, ranked 56 places lower, they were shocked by an early goal and did not recover until the second half when they flooded forward and scored twice in quick succession - before Klaus Gjasula snatched a stoppage-time equaliser.\n\n\"First half we played badly. We were very slow. In the second half we played a lot better, a lot more decisive,\" added Dalic.\n\n\"We gave our all to get to 2-1 and for 45 minutes our opponent couldn't pass the half-way line, and then in extra time we allowed them to come at us and we conceded this goal.\"\n\nDIFFICULT STORY\n\nDalic, whose team lost their opening game 3-0 to Spain, said he had not expected the tournament to be so hard for Croatia but noted other teams with big pedigree had struggled too.\n\n\"We didn't expect to have such a difficult story in these two matches, it has been a struggle,\" he said.\n\n\"The World Cup was two years ago and slowly our players are getting older, and this whole tournament has shown us that everyone is having a hard time ... It is very open and the teams are pretty equal.\"\n\nHis players acknowledged they must improve.\n\n\"The disappointment is huge. Something like this must not happen to a team like us. We were leading and should have ended this calmly, but this is a lesson to learn,\" midfielder Luka Sucic said.\n\n\"The second half was better, it shows how to start against Italy ... If we play like in the second half we will surely get through this group.\"\n\nMan of the match Andrej Kramaric, who scored Croatia's first goal, was philosophical.\n\n\"This is why everyone loves football. In the last seconds, sometimes you score a winner, sometimes you concede, unfortunately that is what happened to us,\" he said.\n\n\"We should have won. But that's football. Croatia can't do anything the easy way. Everything is still open. We are well aware we are playing against a top team Italy. We have to win, we have to give our all.\"\n\n(Reporting by Andrew Cawthorne and Daria Sito-Sucic, Editing by Ed Osmond)", "source": {"uri": "thestar.com.my", "dataType": "news", "title": "The Star slowly and struggled to create chances - with captain and talisman Luka Modric certainly not immune.\n\nThey were indebted to Livakovic for two huge saves to keep the scoreline at 1-0 at the break, We shouldn't have allowed the opponent to come onto us.\n\n\"This added time was really bad, there was a struggle without any need to play like that.\"\n\nCroatia will now probably have to beat holders Italy in their final Group B match on June 24 to progress to the knockout phase for a fifth straight major tournament, after suffering an opening 3-0 loss to Spain last week.\n\nCroatia have enjoyed an unprecedented spell of success since a surprise run to the World Cup final in 2018, when they lost to France.\n\nThere are fears the Euros in Germany could be the end of an era for a team including 38-year-old Luka Modric, 35-year-old Ivan Perisic and Andrej Kramaric, who marked his 33rd birthday on Wednesday with a goal.\n\n\"This is a different tournament, a different story,\" said Dalic.\n\n\"We didn't expect to have such a difficult story in these two matches so it's been a struggle.\n\n\"Maybe that's the way to get out of it even better. We have two difficult matches. It's not over, keep your heads up. Our goal is to advance from the group and we will do our best to achieve that,\" Dalic said of a game Croatian media have billed as do-or-die.\n\n\"Everything is still in our hands, still under our control. We need to be better... It's up to me to turn things around, point out the flaws and not dwell too much on the Spain match.\"\n\nDespite being viewed as minnows, Albania topped their qualifying group over teams such as the Czech Republic and Poland and are not at the tournament to make up the numbers.\n\nTheir Brazilian coach Sylvinho will try to keep his team disciplined before hitting Croatia on the break -- as they did against Italy with a goal after 23 seconds and so nearly again at the end when they narrowly failed to equalise.\n\n\"I have seen other sides in this tournament. {"uri": "8184262762", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-18", "time": "20:53:16", "dateTime": "2024-06-18T20:53:16Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-18T20:52:52Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5098039507865906, "url": "https://www.irishexaminer.com/sport/soccer/arid-41419204.html", "title": "Croatia's Dalic has a pop at England and says his team deserves more respect", "body": "Dalic delved into the history books and brought up England's record to emphasise his side's credentials before Croatia face Albania in Hamburg on Wednesday. In a punchy press conference, Dalic said he is fed up of his team being patronised and took aim at those writing off his side after a difficult start in Germany.\n\nCroatia, whose base is in Neuruppin, an hour northwest of Berlin, lost their opening Group B match 3-0 to Spain.\n\n\"It wasn't a pretty sight, it wasn't great to watch, we didn't get a great feeling,\" Dalic said of the defeat, before airing his frustrations.\n\n\"But we are always the dark horse, we are always not among the favourites, nobody believes in us but in the past six years we have won three medals.\n\n\"After France, our national team is the first team to have done this so I always keep saying that Croatia deserves greater respect from everyone else for what we have managed to do.\n\n\"We have won three medals, England won one [more than] 50 years ago but they are a great team, we are not, we are always the dark horse. We are little but we are brave, we will fight and we have the evidence of thousands of Croats in Berlin. We are a nation that is entitled to feel proud and our results show that we are better than our perception.\n\n\"I know after this defeat [to Spain] there is a lot of pessimism and negativity but we will give our best and we are doing the best to be the best we can. Everything we have done in the past six, seven years, we have to look at that and feel proud. Croatia is much better than is said and seen in the public.\"\n\nCroatia were runners-up at the World Cup in Russia in 2018, third in Qatar in 2022 and Nations League runners-up last year. England, who won the World Cup in 1966, were runners-up at the delayed Euro 2020 and finished third in the Nations League in 2019.\n\nThe forward Bruno Petkovic, a substitute against Spain, is in line {"uri": "8184854989", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "07:35:31", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T07:35:31Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T07:34:41Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5058823823928833, "url": "https://www.mirror.co.uk/sport/football/news/croatia-england-dalic-respect-euro-33060081", "title": "England brutally mocked by rival Euro 2024 manager who demands 'more respect'", "body": "Zlatko Dalic had a dig at England after feeling aggrieved by the media's presentation of his side as dark horses\n\nCroatia manager Zlatko Dalic has hit back at critics who have labelled his side as \"dark horses\" at this summer's Euros - and even aimed a swipe at England.\n\nDalic's side slumped to a 3-0 loss to Spain in their opening group stage game over the weekend, with all three goals arriving in the first-half of a match marked by a lack of incision and clinical edge from Croatia.\n\nThe result leaves Croatia bottom of Group B on zero points, behind Albania, whom they face on Wednesday.\n\nAnd in a spiky pre-match press conference Dalic embarked on a fervid defence of his side's credentials, criticising those he perceived as baselessly writing off Croatia after their Spain performance, while also digging out England's track record at major tournaments under Gareth Southgate as a means of comparison.\n\n\"It wasn't a pretty sight, it wasn't great to watch, we didn't get a great feeling,\" Dalic said of the defeat to Spain.\n\n\"But we are always the dark horse, we are always not among the favourites, nobody believes in us but in the past six years we have won three medals. After France, our national team is the first team to have done this so I always keep saying that Croatia deserves greater respect from everyone else for what we have managed to do.\n\n\"We have won three medals, England won one [more than] 50 years ago but they are a great team, we are not, we are always the dark horse. We are little but we are brave, we will fight and we have the evidence of thousands of Croats in Berlin. We are a nation that is entitled to feel proud and our results show that we are better than our perception.\"\n\nDalic added: \"I know after this defeat [against Spain] there is a lot of pessimism and negativity but we will give our best and we are doing the best to be the best we can. Everything we have done in the past six, seven years, we have to look at that and feel proud. Croatia is much better than is said and seen in the public.\"\n\nCroatia finished runners-up at the 2018 World Cup in Russia, before finishing third in Qatar and runners-up in the Nations League last year. In the two previous European championships, they were knocked out of the Last 16 by Portugal and Spain respectively.\n\nEngland, who won the World Cup in 1966, were runners-up at the delayed Euro 2020 and finished third in the 2019 Nations League. They lost the third-place match against Belgium at the 2018 World Cup and were knocked out of the quarter-finals by France in Qatar.\n\nAgainst Albania, Dalic is expected to switch up his starting XI, specifically in midfield. Albania - who made history in their 2-1 defeat to holders Italy with the fastest-ever European Championship goal - are competing in only their second major finals, after a group-stage exit from Euro 2016 when they claimed a memorable win over Romania.\n\nAnd Dalic is not underestimating the difficulty of Wednesday's match. \"We have to be and feel alive until the end of the match,\" he said. \"We cannot lose our heads and try to force things, but with our quality and our own play, do what we've envisaged because tomorrow we'll go for victory and three points, but patience will be the key tomorrow.\"\n\nJoin our new WhatsApp community and receive your daily dose of Mirror Football content. {"uri": "8184891562", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "08:02:06", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T08:02:06Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T08:01:38Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5058823823928833, "url": "https://www.standardmedia.co.ke/sports/sports/article/2001497443/croatia-hope-to-avoid-shameful-end-for-golden-generation", "title": "Croatia hope to avoid shameful end for golden generation", "body": "Croatia will be aiming to get their Euro 2024 campaign back on track against Albania on Wednesday, with their 'golden generation' in danger of a disappointing farewell from the top level following a humbling loss to Spain.\n\nAlthough World Cup semi-finalists in 1998, Croatia have enjoyed an unprecedented spell of success since reaching the 2018 World Cup final in Russia, where they lost to France.\n\nZlatko Dalic's men are bidding to reach the knockout phase for a fifth consecutive major tournament in Germany, but there are fears this could be the end of an era.\n\nCaptain and star player Luka Modric is 38, winger Ivan Perisic is 35 and midfielders Marcelo Brozovic and Mateo Kovacic, as well as forward Andrej Kramaric, are all in their 30s.\n\nFormer lynchpins of the national team, including Mario Mandzukic, Ivan Rakitic and Dejan Lovren, have already retired from international football.\n\nThe average age of the 15 players who featured in a demoralising 3-0 loss to Spain in Croatia's opener was 28.5 years old.\n\nBut coach Dalic insists that defeat was far from a fatal blow -after Albania in Hamburg, they face holders Italy in their last Group B clash in Leipzig on June 24.\n\nCroatia finished third at the 2022 World Cup in Qatar and lost to Spain in the Nations League final only last year.\n\n\"There is no room for pessimism, everything is still in our hands,\" Dalic said. \"Of course, we have to be better. It's my job to turn the team around.\"\n\nRumours of a rift in the camp after Perisic allowed Bruno Petkovic to take a late penalty, which was saved by Spain goalkeeper Unai Simon, have been played down despite Dalic publicly criticising his striker.\n\n\"I think that situation is over. The coach said everything on that topic,\" winger Lovro Majer said on Monday.\n\n\"Bruno took the penalty, unfortunately he didn't score, it can happen to anyone. It's a finished story and there's no need to add anything special.\"\n\nDalic is expected to opt for a switch in formation, potentially breaking up the midfield trio of Modric, Kovacic and Brozovic.\n\nFormer Inter Milan player Brozovic has increasingly looked off the pace for Croatia since his move to Saudi club Al-Nassr last year.\n\nCroatia did create chances against Spain and were starting to look the more dangerous of the two teams when one through ball from Fabian Ruiz split them open and sent Alvaro Morata in on goal to score the first goal.\n\n\"I don't think it looked as bad as the result suggested,\" said Majer.\n\n\"It's football, sometimes you concede and you don't score, but it didn't look so terrible.\"\n\nCroatia have experience of recovering from similar {"uri": "8186002320", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "22:04:19", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T22:04:19Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T22:03:41Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4862745106220245, "url": "https://www.abc.net.au/news/2024-06-20/euro-2024-five-quick-hits-ahead-of-england-denmark/104000714", "title": "Swiss star's one-touch stunner, Albanian scores for both teams, and royals set to turn out for England", "body": "The groups are starting to figure themselves out at Euro 2024 as the competition gets into full swing in Germany.\n\nHere are the five quick hits from the Wednesday night and Thursday morning action that you might have missed.\n\nJamal Musiala is lighting up the European Championship and showing just why his teammates think the 21-year-old forward can go on to become one of the best players in the world.\n\nMusiala scored his second goal of the tournament overnight to help Germany beat Hungary 2-0 and book its spot in the knockout stage.\n\n\"For me, it's incredible to play with him, he can do the unexpected in every single situation,\" Germany captain \u0130lkay G\u00fcndo\u011fan said.\n\n\"Maybe he's the most important one at the moment for us and at such a young age as well.\n\n\"And, I love him. He's such a complete player and such a nice guy as well. Very humble. And if he keeps doing his thing, the way he's doing right now, he can be one of the best.\"\n\nMusiala opened the scoring in the 22nd minute with a goal that was furiously protested by Hungary. G\u00fcndo\u011fan had set that up and got on the scoresheet himself in the second half.\n\nMusiala had netted Germany's second goal in the 5-1 opening victory over Scotland on Friday to kick off Euro 2024. Hungary lost 3-1 to Switzerland on Saturday and now faces an uphill challenge to advance.\n\n\"He did brilliant in both games,\" Germany coach Julian Nagelsmann said.\n\n\"Not only the two goals, I think every situation or offensive proposition is pretty tough for the opponent to defend.\n\n\"I think it's important for him not to deal with the pressure, just to deal with his capability to solve any offensive one-on-one situations ... He should not think about the pressure, because he's brilliant in just playing soccer.\"\n\nXherdan Shaqiri's stunning first-half strike secured a 1-1 draw for Switzerland against Scotland on Wednesday.\n\nThe 32-year-old Chicago Fire forward rolled back the years with a first-time curling effort from about 20 meters out at Cologne Stadium.\n\nScotland had led from the 13th minute when Scott McTominay's shot took a wicked deflection off Fabian Sch\u00e4r to beat Switzerland goalkeeper Yann Sommer.\n\nBut Shaqiri pounced on Anthony Ralston's loose pass in the 26th to even the match.\n\nThe draw leaves Switzerland second in Group B on four points, while Scotland's hopes of advancing to the round of 16 depend on the result of its final game against Hungary on Sunday.\n\nAlbania substitute Klaus Gjasula had the rare experience of scoring for both teams in an intense 2-2 draw with Croatia that could make it difficult for each to survive the group stage at Euro 2024.\n\nThe Croatian players were particularly disappointed with the result in Hamburg after Gjasula's stoppage-time goal denied them a much-needed win after they lost 3-0 to Spain in their opening Group B match.\n\n\"My first minutes on the pitch were very, very difficult for me not only for the own goal but also other situations,\" Gjasula said.\n\n\"Then God wanted and gave me the opportunity to score. A very beautiful, historic day for me.\"\n\nIn the first-ever competitive match between the two Balkan teams, Croatia tried to set the pace from the start, but it was Albania's Qazim Laci who scored first, heading in a cross from the right flank in the 11th minute.\n\nAndrej Kramari\u0107 equalised in the 74th minute before Gjasula's own goal made it 2-1 for Croatia just two minutes later.\n\nAt that point, Croatia looked in control but a late surge by Albania changed everything once again as Gjasula redeemed himself by scoring with a low shot in the 95th minute.\n\nIt was a thrilling end-to-match that left both Croatia and Albania in a precarious situation in the group. Albania lost to defending champion Italy 2-1 in its first match.\n\nUEFA fined the Albanian and Serbian soccer federations 10,000 euros ($16,270) each on Wednesday for fans displaying banners with nationalist maps at European Championship games.\n\nEach federation was charged with \"transmitting provocative messages not fit for a sports event\" because they are responsible for the conduct of their fans at stadiums.\n\nAlbania fans displayed a banner with a map of their country extending its borders into the territory of neighbouring countries. It was shown during the 2-1 loss against Italy on Saturday in Dortmund.\n\nSerbia fans' banner included the independent territory of Kosovo and the slogan \"No Surrender\" at a 1-0 loss against England in Gelsenkirchen. A case was prosecuted by FIFA at the 2022 World Cup when players were photographed with a similar banner in their locker room ahead of a game against Brazil.\n\nUEFA also opened a separate investigation into alleged discrimination by Serbia fans. The Kosovo soccer federation filed a formal complaint with UEFA.\n\nThe Albanian federation was fined a further $44,000 for fans lighting flares and fireworks, throwing beer cups and a fan who went on the field.\n\nTwo kings and a prince are set to watch the soccer aristocrats playing on the field at European Championship games.\n\nKing Frederik X of Denmark and the first in line to the British throne, Prince William, will be together in the VVIP seats when their national teams meet in Frankfurt.\n\n\"It's a big honour. I'm a big fan of the Danish royal family,\" Denmark goalkeeper Kasper Schmeichel said on Wednesday.\n\nSchmeichel previously met Prince William at the FA Cup final in May 2021, when the future king also presented him with the trophy as captain of the winning Leicester team against Chelsea at Wembley Stadium.\n\nKing Felipe VI of Spain is due to attend the later game when his national team plays Italy in Gelsenkirchen.\n\nUEFA confirmed the scheduled royal visits to the month-long tournament in Germany.\n\nPrince William is the longtime president of the English Football Association and a fan of Premier League team Aston Villa, which has two players in the England squad at Euro 2024.\n\nKing Frederik, who became monarch in January on the abdication of his mother Queen Margrethe II, is a A powerful run down the left from substitute Mario Pasalic led to a cut back and a hurried shot. Albania's goal had led a charmed life for some time but their fortune ran out as a ricochet off Klaus Gjasula flew into the net, leaving goalkeeper Thomas Strakosha helpless.\n\nBoth goals were crucial for Croatia, who despite their second-half dominance had looked in real danger of falling to an ignominious defeat against one of the lowest ranked teams in the tournament.\n\nBut the drama did not end there. In added time, Gjasula made amends for his own goal, latching onto a cross and finishing coolly to send the Albanian fans into raptures.\n\nLike in their opening game against Italy, Sylvinho's side were unable to hold onto their narrow lead, despite some resilient defending for long periods. This time, though, they rallied themselves after conceding twice and earned a deserved draw in a finale that left the commentators breathless.\n\nCroatia's players were visibly dejected at full time. I always say we deserve more respect, England won (1966 World Cup) 50 years ago and they're a 'great team', but we're the dark horse.\n\n\"We have the results to show we're better than perceived. After this defeat there's a more negative outlook, but we're looking forward to the next match.\"\n\nDalic said there would be changes to his starting XI.\n\nCroatian media reports have suggested he will break up his midfield trio of Luka Modric, Mateo Kovacic and Marcelo Brozovic, with the latter expected to miss out.\n\nAlbania showed in their opening 2-1 defeat by holders Italy -- when they scored the fastest ever European Championship goal -- that they will not be pushovers in a tough group.\n\n\"We have to be and feel alive until the end of the match,\" added Dalic.\n\n\"We cannot lose our heads and try to force things, but with our quality and our own play, do what we've envisaged because tomorrow we'll go for victory and three points, but patience will be the key tomorrow.\"\n\nAlbania are playing in only their second major finals, after a group-stage exit from Euro 2016 when they claimed a memorable win over Romania.\n\nHead coach Sylvinho is still hopeful his men can pull off an even bigger shock in Germany.\n\n\"There's a beautiful path ahead of us,\" said the former Brazil left-back.\n\n\"I think we played quite a good match (against Italy). We didn't collapse, we were there until the very end and we had the chance to equalise and that's good...\n\n\"This is a very tough group, definitely, but I believe it can be true joy for us, because we're here playing against the best teams and we can learn from them.\n\n\"We'll give it our best shot. {"uri": "8183996929", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-18", "time": "16:58:15", "dateTime": "2024-06-18T16:58:15Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-18T16:57:02Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.47843137383461, "url": "https://www.thestar.com.my/sport/football/2024/06/19/soccer-albania-relish-facing-big-guns-eye-croatia-next", "title": "Soccer-Albania relish facing big guns, eye Croatia next", "body": "HAMBURG, Germany (Reuters) - Far from lamenting their luck in a fearsome Euro 2024 group, unfancied Albania are savouring the opportunity to take on Europe's top sides with Croatia next up on Wednesday.\n\n\"It's a true joy to be here. We're playing against the best teams and learning from them,\" said their coach Sylvinho, declaring his team 100% fit for the game in Hamburg.\n\n\"These teams that have players from Manchester City, Real Madrid, Inter Milan, they have a very high technical level, it's a great thing to play against these teams. But we will never give up. The players are ready.\"\n\nRoared on by some of the biggest and most passionate support at the tournament, the Albanians stunned reigning European champions Italy with a goal after 23 seconds in their opening Group B match.\n\nItaly then scored twice, but Albania agonisingly missed a chance to equalise in the dying minutes.\n\n\"We came close to a draw. Perhaps tomorrow we might win, who knows?\" said Silvinho, who will be relieved to have winger Jasir Asani available against Croatia after an ankle problem.\n\nWith Croatia having also lost their opener, against Spain, both teams desperately need points at the Volksparkstadion, either to progress in their group's top two or as one of the four best third-placed teams.\n\nIt is a first ever meeting between the Balkan nations.\n\nDespite Croatia's 3-0 defeat by Spain, they created chances and possess world-class talent in the likes of midfielder Luka Modric, Sylvinho noted.\n\n\"They have technical skills, great passing, very high quality,\" he said.\n\n\"It's a great pleasure to play against these players ... But we have good players too, our captain has won the Europa League. We have a good mix of experienced and younger players.\"\n\nTeam captain Berat Djimsiti, 31, was integral to Atalanta's Europa League triumph and successful Serie A campaign which earned them a Champions League spot.\n\n\"Croatia is one of the favourites,\" he said alongside his coach at a news conference, adding that hopefully his experience would help the younger players.\n\n\"The matches are very difficult and demanding when you are facing champions, big teams. Any minor issue or mistake can result in a goal. We need to address that in the next match in order to put Croatia into a difficult situation.\"\n\n(Reporting by Andrew Cawthorne; Editing by Ed Osmond)", "source": {"uri": "thestar.com.my", The 2018 World Cup runners-up are currently sat at the bottom of Group A with 1 point from two games and a goal difference of -3. Zlatko Dalic's side are at the serious risk of being knocked out with them facing Italy in their final game of the group stage.\n\nDalic lined up his side in a 4-3-3 with a midfield trio of Marcelo Brozovic, Mateo Kovacic and Luka Modric. From the get go, Croatia looked uninspiring, failing to create any danger and struggling to connect their lines from back to front. Albania looked threatning on the counter and punished them early in the game.\n\nQazim Laci got the faintest of touches on Asani's cross from the right and Croatian goalkeeper failed to keep the ball out of net. Dalic's side have already given up four first half goals this tournament and lost all sense of grip on the game beyond this point struggling to impose or create any meaningful danger.\n\nThe second half substitution did prompt a sense of urgency with Mateo Kovaci moving into a slightly deeper midfield role and Modric pushing up a little. The overall result however was more of the same. They found a spell of effective possession and scored two goals via Andrej Kramaric and an own goal from Klaus Gjasula. Albania pulled a rabbit out of their hat in the 95th minute, with Gjasula turning hero scoring from a cutback and becoming just the second player to score a goal and an own goal in the same Euros game after Anton Ondrus in 1976.\n\nLuka Modric, despite what the numbers might suggest, did not have a great showing. He played the entire 90 minutes attempting and completing over 100 passes, recording six progressive passes, creating two shots and yet his possession play looked underwhelming at times by his godly standards. His incisive vertical passing failed to find teammates in advantageous positions often.\n\nHe tried to do a lot and often to successful measure but Croatia's disjointed nature and weird tactical plan and profiles on the pitch made matters worse. After a long season with Madrid, Modric has looked slightly worn out this tournament thus far.\n\nThe 38-year-old will be hoping for a miracle against defending champions, Italy, in order to advance However, most of those footballers are now in the twilights of their career, with the young players in the squad not quite to the same standard.\n\nDespite their poor performance in their opening game at Euro 2024, their manager feels that there has been a lack of respect given to his team ahead of this tournament.\n\nREAD HERE: The Turkish Commentary For Arda Guler's Worldie Was Amazing\n\nCroatia reached a World Cup final in 2018, having also finished third in the 2022 edition of the tournament. Add to that their third place finish in 1998, and it's fair to say that the Balkan nation have been one of the most successful European countries of the last few decades (even if they have never got beyond the quarter-finals at the Euros). They also came second in the 2023 edition of the UEFA Nations League.\n\nThey have consistently been labelled as 'dark horses' heading into major tournaments during this period, a tag that their manager actually feels is quite disrespectful.\n\nSpeaking ahead of their Euro 2024 game against Albania, Croatia boss Zlatko Dalic threw a cheeky dig at England by comparing the major tournament record between the two nations.\n\nIt wasn't a pretty sight, it wasn't great to watch, we didn't get a great feeling.\n\nBut we are always the dark horse, we are always not among the favourites, nobody believes in us but in the past six years we have won three medals.\n\nAfter France, our national team is the first team to have done this so I always keep saying that Croatia deserves greater respect from everyone else for what we have managed to do.\n\nWe have won three medals, England won one [more than] 50 years ago but they are a great team, we are not, we are always the dark horse.\n\nWe are little but we are brave, we will fight and we have the evidence of thousands of Croats in Berlin. We are a nation that is entitled to feel proud and our results show that we are better than our perception.\n\nI know after this defeat [to Spain] there is a lot of pessimism and negativity but we will give our best and we are doing the best to be the best we can.\n\nEverything we have done in the past six, seven years, we have to look at that and feel proud. Croatia is much better than is said and seen in the public.\n\nCroatia defeated England in the semi-finals of the 2018 World Cup, with the English having finished no better than fourth in any edition of that tournament from 1970 onwards. They were also relegated from the same edition of the UEFA Nations league that the Croatians finished second in.\n\nZlatko Dalic clearly feels that while his side have been underrated by many, the We are always not among the favourites. Nobody believed in us. In the past six years, we've won three medals,\" Dalic told reporters in the lead-up to Wednesday's game, pointing out that their record trails only that of France.\n\n\"So I always keep saying that Croatia deserves greater respect from everyone else for what we've managed to do.\"\n\nTo make his point, the Croatia boss compared his side favourably to frequent underachievers England, who won the World Cup in 1966 and have reached one European Championship final since.\n\n\"We've won three medals. England won one 50 years ago, but they are a great team. We are not... Croatia equalized in the 74th minute when Andrej Kramaric's kick hit the net. The FIFA World Cup 2022 bronze medalist then took the lead in the 76th when Albania's Klaus Gjasula scored an own goal. Eventually, it was Gjasula who managed to secure a draw when he scored in the fifth minute of extra time.\n\nThe other match of Group B's second round will be played between Spain and Italy on Dalic believes Croatia's consistent performance deserves acknowledgement similar to or greater than that of teams like England.\n\nCroatia boss Zlatko Dalic is fed up with his team being treated like dark horses and says the side deserves more respect at Euro 2024 for their past achievements - especially when compared to England. Dalic's side face Albania in Hamburg later on Wednesday, needing to get their campaign back on track after a comprehensive 3-0 defeat to Spain in their Group B opener.\n\nThat result left Croatia licking their wounds, but after reaching the World Cup final in 2018 and finishing in third place four years later in Qatar, Dalic says his side, who also reached the Nations League final last year, should not be written off. \"We are always the dark horse. We are always not among the favourites. Nobody believed in us. In the past six years, we've won three medals,\" Dalic told reporters in the lead-up to Wednesday's game, pointing out that their record trails only that of France.\n\n\"So I always keep saying that Croatia deserves greater respect from everyone else for what we've managed to do.\" To make his point, the Croatia boss compared his side favourably to frequent underachievers England, who won the World Cup in 1966 and have reached one European Championship final since.\n\n\"We've won three medals. England won one 50 years ago, but they are a great team. We are not... {"uri": "8185946156", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "21:02:58", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T21:02:58Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T21:01:43Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4156862795352936, "url": "https://www.nytimes.com/athletic/5575468/2024/06/19/day-six-euro-2024-mls/", "title": "Euro 2024 day six: Germany advance, an MLS strike, comedy goals, don't trust world rankings", "body": "Day six of the European Championship saw the second round of games for six teams, one comical own goal and another own-goal reversal, an unexpected draw (if you believe in world rankings) and the first team through to the knockout stage.\n\nYes, hosts Germany are guaranteed at least one knockout game and it looks like they could be in for a few more after they eased to a 2-0 victory over Hungary in group A. They were also wearing their pink kit for the first time in the tournament, which is the fastest-selling away shirt in the national team's history.\n\nIn the same group we had the first Euros goal ever scored by a player based in MLS (or North or South America for that matter) as Scotland and Switzerland drew 1-1. And the days games actually began with half of the second round of matches in group B where Albania secured that dramatic draw (2-2) with Croatia.\n\nHere our writers run you through the highlights of the day.\n\nA 2-0 victory over Hungary sent Germany through to the last 16, and they got there pretty comfortably. Although they have not played any top sides so far, they look a fearsome prospect and even the better teams in the tournament will not fancy facing them, especially as they are playing at home.\n\nHow would opponents cope with Toni Kroos dropping in at left centre-back, for example? With Antonio Rudiger (pictured top) being happy to bring the ball out, you will always have somebody to watch even in the back line.\n\nIf the Germany full-backs go forward, it pushes Musiala and Florian Wirtz into central pockets of space either side of Kai Havertz, with Gundogan arriving late to back them up, meaning they have four quality players in central areas, and, as we have seen already, some of them are always looking to pick up the ball behind the backs of the opposition midfielders and some are making runs in behind.\n\nIf you, as the opponent, use two holding midfielders to try to add numbers in the middle, you will be trying to deal with Gundogan and one of Musiala or Wirtz, possibly both, leaving Robert Andrich spare. He may not be quite as technically proficient as the others, so you may be happy with that, but Andrich is clearly not a passenger.\n\nBasically, they pose plenty of problems, and beyond the individual quality of the players, you have to consider the fact that their movements are incredibly well synchronised: for example, Wirtz will trot inside from the right to bring the opposition left-back inside while Kroos switches the ball to the right wing, so Joshua Kimmich has plenty of space to receive.\n\nThey look just about as organised as a club side, which is pretty impressive, and they have good options on the bench, too (if Leroy Sane can keep a high level).\n\nThere might be some weaknesses -- it will be interesting to see how the full-backs/Andrich react if they are asked to carry the team's attacking threat, if the opponents pack the middle to take care of Germany's big guns, and while Rudiger and Jonathan Tah are big, imposing centre-backs, they are not especially quick -- but overall, the hosts look capable of doing something special this summer.\n\nAt the other end of the spectrum are Croatia, who were held to a draw with Albania, just the 56 world ranking places beneath them at 66 (more on this later) and are now in danger of failing to make it out of the group. You can track all the permutations here.\n\nSam Lee\n\nSome players are just more at home in international football. Xherdan Shaqiri has barely been a factor in a bad Chicago Fire team this season, scoring just twice in 12 appearances. He hasn't even been an automatic starting choice for them: not ideal for the third-highest earner in the league, at $8million a year. But put a Swiss shirt on him and he comes alive.\n\nShaqiri was actually a surprise selection for Switzerland's second Euro 2024 game against Scotland on Wednesday. But he not only made an impact, he made history: Shaqiri's brilliant strike in the first half, pinging a shot into the top corner of the top corner, was the first time a player in Major League Soccer has found the net in a European Championship game. In fact, he's the first player from a North or South American club to score at Europe's big jamboree.\n\nIt's the sixth major international tournament in a row that he's found the net in: three Euros, three World Cups. And remarkably, he's still only 32.\n\nIf one trend at Euro 2024 is the number of goals being scored from outside the box, another is the early spike in comical own goals.\n\nA fine example came in the Albania's surprise 2-2 draw with Croatia\n\nAfter Croatia equalised, Albania were trying to reset their defensive shape but Elseid Hysaj was too weak in the challenge, allowing Budimir the chance to pull back for Luka Sucic.\n\nBut his free shot was heroically blocked by captain Berat Djimsiti...\n\n... only for the ball to ricochet off Klaus Gjasula and into the net.\n\nGjasula was unlucky, the ball could have gone anywhere (and he redeemed himself in stoppage time), but it rolled over the line and became the latest hugely unlucky own goal at this tournament.\n\nThere was Germany's Antonio Rudiger accidentally heading the ball backwards into his own net.\n\nAnd Austria's Maximilian Wober also nodding one in (see below) or the ball deflecting off Robin Hranac for the Czech Republic against Portugal.\n\nThis one felt like the cruellest. Albania, just like against Italy, were ahead and could have pulled off the greatest result in their footballing history. They missed out on that chance but they at least rescued a point through that man again, Gjasula.\n\nAnd day six concluded with some administrative own-goal drama.\n\nWhen Fabian Schar raised his leg and deflected Scotland midfielder Scott McTominay's shot from its trajectory into the goalkeeper's arms and instead speared it into the top corner of Switzerland's goal, UEFA gave it as an own goal.\n\nThat brought protest from Scottish supporters and pundits and shortly before the end of the game UEFA reversed its decision, instead awarding the goal to McTominay.\n\nSlovakia's 1-0 win against Belgium on Monday was the biggest European Championship upset ever, with 45 places between the teams. On Wednesday, Albania (66) drew with Croatia (10).\n\nThe problem in football is that international sides only play about a dozen matches a year. Some of those will pit world-beaters against minnows, and others will be non-competitive matches, so there isn't much information to factor into the rankings.\n\nThe precise algorithm used to calculate the rankings has been criticised and subsequently overhauled several times: in 1999, 2006 and most notably, 2018, after complaints that various sides -- particularly Switzerland and Poland -- were trying to 'game' the system by limiting the number of friendlies they played.\n\nThat's different from a sport like tennis or golf, where the best in the world regularly participate in the same tournaments and compete directly against one another. There, a fair ranking system is considerably easier to formulate.\n\nIn 1970, there were no official seeds, and FIFA formed four pots of sides solely in order to keep certain teams apart (Israel and Morocco, in particular).\n\nAhead of the 1974 World Cup, there was a behind-closed-doors vote on which sides would be seeded. For the next few tournaments, the organising committee at least made that session public.\n\nBut this clearly wasn't particularly scientific, and it was only from 1990 onwards that actual empirical results -- performances at previous World Cups -- were taken into consideration. But that effectively discriminated against emerging nations, so from 1998 (the rankings were considered too new to have much meaning in 1994), FIFA could factor in official rankings when selecting the seeds.\n\nSo while the precise rankings system remains something of a mystery to even the keenest football followers, it's worth reiterating that the FIFA rankings do serve a purpose. If the alternative is FIFA executives arbitrarily deciding on seedings among themselves, then it's probably worth having official rankings.\n\nMichael Cox\n\nAnd the good news is we get to do it all again on Thursday...", "source": {"uri": "nytimes.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The New York Times"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Florian_Wirtz", "type":
